raw_text.5: slight spoilers one of the best things about literary fiction is being held in thrall by the sheer power of an unusual voice sometimes a unique voice is disastrous but in peter heller's dog stars i was swept away by the most powerful prose i've read in a very long time genuine and moving this book manages to teach lessons about the true nature of human existence while simultaneously being very quiet and introverted here's what i loved 1 the character development is superb even the dog jasper was as real to me as people i actually know and when spoiler alert he dies i was literally sobbing i really mean it whether you love or hate his writing style the author deserves major kudos for the exquisitely rendered humanity of all the characters in this harrowing book even the ones who aren't actually human 2 the story is unflinchingly honest there is no artifice here there is only a story so purely real it resonates on another level than most books i read my heart ached for the protagonist for the beauty and horror for everything lost and the few tiny scraps of hope that can save a man from madness or despair there is great violence and also great tenderness here and all of it is handled with the care of an artist who knows exactly what he wants to say and how to get a reader to feel the weight of his conviction to the theme in subtle emotional ways 3 the prose my god the f'ing prose i stood in the shade of the tree in the cool breath of the moving water and let the sound the light breeze blow through me i was a shell empty put me to your ear and you would hear the distant rush of a ghost ocean just nothing the slightest pressure of current or tide could push and roll me i would wash up here on this bank dry out and bleach and the wind would scour and roughen me strip away the thinnest layers until i was brittle and the thickness of paper until i crumbled into sand that's how i felt i'd say it was a relief to have at last nothing nothing but i was too hollow to register relief too empty to carry it there is a beatiful stop start push pull cadence to the prose that is at once lyrical and simple it's like the literary love child of william styron and ernest hemingway it's achingly beautiful yet without a whiff of pretense which is a pretty spectacular feat in and of itself ok i'm done raving bottom line not only is the dog stars worth reading i think it should be required reading not everyone will get it and that's okay but everyone who reads should be exposed to this level of genius it will make you a more discerning reader and just maybe a more discerning person

raw_text.17: i don't know about you but picking out holiday presents for the men in my life is like going fishing i never know if i'm going to land a keeper or a guppie the dog stars is the guy book of the year and by guy i mean actual manly men who do manly things not only that once your giftee finishes you can mine the book for all kinds of thought provoking writer tricks so without further ado basic premise man vs nature man and himself use this as your lead line when said present is unpacked it will hook 'em when asked for further details by other likely female interested parties hig a survivor of a pandemic flu that wipes out the known human race retreats to the community now deserted around the air strip where he keeps his plane with his dog jasper warning jasper is old and fights to survive he makes an ally who is a weapons master they are attacked by unfriendlies hig eventually leaves to find more survivors cue eve this book has got everything a guy reader could want guns planes dogs fishing hunting fighting for survival adam and eve note this is not a kids' book even poetry didn't see that coming right neither did i but heller uses it boldly and uses it well what can the writer can take away from this piece heller is a poet so the very style of word on page is as unique as a fingerprint rules of grammar aren't just bent or broken they've been reinvented for instance heller uses no italics to set off dialogue often he doesn't even set it off at all that made reading at times a little harder it also for me distanced the story from the here and now on the other hand his overall style came across as journaling so for some it could make the telling more intimate at the very least not using quotation marks is a very nifty tool if you can figure out how to use it i'm still working on that part
raw_text.18: of the dozen or so post apocalyptic novels i've read the dog stars is probably the most unique and stands out amid the bleak war torn nature of its genre in a way that i wouldn't have thought possible i was having trouble coming up with the exact way i wanted to word it so i glanced through a few of the reviews on goodreads and found the exact word i needed in a few of them beautiful this truly and almost unsettingly given how much of the world has gone to hell is a beautiful novel it is the story of hig a former pilot who flies his small cessna plane around the perimeter of the colorado sanctuary him and his gun happy militant companion bangley have set up and defend with vigilance it is clear from the beginning of the novel just how deserted north america is this particular apocalypse coming from a disease that spared a very very few who were immune for whatever reason accompanying hig and providing an inspiration for the novel's title is his faithful companion jasper whereas hig and bangley though tightly allied and loyal to one another don't even come close to resembling friends given their differences jasper is hig's companion and best friend in all things even serving as hig's navigator when he flies that's about as far as i can go with the plot without revealing things that are better left to the reader to find out i will say that if you have any interest in this genre or even just like stories of the outdoors you have no reason not to read this excellent book's fascinating take on the topic
raw_text.19: i loved this debut novel a spare and bittersweet story of survival in rural colorado after a disease induced apocalypse the strength in this tale lies in heller's portrayal of grief stricken hig who is continually balancing his lyrical introspections on finding meaning in his narrowed life and his cherishing of the beauty that remains hig has been living a lonely life for nine years after an epidemic flu killed off most of humanity he has settled at a remote airport north of denver where there is solar power and fuel for his cessna plane houses nearby for scavenging a plot for gardening and open ground for his survivalist partner bangley to efficiently kill off periodic marauders with his stockpiled arsenal but bangley doesn't talk much so hig spends a lot of time talking to his blue heeler dog jasper together they find some solace on hunting and fishing excursions where he communes with nature and grieves over the loss of his wife and the loss of species due to global warming his true escape comes from the sense of freedom he gets from flying he scouts the perimeter for threats and periodically visits a community of mennonites from which he must keep his distance due to a blood disease slowly killing them off but everything changes when he spots from his plane a remote box canyon with signs of civilized life a house with smoke from a chimney and a woman out gardening heller's experience as a non fiction "adventure writer" shows with his lovely telegraphic prose about nature as in this piece about fishing with his dog sometimes back then fishing with jasper up the sulphur i hit my limit i mean it felt my heart might just burst bursting is different from breaking like there is no way to contain how beautiful not it either not just beauty something about how i fit this little bend of smooth stones the leaning cliffs the smell of spruce the small cutthroat making quiet rings in the black water of a pool and no need to thank even just be just fish just walk up the creek get dark get cold it is all a piece of me somehow the relief he gets from his bird's eye view of the world from his plane is wonderfully captured in this passage and for a time while flying seeing all this as a hawk would see it i am myself somehow freed from the sticky details i am not grief sick nor stiffer in the joints nor ever lonely nor someone who lives with the nausea of having killed and seems destined to kill again i am the one who is flying over all of it looking down nothing can touch me there is no one to tell this to and yet it seems very important to get this right the reality and what it is like to escape it that even now it is too beautiful to bear also i wonder how bangley is built inside and everyone like him he is at home in his solitude as the note reverberating inside a bell prefers it will protect it to the death lives for protecting it the way a peregrine lives for killing other birds midflight does not want to communicate what the death and the beauty do to each other inside him the stars in the book are a perpetual reminder of how small humans are in the scheme of things as in this example now we walk fast in the dark me and jasper the sled scraping behind cold good and cold high stars nettle the black no moon crossing under the milky way like crossing a deep river never will get to the other side we never do like survivors of war the killing it takes to exist can be taken in stride but the associated losses along the way undermine the victory the dead goats multiply you can pull a goat off into the field but a memory you can only haul into the sun and hope it dessicates dries to something crumbled and odorless hig is fond of certain chinese poets and takes solace in these lines which appear to be heller's own emulation we have traveled now you will be the pathi will walk i will walkover you thus the book stands out from the "genre" of post apocalyptic tales in its artful dwelling on what in life is worth preserving the vignettes about nature and the love story in the novel suffer from being a bit too "precious" but they moved me a lot nonetheless some other quotable quotes are raw_text.24: the fact that this is a debut novel is absurd but it's not like peter heller doesn't have a plethora of writing experience his vast knowledge of survival techniques and aviation comes into play all over this book a unique and well told apocalyptic story dog stars picks up right where most apocalyptic stories end it's been about a decade since the majority of humanity was wiped out people being horrible is no longer surprising or even disgusting and yet the protagonists continue struggling to survive it's a fascinatingly optimistic story and one that took me by surprise given some of the downright depressing things that are littered throughout working within a genre that's gotten an unnerving amount of play recently why do we love the end of the world so much heller managed to craft a unique and realistic story that somehow managed to maintain a certain faith in humanity

raw_text.30: beautiful this whole book reads like lyric poetry an extended lamentation and celebration for a world destroyed by illness in a post apocalyptic world 99% of the population has been wiped out by a flu mutation hig has lost his wife who was 7 months pregnant with their first child he now faces the task of finding meaning in a world that has been stripped down to the bone the survivors are often violent those who are left are forced to kill each other in fear and desperation hig narrates the tortured contents of his consciousness with succinct beauty in the midst of complete devastation he finds moments of sweetness love even happiness this is a book about the soul and about the heart it is a story that argues that even in the face of the most tremendous loss a person might find reasons to live and reasons to rejoice this book is full of so much sadness and so much hope that i felt ready to burst with it the narration is unusual short direct and fragmented reflecting the broken world it seeks to uncover hig is a character that i will not quickly forget his voice is musical and dream like i read this book in two evenings and drank down every word

raw_text.37: this is a review of the audiobook versioni would not have thought that there was such a thing as a literary dystopia but peter heller has managed to write one at times lovely and poetic at other times crude and violent the dog stars is one of the most realistic and lovely postapocalyptic tales i've read it reminded me a bit of laura kasischke's in a perfect world and as ti and alyce both said a lighter and gentler version of cormac mccarthy's the road the writing is often lyrical and gorgeous the passages on grief and loss were some of the best i've ever read in addition the descriptions of outdoor pursuits like fishing and hunting made me think of norman mclean's writing in a river runs through it yet for all the lovely parts there are equal measures of stream of consciousness fragments that take some getting used to there are also moments of brute violence that contrast sharply with the more lyrical parts it is an interesting book and i enjoyed it once i got used to its odd rhythms and pace as in many dystopias the dog stars takes place in a world where almost the entire human and animal population has been wiped out by a virulent flu our narrator hig an outdoorsman pilot and poet is eking out a living at a small airfield in colorado with only his dog jasper for company his closest neighbor and ally is bangley a taciturn weapons expert who lets his guns do the talking for him together hig and bangley have carved out a life and routine for themselves hig patrols their territory from the air in his 1950s cessna while bangley provides firepower and tactics for dealing with the less than friendly strangers who sometimes visit their lonely outpost this is a world where you shoot first and ask questions later an approach that doesn't naturally fit hig and his lack of commitment to bangley's methods often get him into trouble with bangley being such a closed down person hig's best friend and constant companion is jasper with whom hig talks to as if he was a person after life changing events shake up hig's world he decides to leave the relative safety of the airfield and go past his point of no return to chase after a long ago radio transmission he heard years earlier the things i liked most about this book was how grounded and realistic it felt heller really seems to have considered what might work and not work given the situation he created for his characters how long gas would last what kind of food would be available it felt like hig and bangley were the type of people who could survive in such a world in addition i liked how hig and bangley form a kind of symbiotic relationship that becomes richer and deeper over the course of the book but what makes the book work most of all is hig's voice his confusion ambivalence practicality optimism and poeticism made him a deeply likable character you want things to turn out for him although it takes awhile to get into his head and the rhythms of his thoughts you'll like what you find there if you're looking for a dystopia written for grown ups this would be an excellent choice about the narration narrator mark deakins had quite a challenge as sentences were often choppy and fragmented there were also times when i was a bit confused about whether something was a conversation or just hig thinking but deakins did an excellent job and created a voice for hig that felt authentic his voices for the other characters particularly bangley and pops were terrific and it was easy to tell when they were talking although this might be a book where reading it in print might be easier than listening on audio it was a worthy listen

raw_text.39: written in an engaging and unique style the dog stars is a novel that will make you smile despite it being set in a grim and unrelenting world a flu epidemic has killed everyone except a few isolated survivors hig traumatised and grieving after the death of his wife and everyone he knows lives a bleak existence only three things keep him sane - his faithful dog jasper his gun toting neighbour and his cessna airplane hig regularly takes off into the sky to check the perimeter of airfield he lives near people who turn up have a habit of trying to kill hig and his neighbour so they must be vigilant but then one day he hears a random transmission on his plane's radio and it ignites a hope that a better life might exist beyond the airport one day he makes the decision to fly past the point of no return without enough fuel to get him back home and that's when the novel truly starts and he encounters things that are both better and worse than he could have hoped for this novel is completely riveting - it is savagely funny and breathtakingly sad all at once - and it is completely different from anything else i have read before more reviews on www karenm co nz

to survive not only physically but emotionally and spiritually as well in a world that has fallen apart i initially had a hard time getting into the story i think there were two reasons heller's writing is rather poetic lacking much of the punctuation and structure i prefer in prose i had to adjust to the rhythm and pacing of his language the other reason is connected to the first i began by reading a digital galley and the formatting was confusing normally i don't have an issue with this but heller's writing depends on things like line breaks and page layout to make sense when those aspects are absent from the form it is really hard to tell who is speaking or what is going on i switched to a paper arc thank goodness i had it in both formats and found it much easier to read after that i have not seen a finished digital copy of this book but readers might want to see if they can sample it on their ereaders before purchasing in case the formatting wasn't entirely fixed the plot of the dog stars was fine but didn't impress me much i might just be too burned out on these kinds of stories there's something in the current zeitgeist that has resulted in a flood of post apocalyptic tales and it can take a bit to distinguish one from another for me when the real end comes i expect i'll be thoroughly bored by it i was quite bored with the first part of this book as well it takes its time setting up the characters and the world and combined with the stream of consciousness narration it was plodding at times more happens later in the book which managed to keep me engaged so i didn't abandon my reading the main character hig has a really touching love for his dog and keeps himself sane by flying his plane much of what he doesn't isn't so much for survival as it is to keep life worth living for him a lot of the plot is very internal early on and didn't seem to pick up until there were more actual events and some danger to spice up the story i expect that there will be many fans of this book but i'm left feeling a bit lukewarm there are some lovely passages and it's nice to think that the death of most of humanity can leave a man feeling so spiritually raw_text.96: a view for the apocalypse after a pandemic wipes out most of the population hig a pilot and his dog jasper team up with bangly to create an life bangly is crazy but he's the kind of crazy you need on your side when starving people are likely to creep up on you in the night with bats and swords their life is comfortable but always on edge heller does a great job of creating that world where everything could be taken from you by people just like you who just want to keep on living this world isn't bleak it's often quite peaceful and simple but there is always the chance of a threat to come and destroy it inside hig's head is a world of sadness his need to find human connection leads him to take risks first with a mennonite group who have the blood disease and then by flying beyond his fuel capacity to look for the people behind a signal he received years ago in his plane this story isn't about destruction it's about rebuilding as opposed to many other distopian books it leaves you with a sense that we are not doomed that there will always be people who care people who will reach out heller's writing style is tight and sparse there are no wasted words here some of the sentences are clipped or choppy but those few words can convey more than a flowery description any day
raw_text.97: three and a half stars i need to start with this i get that this cormac mccarthy we don' need no steenking punctuation style is a thing nowadays i just don't get why it really hurts the flow of the writing in my opinion it's jarring to have to stop on a somewhat regular basis and work out what's meant to be dialogue and what isn't that peeve aside this was a pretty good story i really disliked the ending but i get that this will be a highly subjective matter hig has been thrust reluctantly into the role of post apocalypse survivor due to an outbreak of a superflu strain he lives at an airport with bangley who enjoys needling hig nearly as much as he enjoys killing anyone who stumbles across their humble abode the death of hig's dog jasper prompts a momentous decision on hig's part outstanding setting in this not just the wild beauty of colorado but the constant reminders both obvious and subtle that the world has changed drastically heller tends to his characters as devoutly as hig watches over the group of sick mennonites who live near the airport and it's clear he cherishes even their most fundamental flaws all in all a good balance of what it means to be human in a world mostly empty of people and a sense of hope not for salvation but for dignity and living life on one's own terms a concept profoundly missing from on the beach and the road which is perhaps why i found the former so depressing and the latter galling to the point that i couldn't finish it

raw_text.150: the dog stars by peter heller is not my usual type of book i know there are readers who regularly read post apopolytic end of the world fiction but i am not one of them perhaps i should start reading more of that genre because i really enjoyed this book the main character is hig he is a pilot who lost his wife to the pandemic flu he is living simply with his dog jasper and another man bangley hig is a simple man he gardens fishes and misses the world that was this is more than just a band of roving bandits attacking each other though there is some of that story this is a love story platonic love between two men who care for each other and would die for each other between a man and his dog a man and his land memories dreams the writing is different stark it fit well with the smallness of the world that was left bangley held his coke in both hands in his lap he kind of hunched over himself maybe remembering suddenly remote like his spirit retreated to a safer distance to watch from a distance still rocking the chair that didn't rock

raw_text.152: a post apocalypse novel about a man his dog and survival written in the first person hig basically tells his story by giving you a voyeur's perspective into his mind i found the style at first to be difficult to follow imagine a book without a single quotation mark but as the book progressed it became an essential part of telling the story sort of like sitting around the campfire and telling ghost stories in fits and starts incomplete sentences asides taking tangents but always coming back to the main story the story is full of tragedy but with the light moments that everyone has even in the worst of times and surprisingly hope in the face of all that tragedy there are horrible things here the end of civilization man reverting to hobbesian nature but also love compassion daring trust in fate kinship of spirit even between species and quests both minor and great if you can make it through a couple of chapters and get use to the flow of thoughts you will be moved by this i lift my head off the pillowi see the frosted moon i lower it down i think of home li po

raw_text.165: review first published on my blog http memoriesfrombooks blogspot com the dog stars is the story of a post apocalyptic world nine years have passed since a disease killed most of the population of the world and most of the natural life a few survivors remain some are infected with contagious diseases and still attempt to live life some are infected and have gone feral a very few are immune and the survivors hig is one of the immune survivors he has seen his life his family and his world destroyed he lives with his dog at an airport he flies an old 1950s cessna and attempts to live some kind of a life most of his life is dedicated to simply surviving food provisions and the fight again bands of invaders yet he finds moments of hope and beauty even in this world mountains and trees starting to come back to life his attempts to help families living with the disease his love for his dog and his hope found in a random transmission caught on his radio hig shares his airport home with bangley an old soldier who loves guns and focuses on survival and protection one day hig decides to risk this life and pursue the hope that the radio transmission brought to him the risk lies in the fact that the origination point of the transmission is beyond his point of no return with the fuel capacity of his plane if he flies out he will not have the fuel to return unless he finds a source out there what he finds out here brings disillusionment sorrow and hope in different ways but that would be giving too much away post apocalyptic novels are not my usual genre yet i really enjoyed this one the focus of the story is on hope human relationships and human emotions all the makings of a good book the writing style is succinct and sometimes fragmented yet in this story it works it seems to reinforce the fragmented nature of hig's life and emotions as the constant struggle to survive and hold grief at bay continues i am not sure i will seek out more post apocalyptic novels but i am glad i read this one

raw_text.171: i forgot where i saw someone write that a book hangover is time you spend thinking about a book after you've finished it before you can start another the dog stars has left me with a killer book hangover i fall in love with a book maybe once every two or three years the last one was thread of grace and now i have fallen in love with the dog stars that's not something i thought i'd ever say about a book of post apocalyptic fiction the dog stars takes place nine years after a killer flu wipes out 99 9% of humanity i won't go in to the plot at all except to say that it keeps you riveted to the pages it's the writing and the characters that makes this novel great it's the kindness compassion and raw humanity of hig's inner landscape that takes your breath away heller has developed a unique style of stream of consciousness that slowly blends in and out of traditional narrative a lot of people including myself have a hard time with stream of consciousness but i had no trouble with this book because of the way it's integrated into the flow of the story you may know heller from his time as an npr contributor but this is his debut novel and it is a rare gem something truly special

raw_text.177: welcome to the compassionate side of distopian fiction where cormac mccarthy drags us down the gut wrenching road peter heller sees an aspect to our humanity that does beyond survival i thought of harlan ellison's a boy and his dog for an instant since the novel concerns a man cruising the post apocalypse with dog as his co pilot where ellison more than hints that we as a race get what we deserve heller agrees but concedes that what we deserve what we are capable of is seeing the beauty it what still is his stint as editor of such man reads as outside magazine men's journal and natgeo outdoors serves him well here i loved his novel kook about an everyman compelled to embrace the california dream of surfing here again he captures the true heart of masculinity tough guarded and deep with suppressed emotions in this novel our pilot forced off the grid by global tragedy hovers above the remains hunting and fishing not only for survival but for the link it has to his old life then he hears a radio transmission like the whisper of a promise and he ventures forth to recapture what he almost lost community

raw_text.236: what an amazing reading experience this is gut wrenching tender heart breaking life affirming exquisitely written and with some truly affecting beautifully drawn characters including a dog called jasper as a long time sf reader i am willing to invest extra effort in a text and am always up for a challenge heller adopts a writing style in the dog stars as unvarnished and rough spun as some of his characters sentences are jumbled many are only single words paragraphs are separated by line breaks there are no speech marks but once you get the hang of this you soon understand how heller uses this style to modulate the rhythm of his story and to let his characters and set pieces breathe i am unsure if mainstream fiction readers are as open to experimentation as sf readers but i suspect some people are going to be so distracted by the mechanics of the writing style that they will be unable to see past it to the heart of the story which will be a real pity so hang in there this is a truly remarkable novel i was amazed to discover that this is the first novel by peter heller a writer of nature articles who is now in his 50s hopefully he doesn't wait too long to write another there has been a spate of end of the world novels of late with a new delhi superbug dealing humanity the death blow in the dog stars i was amused that one of the regions unaffected is the middle east with the a rabs as one character calls them actually forming a crucial plot point near the end once again peter heller proves you can take any old cliche and turn it into something truly wondrous the simple story is about a pilot called hig and how he ekes out a living at an abandoned airport in colorado with his dog jasper and a neighbour called bangley the ornery give and take relationship between these two diametric characters is what makes the dog stars such a joy to read indeed one gets to invest so much emotionally in these characters that there are certain points in the novel that are likely to reduce any reader to tears one of these moments is the reason that compels hig to climb into his cessna and fly away into the blue yonder until his fuel runs out a sort of amelia earhart cum out of africa type romantic send off what heller does instead with this is rather miraculous instead of ending the story goes off in another direction completely there is not a single wrong word or false note here and reader expectations are confounded even further when heller switches into thriller mode and delivers a nail biting climax heller's knowledge of and love for the countryside is abundantly clear however he is no sentimentalist this is a grim and bleak novel with some unsettling scenes of violence we gradually learn that no one in this fallen world is innocent or unscarred and yet at the end it is hig's faith and love that shine through in heller's remarkable narrative voice that is like a combination of john irving and david guterson superb
raw_text.237: the exploration of good and evil in this post apocalyptic story is told in a sparse often disjunctive language i admit took me a bit to get into cadence hig our narrator is a soaring spirit of hope that triumphs over heartbreak trauma and insurmountable struggles there are moments of unexpected happiness of real human interaction infused with love and hope like the twinkling of a star we might wish upon which makes this end of the world novel a timely must read

raw_text.266: review of an arc courtesy of net galley and the publisher the dog stars is exactly what i had hoped it would be a taut exhilarating hopeless yet hopeful novel of a near future dystopian america hig is a fully realized flawed yet likeable narrator who holds onto the beauty of the country despite the decimated population and roving gangs at first glance hig's partner bangley is a straightforward weapons nut intent on defending their safe zone around the airport heller though throws in some characterization curveballs that force the reader to adapt their view of him just as hig does the author's prose vacillates between adrenaline fueled scenes of danger and dreamlike ruminations on one's past and present states it's a wonderful combination that keeps the reader immersed and on edge throughout the book four and a half stars recommended for fans of literary or dystopian fiction

raw_text.281: this is a story about hig who lives on a hanger with his dog jasper after a flu pandemic takes out most of the population his only neighbor and human companion is a volatile gun survivalist that seems perfectly content in a world ruled by violence hig and jasper on the other hand find their salvation securing the perimeter in a 1956 cessna that sails off into an open sky and gives them some sense of purpose and escape from a world both broken and dangerous hig tries to focus on the immediacy of the beauty around him by living for the moment but his isolation and loneliness is palpable jasper is really the only tenacious thread that keeps his hold on humanity most of the other survivors it seems are wasting away from the effects of the blood disease or lawless elements that would as soon cut your throat as look at you surviving is a question of someone having your back life is a ritual the dog stars is not a book without its share of suspense and action but it is also a book rich with stark vivid images of true beauty with its descriptions of isolation regret loss and sorrow it becomes a metaphor for life itself it becomes a challenge to know what barriers are necessary to survive and what barriers must come down to even make survival desirable the dog stars is more than a post apocalyptic book it is a book about discovery and a book about hope surviving in the darkest of days and in the strangest of ways
raw_text.282: there are many things to like about this book peter heller writes such sweet lyrical prose that it almost takes you out of the horror his characters are living i loved that hig the story's teller was still able to see so much natural beauty all around him even though the world had ended and been replaced with a nightmare he also finds loveliness and a familial connection in the people he happens to meet who decide not to kill him just be cause he might be a threat to them but wait to see if he might be worth trusting worth saving worth forming a bond with he remains positive in a dark world and he finds light where it still exists even when it might be hiding bravo peter heller i will read anything you write

raw_text.286: the dog stars brings you into the day to day world of hig an airplane pilot and his faithful dog jasper after an event a flu pandemic that has left them alive but forced to make difficult concessions and moral gymnastics in order to survive trusting no one hig and the majority of survivors have adopted a kill or be killed mentality hole up and endure but the story doesn't stop there the dog stars moves well beyond the majority of dystopian post apocalyptic novels by addressing hig's conflicted nature and finding the overlap between a core morality juxtaposed in a life and death existence how thin do relationships spread without a thread of trust if you're looking for zombies you'll have to look elsewhere but who needs to worry about zombies when you've got survivors who'd kill you for soda or ammo i was impressed by a very credible love story that begins to bloom even as a rolling ecological disaster makes the new lovers aware how futile their time together is or how precious even in its darkest scenes the dog stars will make you challenge yourself to think what would i do the dog stars is a very well crafted highly compelling read

raw_text.314: a post apocalyptic book without zombies warring factions cannibalism or gangs of roaming savages i don't know why i couldn't have visualized it until this book but i was genuinely surprised to find a quiet poetic dystopian novel which is strange because it seems natural that in any post apocalyptic scenario there will be but a brief time of chaos and destruction and then the few survivors will have to settle down to the slow meticulous lonely work of getting on with life the dog stars tells one of those stories hig lives a solitary life with his dog jasper on a small homestead near an airport in what used to be colorado he has formed a small detached alliance with his cranky gun toting survivalist neighbor but the story does not focus on that relationship so much as that relationship allows hig the space and range to tell his story of flying hiking remembering and seeking it is a slow story with lovely imagery and poetic language but when hig is lured away from their small homestead by the possibility of other human interactions the book picks up some plot and a little more speed not so much that we lose track of heller's lovely prose or the internal patter that hig keeps up on his own but enough to provide a whole story and hold the interest of readers who want more than just beautiful language it never becomes a page turner but for fans of literary fiction who want a different kind of setting to delve into the human spirit and watch characters unfold you could hardly pick a more strange and lovely place than heller's rocky mountain airstrip

raw_text.317: i was disappointed the writing is reflective lyrical and fairly well done but the narrative wandered too much for my liking i also found myself torn between my own thoughts about the story especially the back story of the book on the one hand i was grateful for post apocalyptic novel that didn't dwell on the details of whatever disaster tore apart civilized life for the survivors but then i kept asking what happened the story is dark and violent throughout which guess what is kind of the way these stories go these days i guess we already know the post apocalyptic america will be tense and brutal just plain ugly that seems to be the agreed upon view in the genre the dog stars on the other hand makes an effort to show that it is not necessarily a heartless world in an ironic way peter heller uses a lot of bloodshed to create a more tender story if this book ever makes it to contemporary hollywood watch out if you're into quick reads violence and friendship and pages of a man describing rediscovered consummated love this is your book or if you happen to be in a book club certainly this one will get a recommendation or two i suggest reading the first ten pages before deciding this will prett much tell you what you will get

raw_text.326: i realize i've set the bar pretty low by reading so much poppy pulp trash for so long but this book still stands out -- above -- most of the other post apocalyptic novels i've been strangely unable to stop myself from reading yes the twelve has literary qualities and ambitions but its still much too reliant on its plotting and the cosmology of its vampires to make it much more than a really good thriller dog stars is not so concerned about how society ended or even really precisely about how it continues although in a sense that is exactly what it's about but instead focuses on the losses and the grieving and the psychological battle of a survivor to be more than just a being that continues to live the costs of survival are staggering and so we follow hig as he staggers often literally through some of the most beautiful yet desolate pa landscapes both geographical and emotional you may ever encounter hig's narrative voice feels fresh to me which was unexpected and welcome when i started it i thought the pseudo stream of consciousness was going to be tedious and that i might struggle getting through it but not at all despite spending the whole novel in hig's addled head i was never bored and the action his dogged determination to get more from what is left of life pulled me right along plus i have to say there are some nice turns of phrase and beautiful ideas and bits of language sprinkled throughout that make your reading a surprising treat it's not overdone not like heller was trying to hard to be literary it's just well done which makes it great example this oft highlighted passage grief is an element it has it's own cycle like the carbon cycle the nitrogen it never diminishes not ever it passes in and out of everything 115 or this nothing to lose is so empty so light that the sand you crumble to at last blows away in a gust so insubstantial it's carried upwards to shirr into the sandstorm of the stars that's where we all get to the rest is just wearing thin waiting for wind 197 even one of the sex scenes -- in which hig imagines himself and his partner disintegrating blown apart the remains of their bodies raining raw_text.329: the dog stars a debut novel by peter heller succeeds on so many levels it's almost frightening it is a piece of literary fiction that is likely to be a best seller it is a dystopic future tale that is nevertheless full of beauty it is a moving novel that illustrates the horror of climate change without ever mentioning climate change heller paints a grim picture of the world we are even now sculpting populates it with people who are desperately violent or violently desperate but leavens it with a triumph of the human spirit in the form of hig one of the most endearing and unlikely heroes to show up in fiction in a long time

raw_text.336: the prose is muscular and incisive given human nature this describes a post apocalyptic world well within the realm of possibility the novel ranks alongside on the beach many good reviewers could not get into the style which i fully appreciate i had trouble myself for a chapter or two then i got into the rhythm of it when i was able to pick up the cadence and see with hig's eyes hig had only bangley to talk to and bangley was a man of very few words therefore the prose was as parsed as hig's thoughts must have been the author masterfully drew me into hig's mind observing the terrain anticipating the next calamity reminiscing about lost trout and lost love and hoping for a better future it helped that i flew a plane very much like the beast fished some of the same waters that hig did and lost a dog very much like jasper i could sympathize and connect with this humane man in an inhumane world there were some unforgettable scenes hig fleeing from intruders and bangley covering his retreat from the watchtower hig discovering the woman and her father in their hidden camp with only a little fuel left in the plane terrific pulse pounding descriptions and intense action enduring images painted by great words my guess is that someone is already planning a movie

raw_text.338: first of all let me begin by stating that i am a college professor who by our own nature are highly critical of the written and spoken word it is rare that i gush over a book and tell and want many others read it this is that book this is one of the best books of 2013 the main character hig is surviving in a world that has been wiped out by a flu like pandemic he jasper his dog and bangley his colorful neighbor live in an abandoned airport hig's inner demon is the loss of his wife and his yearning to find other survivors this yearning is fueled by a call when flying over another several years before this one call gives hig hope and serves as the premise of the book on every plane ride the author writes as if you as a reader are flying side by side with hig experience the wind the scenery and the thrill of flying at its core this book is a love story but in a unusual sense it is a love story of the appreciation of nature of flying animals humankind and the little things that we all take for granted i know that statement sounds trite and bathetic but the statement is true it makes the reader or listener fall in love with simplicity and the yearning for human contact scene 4 as far as post apocalyptic fiction goes this is by far one of the best because of one main reason this story is believable when the after does occur it would not have to involve war alien attacks zombie like sickness or humans living in silos like the popular wool and dust series convey the book is excellent because of the simplicity of plot wrapped with beautiful imagery of not only raw_text.345: damn okay this was really excellent i am sure this is an example of where the audio version made the book better the complaints i read about this was that the writing was difficult to read at times too choppy i had both the ebook and the audio and bounced back and forth occasionally i may have made the same complaint if i were reading it the audio version is read by mark deakins wonderfully he does the heavy lifting of reading choppy sentences that do not contain any quotations his voices are believable his reading was brilliantly paced and he brought each character to life in a way that such writing may have more right to the writing is stark and brief at times it is also surprisingly poetic and quotable the language and dialogue seem utterly believable i do hope to never need to verify that statement i see the comparisons to the road the end of the world and stylistic similarities are there i loved the road and will now reread it for comparison there was unless memory fails me even more beauty and certainly more optimism in the world of the dog stars people are nasty but there is still some hope the main characters of hig bangley cima and pops and jasper hig's dog are all people you would want to know and would certainly want on your side of a fire fight at the end of the world
raw_text.346: i read this yesterday and literally could not put it down it's an unusual story told in an unusual way and not a whole lot happens that would sound like a terrible book but peter heller keeps it very interesting it's really story about humans and relationships and trying to keep a sense of normal in a world that is anything but the characters all seem believable they all resemble someone i know even the unhinged bangley who is likely unhinged because everything is very much not normal characters make rational choices and behave exactly as you'd expect real people in their situation to behave there's very few honestly bad guys i can only think of one group of marauders who behave in the stereotypical i'm a bad guy and i do bad things because i'm a bad guy kind of way everyone else is just conflicted unlike the road this apocalyptic tale doesn't take place in a world devoid of hope in a refreshing twist it's very much about the human condition and making the absolute best of a very bad situation and carving out your own slice of heaven in a neverending hell of a world absolutely one of the best apocalyptic novels i've read in a long time and it shows that too many focus on the wrong things it's not about the world it's about the characters and how they respond to it

raw_text.348: in a genre rife with post apocalyptic themes peter heller provides a unique and entertaining novel he does this through the terse clipped and often fragmented prose that at first is difficult to read once you get accustomed to the style you find it is congruent with the main character hig a pilot who has taken refuge in an abandoned airport with his dog and a rather brash half crazy survivalist his life is indeed fragmented and cruel but through it all he thinks back to before the disease and death in a attempt to hang onto his morality bangley his gun nut neighbor at the airport sees this as noting but weakness and something that will get you killed in the new world of chaos and death in this way the prose reflects the main characters for me a colorado native the scenery is familiar and the activities ones i can relate to flying the front range in my father's cessna trout fishing hiking the hills with my favorite dog are all parts of my upbringing in this way the details of those actions clearly articulated and activities the author knows firsthand lend a level of credibility to the story
raw_text.349: i've always enjoyed a good post apocalyptic novel be it zombie alien or as in the dog stars a super flu that has wiped out 99% of the population what stands out in the debut novel by peter heller is a world filled with both the ugliness of human behavior almost in contrast with immense beauty of the landscape as seen from the main character's old cessna and in the end this is a novel filled with a cautious hope and optimism that just maybe love and compassion can survive hig lost his wife to the flu some 9 years prior to the events that start the novel he lives in a small airport hangar defending his little slice of life along with a cantankerous often scary partner named bagley as well as his best friend and dog a deep sadness permeates hig's inner thoughts but he also finds some contentment while scouting the countryside from the sky as well as fishing and hunting the land with his faithful canine companion a chance transmission received from a city past the point of no return the point at which there would not be enough fuel to fly home sticks with hig and after thinking and waiting and killing in defense for 3 years events bring hig to set out and explore what results is...well read it for yourself the prose has a unique beat of its own poetic even with a hint of hemingway thrown in there are so many post apocalyptic stories and novels out there it's hard to find an original way to tell the story of humanity's continued survival anymore but heller brings an optimism to a theme that is often quite the opposite

raw_text.351: the third in my recent stint into dystopian futures the dog stars features a likable protagonist hig paired with a killing machine survivalist holed up in a small colorado airport eight short miles from the front range between offing small raiding parties among the point something percent who survived a pandemic flu that crashed society hig flies his antique cessna around their perimeter seeking some higher purpose than home security his wanderlust and unarticulated search for humanity boil over after a tragic ending sending him flying off past the point of no return for one flight's fuel supply hig finds restoration destruction love and redemption along the way the story telling kept my steady interest but the choppy writing style annoyed me many times the character development seemed more advanced and gun violence more horrific than world made by hand by kunstler and i loved hig's mountain sojourns when danger was set aside to fish for carp which replaced the trout that died off in the warming of the streams recreating as his partner derisively calls it instead of simply hunting to restock the venison jerky supply the dog stars lacks the bleak compelling poetic drive of the road by cormac mccarthy but offers a kernel of hope that woman the healer and man the protector can perpetuate the species with honor and dignity at least in small pockets of community in the post apocalyptic landscape

raw_text.355: the dog stars by peter heller knopf 336 pages $24 95 tthe end of the world as we know it does not necessarily mean the end in the stand stephen king unleashed a flu epidemic captain tripps onto mankind killing billions some possessed a natural immunity to the disease these survivors were central in the fight between good and evil in the end las vegas and the darkman were obliterated but life went on tcormac mccarthy also wrote about the end of time in his bleak and powerful novel the road an unnamed father and son journeyed through a post apocalyptic utterly unrecognizable landscape mccarthy used nuclear war instead of a disease his characters struggled against an angry earth and even angrier survivors who were hell bent on making a new world as they saw fit tyet in both these ravaged and savage landscapes pockets of humanity still existed hope did not die king and mccarthy now pass the torch to a new novelist i say he is worthy of the comparison his name is peter heller and his transcendent beautifully lyrical debut is called the dog stars tnine years before the dog stars begins a flu epidemic wiped out most of the world's population think something like this is just fiction look up the 1918 spanish flu and i guarantee you will get chills in heller's story a superbug mutated and combined with bird flu the first cases of the africanized bird flue appeared in london in all likelihood though the virus originated at a national weapons lab not long after the flu had spread everywhere chaos erupted if flu were not enough another catastrophe got added to the mix a blood disease similar to hiv wreaked havoc on those who survived the flu tyou can imagine the kind of world left behind it's a kill or be killed existence something heller's protagonist hig knows all too well as heller writes old rules are done hig went the way of the woodpecker gone with the glaciers and the government new world now new world new rules never ever negotiate thig is an old man at forty who lost his wife and their unborn child to the flu hig's narrative is unconventional as heller uses flashbacks and sometimes strange streams of consciousness to tell us his story after the flu struck encephalitis felled hig two straight weeks of fever three days 104 to 105 hig explains i know it cooked my brains there is no pattern to hig's thoughts they are often jumbled and mish mashed often without segue from one thought to the next he begins many of his sentences with and or so and most of his thoughts are fragments what hig has lived through and what he has lost speak to us from the page heller uses a very powerful device and hig just would not be hig without it tafter living through the end we would try to make a home in a place of familiarity and safety that is exactly what hig does he makes his home at a small abandoned airport where he sleeps under the stars with his faithful old dog jasper he shares the airport with bangley his neighbor and good ole boy who often saves hig's bacon bangley needs hig because hig pilots an eighty year old 1956 do the math and the year is about 2036 cessna that he nicknames the beast hig and jasper patrol the airport's perimeter which means hig can see who or what is coming before the who or what gets there most of the time tin the novel's most violent episode nine people stalk hig as he returns from a hunt bangley warns him from his spot on a tower and coaches hig on what to do remember this is a kill or be killed world a firefight ensues one of the stalkers is a young boy who hig kills killing may come easy for bangley but it is hard for hig he is losing hope especially as he sees the blood disease slowly kill the mennonite families who live close to the airport and who he furnishes some supplies thig knows he has to leave the airport and bangley to restore his faith a few years ago he heard a voice over the radio while flying it was a woman's voice who referenced the grand junction airport hig is determined to go there and to find out what is out there if anything heller shows that sometimes one must take a leap of faith sometimes one has to venture out into the unknown tbecause hig flies a plane readers are given a birds' eye view of what is below climate change has made our world almost unrecognizable and alien few fish exist droughts are common animals such as bears cows and elk are rare birds are almost extinct the tiger left the elephant the apes the baboon the cheetah the tinmouse the frigate bird the pelican gray the whale gray the collared dove sad but didn't cry until the last trout swam upriver looking for maybe cooler water tno wonder hig thinks of dinosaurs i thought of a painting i had seen at the natural history museum in denver a bunch of mixed dinosaurs i remember triceratops fleeing across a sparse plain pursued by fire and volcanoes erupting in the background i wonder if they could run as fast as a mama grizzly or a deer tholding on to memories can go far in keeping a person alive hig is testament to this belief yet he must let go of the past in order to embrace his future in a world devastated by violence flu and climate change sometimes a person has to take certain liberties especially if he no longer remembers the names of constellations sometimes like hig we must make it up as we go along in a time when there are no rules hig has to decide what his rules are only then can he restore his lost hope the dog stars reminds us that even when mankind has been wiped out humanity never truly dies theller contrasts violent brutality charred cities and empty houses with pastoral scenes of nature there is such beauty in this story even when everything is dead or dying heller seems to relay an underlying message for readers take care of the earth before his fictional story becomes an actual reality cold milk fresh apples a touch a faithful dog naming the stars going fishing a bird call raw_text.387: the world was rocked by a flu epidemic and a subsequent blood disease that killed a significant portion of the population and even mother nature has been affected--winters are getting shorter and shorter temperatures are getting hotter wildlife has died in many places and droughts are coming hig survived the flu although his wife didn't he and his trusty dog jasper live in an abandoned airport in colorado along with a cranky well armed misanthrope named bangley hig and bangley have a marriage of sorts--hig hunts and fishes and cooks and plants while bangley berates hig for his lack of strategic thinking as he keeps hig protected from roaming survivors who wander into their compound with nefarious purposes on their minds hig and jasper fly the beast a 1956 cessna both to monitor the perimeter and simply to escape the reality of losing everything and everyone you love one day hig decides to go in search of the voice he heard briefly on the plane's radio three years before to see if there are others out there he flies beyond the point where he has enough fuel for the return trip home but he does encounter people he never thought he would and comes face to face with emotions he has hidden deep inside of him this is a book that wonders how do you keep hope alive when everything around you has been destroyed or will die how do you keep on living when you know there may be an all too finite end in hig peter heller has created a complex resolute character lonely and sad hopeful and grateful who really doesn't know what to do beyond putting one foot in front raw_text.402: end of the world stories in both literature and film interest me from killer tides to killer flus i've been drawn to this sub genre since middle school like the stand the dog stars at its core is about rebuilding a community in this case the community has just three members besides his faithful dog the narrator spends much of the story with a survivalist who is as talented with a firearm as the protagonist is with a plane unlike most of the stories i'm drawn to this novel is considered literary fiction it was quite well reviewed and i sought it out the simplest explanation of the difference between genre and lit fiction is that the first concerns ordinary people in extraordinary circumstances while the second describes extraordinary people in ordinary circumstances while the description is quite simplistic and open to argument it would seem to fall apart here after all what circumstance could be more extraordinary than the near total destruction of the human race sadly the story hews closely to this description for much of the book the protagonist's journey is one through the most pedestrian and quite frankly boring circumstances worse the death of his dog was so sad i had a tough time returning to this book only in the final third did it redeem itself and just barely at that i sometimes feel that most mfa grads are writing for other mfa grads despite contributing to numerous outdoor magazines i suspect that with this novel heller is reaching out to his familiars

raw_text.406: a post apocalyptic tale though not really sci fi told through the eyes of hig a cessna pilot and an avid outdoorsman--fly fishing mainly but some hunting too who with his dog jasper as co pilot buzzes around a small portion of what would have been colorado nine years previously anything further back than nine years is referred to simply as before just trying to figure out how to be under the new rules situation not utterly bleak as some post apoc tends to be but more introspective with several moments that can be considered truly uplifting some comparisons are bound to be made to cormac mccarthy especially the road if only because of heller's sparse prose which can be long on sentence fragments and shy on punctuation but unlike mccarthy--who just writes like that all the time--heller's prose in this book seems to be a side effect of attempting to portray the running monologue going on in hig's brain a brain that may or may not have been just a tad overheated from a fever sustained while surviving the virus that brought civilization to its knees before i realize a mccarthy comparison can just as easily be considered a reproach as it could a ringing endorsement but i had to be honest there is some similarity here i'm a fan of mccarthy myself but i wanted to make sure that readers--who might not be mccarthy fans--don't simply write this book off because of the stylistic similarities it's not mccarthy and it's not the road i think the book would be especially appealing to outdoorsy--majesty of nature--types as i said heart rending and uplifting some really cool yeah i can dig that passages there's some language and character behavior that i'm sure some might consider foul but it's not rampant

raw_text.409: i seldom re read fiction but i suspect i will return to this some day this novel rocks i learned of the dog stars through an npr interview with the author heller said that he started it with one sentence--"i keep the beast running i keep the 100 low lead on tap i forsee attacks"--and he went from there unaware of where the story would take him i tried this once with disastrous literary consequences and a character pointlessly stranded in paraguay honestly i'm envious of just how well heller explores his story while writing i felt--and reveled in--his discovery of the character and journey with each page and this winding journey is so wickedly primal it's amazing the lead character walks fully upright it's a story about pushing beyond mere survival it's the urge to get off the desert island retold in a dystopian world only there is no true escape--life for the isolated protagonist has changed for good and we ache from deep within ourselves with his every urge to push beyond we understand the risks he takes after a decade of aging and not much else we feel the weight of the battles he faces persisting means violating the moral fabric of the pre apocalyptic world in which he was raised we want him to find meaning to find something and finding that something is a hell of a ride for everybody it seems--the character the reader and the author on the nit picky side heller uses a fragmented style of writing throughout some sentences are just weird for no--reason i suppose it's journal esque and this sometimes works but i feel like he defies conventional punctuation for the sake of creating a voice rather than having a voice that is somehow encumbered by it this took me a while to get used to but when i did it was fine at worst it leads to the occasional lack of clarity and need to re read which isn't a horrible punishment for any portion of this novel

raw_text.440: the dog stars came recommended to me by several apocalyptic story loving friends and after having it on my wishlist for more than a year i thought it was time i read it for myself at times it feels like the dog stars is trying to be too clever it's certainly haunting and written in a unique way but at times i felt so removed from what was actually happening it was difficult to pull myself back into the story the sentences are written in short bursts and the dialogue doesn't have quotation marks which made it difficult for me to discern at times exactly who was speaking there is a reason given why hig speaks in such short sentences and at times it does make the story more haunting but it also took quite a while for me to get used to the characters are fairly engaging but i found it difficult at times to understand and rationalise hig's motivation for what he was doing and there is a fair whack of descriptions and dialogue about fishing and flying although they were both presented in simplistic yet interesting ways normally when a book has characters that have interests that are really far removed from my own i find it difficult to care but there was no skimming over lengthy descriptions because they are actually in short bursts so there is a positive to the short sentences his neighbour was a bit of an enigma it was hard to understand his motivation as hig didn't really go into any great depth as to how they came together other than running through the basics and i would have liked to know more about him but their relationship dynamic was certainly interesting and really made me think about how people that can be so different can work together in extreme circumstances as to the plot it's pretty much what it says on the tin hig has freedom because of his plane and he uses that to his advantage to scout the surrounding area and to go on his journey to find the other pilot that he hears but although it doesn't move with a breakneck pace it was interesting enough to keep me engaged and reading the dog stars is a book i'm glad to have read but for me it wasn't anything very unique other than the interests of the main character and the style took a bit of getting used to but by the end i had come to appreciate the way that heller had written it it's not the best post apocalyptic book i've ever read but it kept my attention and gave me some interesting food for thought

raw_text.487: the dog stars is peter heller's debut novel which was promoted on amazon as their book of the month in august of 2012 and it gathered rave reviews from the critics and readers alike that's exactly what got me into reading mr penumbra's 24 hour bookstore which i didn't think was all that good but this one appealed to my tastes i enjoy post apocalyptic fiction and thought that it could be a new and interesting addition to the genre which is now mostly populated by novels for young adults since it was described as poetic thoughtful transformative and a rare combination of the literary and highly readable i took the bait and dove right in the story takes place 9 years after an epidemic of super flu wiped out 99 7% of the population it's narrated by hig who lives in colorado with his dog jasper and a fellow survivor bangley mostly hig patrols the area in his old cessna to look for possible hostile intruders why there are always hostile intruders can't people just cooperate to ensure their survival in his free time he makes up names of constellations hence the title and tries to appease bangley who is prone to violence and whom hig doesn't completely trust the novel is narrated by hig and mostly written in stacatto sentences and parapgraphs without quotation marks for dialogue such broken sentence structure serves to reflect hig's thought process as a sentence will often end in the middle without completion and another will begin or not i found it neither original nor poetic and felt that the writing tried to hide the lack of originality of the novel there's little here that has not already been done elsewhere and better it's essentially dystopian fiction 101 with all the familiar tropes i did not find the characters and their interactions interesting and the events leading to the ending were organized a bit too neatly for my taste the ending itself i thought was inconsequential and out of the left field it certainly did not cement the novel in my memory the dog stars is the author's debut and reads like a short story or a novella stretched into a novel while there are parts of it which i enjoyed i doubt i'll think of it in a year or two and doubt that it'll enter the dystopian canon the first novel i've read this year was in the country of last things by paul auster despite being shorter auster's work packs a whole lot more detail and punch than heller's debut i would recommend it to all curious readers and advise to skip this one

raw_text.498: i sought this book out based on lindsay's review it did not disappoint hig is a survivor of an illness that has wiped out most of humanity those who have survived are those who are willing to kill to protect any land or resources they have claimed as their own hig naturally lacks the killer instinct but has partnered with bangley who never hesitates to kill intruders and who coaches hig to bring out the instinct for self preservation hig is a pilot and routinely flies his small plane to patrol the perimeter of the area he inhabits with bangley the beginning of the book establishes hig's life now nine years after the pandemic hit and covers some of his past life what was most striking to me was the lovability of hig he is intrinsically peaceful and enjoys life outdoors although there are plenty of houses to choose from he chooses to sleep outdoors hig often takes small hunting and fishing trips with his beloved dog when he needs space from bangley despite the end of the world as he knew it and the loss of his wife hig is basically happy with solitude wilderness his dog and his odd and ultimately endearing friendship with bangley then suddenly a change occurs and pushes hig to explore and find out who else is out there the rest of the book covers hig's trip and its results as lindsay mentioned the book is both poetic and action packed and one of heller's strokes of genius is knowing how to intersperse and pace these two elements in the end it seems as though the book and the story it is telling could have kept going but it also seemed that it ended at the right place this isn't the whole story of hig or the whole story of the world after the pandemic rather it is the story of one part of hig's life in this new world and it's a true pleasure to read

raw_text.500: winner of the 2013 ala list of notable fiction books the dog stars takes us to a post flu pandemic world where a large portion of the population is gone hig and his dog jasper have survived and live at a small airport with one fellow ex military survivor the story starts off slow as we watch hig's day to day existence with small doses of flashbacks to before mixed in things change when hig hears a radio transmission and sets off in his plane in search of other survivors fast paced easy to read bittersweet the dog stars in a nice change to the bleakness of the post apocalyptic world of cormac mccarthy's the road if you are a fan of the genre the dog stars may easily become one of your favorites if you are new to the genre the dog stars is a good start

raw_text.503: there have been some beautifully written and truly upsetting end of the world books recently--the age of miracles and zone one come to mind--but peter heller's the dog stars has put a fresh twist on the genre in this quiet meditative novel hig the main character has lost his wife and everyone in his family due to a flu epidemic that has killed most of the population of the united states he now lives with his dog and a survivalist neighbor on an abandoned airstrip that's regularly attacked by roving bands of very scary violent scavengers despite the grimness of his life hig manages to see the beauty in his surroundings and it's his voice that keeps you entranced with vivid details like the smell of running water of cold stone of fir and spruce like the sachets my mother used to keep in the sock drawer there is still one loss that hig has to bear and the grief over this sends him flying in his single prop plane into the wilderness without enough gas to return brilliantly this isn't the end of the story because it's the people he meets when he least expects to who change everything proving a truth we know from our everyday nonfictional lives even when it seems like all the humans in the world are only out for themselves there are always those few who prove you absolutely wrong--in the most surprising of ways read more http www oprah com blogs index html

raw_text.518: this book is incredible in so many ways a rare gem that will make your heart pound like a thriller and make your hair stand on end from the prose also rare in the fact that it's written in present tense yet flows effortlessly though i'm a fan of the present tense it has a number of limitations one of which being that it feels unfamiliar since most people are used to reading in the past tense but i hardly noticed it wasn't in past tense i got about fifty pages in before i realized that's how perfect and necessary it is and actually this book made me rethink the way i write in first person hig's narration is fractured often in incomplete sentences and of course it is that's how people really talk even to themselves especially to themselves especially in a world as lonely as this and the way he left certain things unsaid genius really said out loud they're cliches unsaid they're landmines his emotional revelations really it's what the narrator doesn't say that's important the blank spaces we the readers fill in with our own universal experience utterly brilliant

raw_text.520: most post apocalypse novels use a government or quasi government as a foil for the protagonist to work against while promoting a set of values which will reestablish community and civilization this novel imagines a survivalist world that promotes requires values which are not conducive to community building the protagonist does stray a bit toward some compassion and relationship seeking but he kills as readily as his arch survivalist partner while this novel probes various ethical issues ultimately it settles for a set of values that is unlikely to promote the survival of civilization and it ends with a whimper not a bang the discussion at my book club bumped my rating of this book from 2 stars to 2 1 2 stars and i have generously rounded up to the 3 stars

raw_text.522: comparisons to the road are inevitable let's face it that book really opened a big door for literary emotional respectable apocalyptic fiction and i love it dearly so much so that i think it's really hard for me to read a lot of apocalyptic stories they just don't measure up i know this isn't the opinion of the entire world but it's how i felt when i read it after re reading it and after then listening to the audiobook so maybe a different comparison is in order the writer james galvin author of the meadow and some pretty great poems also wrote a lesser known novel called fencing the sky the plot is pretty spare basically a guy kills another guy in a moment of anger regrets it but makes the decision to run away on horseback it's an interesting book it comes to a slow winding conclusion that you start dreading from the very beginning it's a sort of thriller just at a slow trot instead of a gallop one time i got to hear galvin speak and he said he came up with the plot points as an excuse to keep things moving along while he described the flowers and the trees because that's what he really wanted to do that was the book he wanted to write the dog stars has a bit of a similar feel there's an apocalyptic element here no doubt but at the same time i think the author wanted to write about the colorado outdoors love and loss the apocalyptic element seemed like a good way to distill those ideas down to their essences there are great moments in this book you do care about the characters to bring back to a comparison to the road this one would be a great read for someone that maybe felt the road was too intense too dark too hopeless this book does have moments of levity and there are glimmers of hope though the human population has been decimated by disease the natural world is beginning to return to its natural way and these portraits of nature and the small moments the narrator enjoys are a relief if i had to sum it up in one sentence it's the road for people who are too kindhearted for the road which is not such a bad thing
raw_text.523: hig somehow survived the flu pandemic that killed everyone he knows now his wife is gone his friends are dead and he lives in the hangar of a small abandoned airport with his dog jasper but when a random transmission beams through the radio of his 1956 cessna the voice ignites a hope deep inside him that a better life exists outside their tightly controlled perimeter risking everything he flies past his point of no return and follows its static broken trail only to find something that is both better and worse than anything he could ever hope for i bought this book because one of my friends recommended it now i can't even remember which friend it was but if i could i'd thank them the book is written in first person sometimes like a diary and sometimes like hig is talking to us either way it's a style of writing that i enjoy very much the story kept me transfixed throughout and i could barely put it down wondering what was going to happen next it felt real like this is exactly how things would be if a flu pandemic wiped out most of the population i have no qualms about highly recommending this book it's one of the best books i've read in a while

raw_text.530: that the author can describe a future of such horror while still write with overwhelming beauty about the landscape of nature and the soul this is one of the most incredible books i have ever read i can't quit thinking about all that he has said what options we choose politically and personally without accepting the consequences how we act when we believe we have all the time in the world how when we lose everything there is still always more to lose our petty values and vapid goals heller's descriptions of nature the planet that was and the pieces that are still there are among the most beautiful and sensory in contemporary literature so evocative and personal it immediately transported me back to my childhood summers on the north shore of lake superior how one can love a place almost physically and become familiar with all its details so that the loss of it brings grief so too the intense connection with his dog to experience a rare communication that is so unlike having a dog but is instead like being with a dog in an extended conversation and blurred boundaries of where the dog ends and you begin heller does this incomparably well and the sure certainty of the story's turns only increase the emotion that go with jasper at its essence this book may be most about the conflict between preserving one's personal humanity or surviving and that it is often a choice between the two but i wish that the takeaway will be about taking responsibility for our decisions now so that the impacts will not be so violent and global
