raw_text.532: this book was really very good one of the reasons that i enjoy post apocalyptic books is the exploration of the survivors emotions and this book was definately a journey through the mind and heart of hig last man standing i've noticed that some readers disliked the format the book reads as if we are reading hig's mind it actually reminded me of the way i write in my diary it was absolutely appropriate hig is left with only one other person to converse with and his endless thoughts the author did an excellent job of relaying hig's thoughts and emotions while also presenting dialogue in a way that was seemless i also enjoyed the premise most books of this genre fall into the everyone died of the flu or some asshole dropped the nuclear bomb category the dog stars begins with the former idea and heller does a good job of presenting his own take on this calamity in a way that explains the absence of almost everyone the death toll far exceeds most books of this kind while allowing for the pitiful existance of those who have survived only to suffer from a debilitating blood disease with these wretched survivors who are also contagious and hig being one of very few healthy humans it has a little bit of an i am legend vibe the other element i enjoyed was the author's exploration of what becomes of those who are given the opportunity of what is essentially the ultimate freedom there are the few like hig who are simply trying to subsist and then there are far more who exist as homicidal maniacs i love the extreme duality very like the stand definately a good read not quite up there with some of the others of this genre but still a very time

raw_text.554: hig lives on an abandoned airstrip he flies a 1956 cesna with his dog jasper as co pilot his only friend and neighbor is bangley a tough no nonsense survivalist after a flu pandemic wiped out most of civilization nine years earlier all these two men have is each other protecting "one's own" is all they have left and this pair have created a military compound to keep out intruders bands of armed survivors who roam the land in search of food and fuel this is a stark haunting tale told in spare rugged prose hig is a terrific first person narrator thoughtful and compassionate the setting northern colorado is breath taking with it's sweeping valleys and vistas it becomes integral to the story some readers have compared this to the road and i see some similarities but where the mccarthy book is relentlessly bleak the heller novel offers glimmers of hope many of us are getting burned out on dystopian literature but do not let this one get away it's an absolute gem
raw_text.555: why are we all so fascinated by the end i've lost track of how many apocalyptic and post apocalyptic novels i've read and they haven't gotten old yet but some are fresher than others and such was the case with non fiction writer peter heller's debut novel the dog stars the first person narrator of the tale is hig on the opening page he's lamenting the loss of trout all of them there's a long list of other creatures that are gone but it's not immediately apparent what the cause of this dire change in circumstances is but all will be revealed in time and in the choppy and effective prose symptomatic of a man who has little need to communicate and no longer thinks in complete sentences readers will learn about hig's life at a small colorado airport with only his dog and a sociopathic neighbor for company it's a symbiotic relationship that the three have set up and much of their survival is owed to the 1956 cessna 182 that hig uses to patrol the surrounding area daily spotting other people is rare and it's always dangerous hig and his companions are getting by--which is more than most can say he struggles with the conflict of staying in relative safety versus looking for something better weller sets up the scenario above but this compelling novel is entirely character driven it's an intimate cast and readers will become highly invested in their fates in this harsh world well has done a thorough job of world building his apocalypse a lot of the tropes feel familiar but the details--such as the currency of coke--all feel completely organic this debut is as well written as it is well plotted and readers will be turning pages to see if there is any hope for happy endings anymore

raw_text.588: hig's world is a lonely one after the flu that killed his wife went on to take the lives of 99 9% of america he lives with his dog in an abandoned airport his only neighbour is bangley a man with a passion for firearms and no qualm about killing they form an unlikely alliance hig with his plane for surveillance and bangley with his guns if i had read any reviews of the dog stars in advance i probably would have run away from this book the speech is without speech marks and mostly unattributed the prose borders on poetry in places with short incomplete sentences written by a specialist adventure writer one character loves his fishing and his plane the other is a gun toting all american male their world is pretty bleak and their existence consists of killing people that come too close and making sure they have food to eat yet beyond all that appeared a book i fell in love with the fractured prose suits their world when living is isolation is there need for formal grammar it also mimics the train of thought of someone by themselves every so often blurring into speech when hig isn't even aware that he is talking out loud so even the lack of speech marks work for me and usually i find this difficult the characters of hig and bangley are also joined by jasper the dog and it is the relationship between man and dog that starts pulling at the heart strings jasper is truly man's best friend in this case the fact that bangley is such an inaccessible character to start with makes it all the more touching when the emotion slips through that in extreme situations little things like compatibility don't matter and new family bonds are forged a need for human connections overrides everything else i found it touching and moving throughout you just have to give the style a little time to settle in i even started to get interested in the plane and the crucial part it plays in the story without it they would have been truly isolated instead it gives them freedom to forage further and to keep their land safe the violence in the world may be a pessimistic outlook but it is also probably a realistic one it also gives the edge of suspense and keeps the pace up where otherwise it might drag after all the moment when i thought the book may be starting to flag was one of the few times that hig wasn't in danger of being shot at there are small passages about the flu and the blood disease that followed hig befriends a community of mennonites with the blood disease in a nearby property reached by plane but never gets close there is a not too subtle comparison between misconceptions about hiv and this new disease that was born out of the flu but the story isn't really about the apocalypse it's about day to day survival in the world that remains part of that survival is the struggle to be social when in competition when it's easy to become animals it's love that keeps humanity alive

raw_text.594: there's a word i consider more damning then any faint praise and that's the word 'potential' it to me implies a laziness even a selfishness on the part of the subject that they were incapable or even just unwilling to utilize their full talents on a project i hate this word because it's the prime weapon of those who wish to bridge their lack of understanding with a single word or phrase 'try harder' or any of its variants are some other gems that having been said it pains me more than a little to say that peter heller's novel the dog stars is packed with substantial potential but unfortunately only taps into a vague and small amount of it though not from oddly enough lack of skill or even trying but just from it would seem authorial error of emphasis the story is fairly basic and essentially a post apocalyptic long form reaffirmation of humanity and the essential goodness of person to person connection and however it's structured and flawed the idea of 'family' is inherently good protagonist hig flies a plane and partnered with gun and survivalist nut bangley whom he acts as scout for ekes out an existence in an armored airport it's a stoic existence that calls to mind the male yearnings and machismo tinged thoughts of hemingway told in a distinctly faulknerian voice in a surprisingly faulknerian setting it's post apocalyptic sure but it's also very rural and naturalistic with much emphasis placed on at least at first the relationship between man and nature and even man and animal but the flaws in heller's approach become quickly apparent unlike some of my fellow reviewers who took umbrage with hig's pseudo stream of consciousness dialogue due to reasons of obfuscation calling it tiring unnecessary maybe even trying too hard i took issue with it for a much simpler and more direct reason it's incredibly inconsistent both structurally and tonally what starts out as a benji compson like almost expressionistic style of writing quickly degenerates into a level pablum with occasional tectonic shifts of true beauty and even insight there were several stretches of text where i thought 'terrence malick could make an absolutely gorgeous film out of this' and i still feel that though malick would have to take moderate to extreme liberties as he did with the thin red line another flaw perhaps the most glaring is one that runs parallel to the tonal inconsistency and for a post armageddon text this one is surprising it's schmaltzy extremely so whereas mccarthy's the road and even walker's the age of miracles were brutal in their depictions of humanity struggling nobly or savagely in it's death throes heller is much more restrained and subdued as regards the brutality of his setting and even positively hopeful as regards humanity's inherent worth and capacity for grace under the weight of an indifferent and even cruel universe which leads to the next problem of the book whatever case heller is trying to make with his novel is undermined by his well lack of a full bodied depiction for a book so rife with prosaic and even poetic beauty even including allusions to great works of ancient and more recent works of the world canon this is a remarkably hollow feeling story while we're told again and again about the catastrophically small amount of survivors on earth the repeated references to humanity as a whole to civilization rocked to its foundations leaves the reader yearning for some missives from the edge it's described but never elaborated on the state of the rest of the world outside of the characters and their settings but aside from one bizarre yet more or less satisfying anomaly of an ending we're left wanting more in short hemingway could sometimes talk his way around and around a story successfully peter heller is i'm sorry to say not quite so successful it's not a wonderful book but curiously there are portions of wonder and authorial aplomb scattered here and there surprising in their veracity and even heavy hearted whimsy while not a staggering work it will stay with you long enough to move you maybe even make you feel for the blighted but hopeful world depicted definitely worth a look and consideration

raw_text.608: i really loved this dystopian story of the near future heller really struck a note with his somewhat stripped down prose giving us a story of hope and humanity amidst a world that has become ugly and brutish this story has been told before many times the struggle to survive after here a flu pandemic followed by a blood disorder that has killed most of the population there are pockets of survivors here and there all struggling to hold on to their little piece of life tthe story is based around hig the main character who flies a cessna on recon missions around the area where he lives on an isolated airfield with one other person between the two of them they have been able to combine their skills and resources to survive but hig is a dreamer and feels overwhelmed by all the violence and brutality that he is forced to witness and participate in he struggles to find meaning and hold on to his sense of humanity tafter a traumatic experience hig sets off alone in his plane ostensibly in search of a voice he heard on the airways three years earlier but on a deeper level he's looking for something more hope and a re connection with humanity tthe book has been compared to mccarthy's the road but its really quite different there's a sense of hope and a belief in the human condition of making the best of a bad situation i found it to be more closely related to theroux's far north or atwood's oryx and crake all in all one of the best books i've read this year i'm giving it 5 stars

raw_text.612: i like to read apocalyptic fiction and this book bore more than a small passing to cormac mccarthy's the road but overall though portions of it were compelling and emotional i was underwhelmed i also thought the book in general ran long for the amount of events that took place i think it could have been cut mainly in the description area by at least a quarter to no noticeable effect the main conceit of 'the road' that made me believe in its hellish apocalypse was the fact that the skies were dark that nothing would ever grow again that we were reading about the last inhabitants of a dying world that could not be saved therefore any and all savagery or insanity or poetry or long ruminations made perfect sense nothing these characters did or did not do would make any real difference in the final game however 'the dog stars' portrays a world nine years after a global pandemic in which the main body of infrastructure is not wiped completely off the map and the skies are clear the world is changing global warming is showing an impact some species are gone and yet life still remains in some form with the suggestion it will continue to go on so it felt absurd to me that nearly every person encountered in this book was a trigger happy psycho who roamed around in tiny bands and only wanted to shoot people for their stuff or just 'cause at the beginning or in the immediate aftermath of global meltdown this makes sense but nine years later nobody's trying to rebuild anything i would have assumed that all the psychos would have at least banded together into some loose sort of army of rampaging psychos or that there would be at least one or two outposts of people who didn't feel like shooting random people on sight i didn't think i was that optimistic about human nature but if it had been nine years since i last saw a plane in the sky my first impulse would not be to immediately shoot it down and kill the pilot without even trying to ask for information i'm not sure if everyone can pull off the cormac mccarthy 'no quotations around your dialogue' choice either especially when you've got multiple conversations happening it stops feeling like a stylistic choice for dramatic reasons and starts feeling like a stylistic choice to make a book that sounds like 'the road' in that same vein while i liked the narrator's somewhat disjointed confused narration and the explanation of its origins in his sickness i felt at times he was remarkably eloquent and intellectual and his wavering mental state seemed more an extremely convenient plot device than an honest limitation the half hearted mention of something like cannibalism making jerky for the dog out of people seemed unnecessary and almost silly more like ticking a box off the 'signs of the apocalypse' checklist than a necessary detail i also thought the last pair of threats the protagonist had to fight off were cartoonish and ridiculous and undermined a lot of the serious tone of the novel

raw_text.650: a global flu pandemic has decimated the human population and if that's not bad enough the worst effects of global warming are taking their toll the dog stars is set in colorado nine years after the flu pandemic hig a pilot has made a life for himself at a remote airfield and he's coping with his emotional trauma - 'being at the end of all loss' - thanks to the companionship of his dog jasper peter heller is an established non fiction adventure travel writer and i hoped for something a bit different from him and sure enough heller's main character in the dog stars is an inspired choice hig is a keen fisherman who observes the changes in the natural world as he makes hunting trips to the mountain forests he flies reconnaissance missions in his 50s cessna to check for any marauding gangs and he witnesses the local landscape now virtually devoid of human life this novel considers how the ecosystem as a whole is struggling in catastrophic times hig has a neighbour at the airfield - gun toting bangley - and together they defend their perimeter and fend off all predators hig is squeamish about killing on sight but bangley lives by his own motto 'never ever negotiate you are negotiating your own death 'i enjoyed the relationship between these two unlikely partners and heller writes wittily to create simultaneously sympathetic and critical pictures of both men unlike bangley hig isn't willing to sit out his life at the airfield so he flies off in search of someone he heard fleetingly on the airwaves three years earlier but i won't say what or who he finds some readers have likened the dog stars to cormac mccarthy's the road but that's a nonsense comparison just to put the record straight the road is indeed a post apocalyptic novel but all vegetation and animal life is eradicated in that particular version of hell on earth in heller's novel the natural world is in transition because of global climate change human survivors of the pandemic can still farm the main similarity is that survivors live in fear of other survivors in addition some readers complain about the lack of punctuation but to my mind that's appropriate i mean at the end of world do you really think anyone will care about the inappropriate use of the semi colon hig's interior monologue often takes the form of incomplete sentences and single word fragments it works well reading the dog stars did remind me of chris beckett's dark eden also on the shortlist - their main characters are both in tune with nature and they strive to live 'in the now' here's hig it caught me sometimes that this was okay just this that simple beauty was still bearable barely and that if i lived moment to moment garden to stove to the simple act of flying i could have peace the dog stars is a good read and i felt that peter heller brings much to the table in terms of his broad vocabulary and his ability to engage the reader in the detail of fishing flying and more one disturbing aspect of this novel for me is the prediction that in dire circumstances a group of people can only survive if one their number has an all consuming passion for guns and ballistics but maybe in the us this is taken for granted

raw_text.685: i think how a reader feels about a book has as much to do with the current events and mindset of the reader as it does with the actual book itself i read this book over a weekend while on my 12 14th days of an all green juice fast before sitting myself down before a fire to start reading the book i had just taken a much shorter than anticipated walk in the woods with my dog max max is a 14 year old german shepherd border collie mix and usually there is nothing he loves more than a nice walk in the woods on a sunny january day but not that day he started the walk strong but quickly tired and it was painfully obvious that his hips were hurting him so we turned back early i did not mind ending the walk because the fasting had made me cold and a little light headed it was in this state floaty and little flighty in thoughts from the fasting and concerned about my beloved aging dog that i read this beautiful book of love and grief the style of the prose did not bother me but instead enchanted me because it mimicked my own thought patterns at the time the grief that swept through the book especially as the book progressed became my own grief and at times i cried almost as much as hig would the book have moved me as much under different circumstances maybe not however i have no doubt if i read it again in the future it will move me as much if not more since in my mind this book will always be linked to the beautiful weekend spent with max walking in the woods and resting by the fire just like music becomes a snap shot of our life and transports us back in time this book is my time machine regarding love grief and the majesty of knowing and loving a dog

raw_text.689: though a grammar enthusiast's nightmare it was a stylistic choice based on the narrator's previous life events it reminded me of a cross between curious incident and where the red fern grows also dystopic i loves me some dystopic it's also some of the best written prose i've read in a long while when her mouth found mine i disassembled not exploded like a bomb or anything but came apart a few pieces at a time they floated away went into a kind of orbit a splintering galaxy an extravagant slow motion annihilation the only center was her mouth her hair it was her a reconstitution around the core of her my god so many passages i had to read over and over at its core it's a general story of growth dealing with survival hardship ethics love u0026amp loss it's written from a distinctly male perspective with obvious language sexual references and tendencies toward violence but it's also quite heart warming and sweet i think the dichotomy works well and it makes me recommend the book to anyone who likes er books

raw_text.709: the word to describe this book is quite simply astounding yes the dog stars is a post apocalyptic piece of literature yes it includes the horrors that humans are capable of yes it includes some edge of your seat moments but what this novel is really about is grief and loss while a ravaged world is the backdrop grief and loss are concepts we are all aware of if not intimately familiar with but what heller asks is how do you grieve when most of the world's population is already gone how do you face loss when it is just one soul as opposed to many how do you find connection how do you learn to trust how do you exist with another being especially if you do not share a language what does it mean to love heller's prose is incredibly affecting i found myself catching my breath while reading so moved by heller's lyricism asked out of context these are questions that we ponder and discuss and debate in our lives today would their magnitude grow if everyone on earth save a handful were dust these are the issues protagonist hig grapples with in the dog stars i can't come close to doing heller's work justice and i won't even try i will say that this is easily one of the best books i read in 2013 and is definitely an addition to my list of overall favorite reads

raw_text.749: i surprisingly different take on the post apocalyptic world our main character hig is one of the rare survivors of a pandemic he lives out of a strategically secured small airport with an unlikely and challenging partner bangley yes survival is day to day and includes all the typical end of the world threats but hig is a reminder that despite the dangers and horrors there are still things we seek as humans throughout the book he searches for more human connections encountering the good and the bad his perspective is quite naturalist and it is easy to walk through the colorado mountains with him on one of his treks set in the denver and surrounding area this post apocalyptic world was eerily familiar an easy book to recommend

raw_text.751: this is a post apocalyptic tale of physical and spiritual survival that leaves the reader wondering how long would most of us survive if everything we know suddenly disappeared what would it take to stay alive in a world with no rules in the dog stars the familiar has disappeared but there are just enough references to our world walmart 9 11 david foster wallace mcmansions pulp fiction to force us to see how easily we might be thrust into the outer darkness there is poetry in the writing and despite the need for black and white personalities the characters are carefully and subtly drawn each with his and her own scars weaknesses and moments of grace i have no idea if mr heller would appreciate the comparisons but his craftsmanship and attention to detail evoke other iowa writers workshop alumni such as marilynne robinson and paul harding his love of the west evokes wallace stegner this is a fine tale and a wonderful written book

raw_text.759: 3 5 out of 5 since there is no half stars i went for 3 as i felt it was closer to a 3 than a 4 reason behind this is that you need to weigh up the level to which you will recommend a book to a friend and i felt more that i would tell people about the book in conversation but would not tell them to put it on their must read list first off the criticisms from other readers about the writing style are spot on it is quite hard to read at times which does not really make sense as like others have said before me the lead character talks about his love for poetry and that he should have been an english teacher aside from this the book is a decent read not really the kind that you can pick up and read 10 pages at a time though i felt the characters were the best thing about this book you did get a good sense of who the characters were and what they were about i would likely have rated the book higher if there was more dialog between characters which was few and far between

raw_text.781: this might be a somewhat unexpected title to appear as one of my reviews as its connection to the speculative is tenuous at best - it's set in a post apocalyptic america - and it's not historical or crime fiction either in fact i think this falls firmly in the mainstream fiction category nevertheless when a review copy for this title came in the post i was intrigued and added it to my tbr pile meaning to get to it sooner rather than later of course it did become later rather than sooner but i'm glad i got to it before the end of the year as it was an interesting read i have my share of issues with the story and the writing but in the end i had to keep reading just to discover how it ended what troubled me the most about this book and what will probably be the biggest issue for most readers is the structure and the writing told in a first person narrative voice this is a voice i've never encountered before though it not a stream of consciousness form it isn't far off and at times hig goes off on tangents and reminiscences that make for confusing sequences in addition heller has hig add random but's and and's into his narration which for me where highly annoying most of the time on top of the strange narrative structure the book is also typographically different it uses no quotation marks to indicate speech and when in dialogue it sometimes places alternating lines in one paragraph so that it's hard to distinguish between the speakers there is also a distinct scarcity of comma's and lots of short paragraphs with blank lines in between while all of this makes for a unique reading experience it doesn't necessarily make it a smooth one what bothered me story wise is the fact that some elements of the story seemed illogical i couldn't fathom why in the nine years since the flu there haven't appeared any non combative groups of survivors other than the arguably not so non combative bangley similarly would you really wait nine years to go and explore on the other side of the mountain and look for other survivors heller doesn't really answer these questions in fact he never really posits them which i found rather strange where the dog stars definitely succeeds however is in emotionally engaging the reader it's impossible not to come to care for hig and even his grouchy companion bangley their interactions and grudging friendship are beautifully addressed with surprising flashes of humour hig's deep and abiding love for his dog jasper felt genuine and at one point in the novel had me sniffling aloud when hig finally goes out to look for the voice behind the crackly transmission he heard and he encounters pops and cima we get treated to a soulful exploration of what it means to have to move on after the loss of a spouse how terrifying and enchanting that sensation of falling in love can be and how hard it is to move beyond the memories the dog stars has left me with very mixed feelings i was very much taken with the story and the ultimate message of hope heller presents the reader with but with all my issues with the structure and the writing i can't recommend it whole heartedly in the end i think how you'll like this book is very much dependent on the emotional connection you make with both hig and the narrative for me that connection wasn't sufficient to overlook my objections but if the premise of the story appeals i'd recommend you give it a try as the story might work far better for you than it did for me this book was provided for review by the publisher

raw_text.792: if it's exciting end of the world action you're looking for keep looking if introspection and elegiac commentary is more your style however you're going to probably out this at the top of your favorites list peter heller shares the story of hig a guy living in a world nine years after a pandemic has wiped out over 99% of the population along with his faithful dog jasper and a kick ass crotchy old guy named bangley hig lives near a small airport just north of denver and concentrates on survival eventually hig strikes out on an adventure of sorts in his 1955 4 seater cessna the action is pretty spare but worth the wait and the real beauty of this story lies in heller's ability to imagine this post apocalyptic world so completely i especially enjoyed the way in which he manages to flesh out hig's interior life most of the dialogue consists of hig's own conscious flow of thoughts but it's well done and hig is an appealing protagonist at various points you'll find beauty and horror and a fair amount of bizarre well bizarre to us from the vantage point of the before before behavior it's a challenging piece not for the faint of heart or the world weary this certainly won't for the most part boost your mood or outlook on the human condition i closed the book though feeling pretty satisfied and that's almost impossible to pull off for a post apocalyptic novel kudos to heller for his creation it's near the top of my list in the genre

raw_text.809: the book is presented as the journal of hig a survivor of a pandemic flu virus that killed most of the world's human population the broken language and punctuation would seem to reflect a damaged survivor of a global catastrophe hig flys his 1950s plane from a colorado front range airport where he lives with a ruthless gun fanatic and fights off fellow survivors who raid their base simply surviving isn't enough for hig and he takes off on a search for other survivors the book contains graphic violence as hig battles raiding survivors and feeds his beloved dog on their flesh it also contains intimate details of hig's sexual reawakening with cima a western slope survivor i could have done without some of the details a repeating theme in the book is a warning about the path our society is on the pandemic is hinted to be caused by an accident in a government biowarfare program global warming still stalks the survivors arabs seem to be the only organized world survivors they probably would have been vietnamese 30 years ago our society turns on itself in bloody chaos when they can't stop the plague leaving victims and predatory bands i don't think it has to be that way though hellar mccarthy and others paint it that way a more personal theme is hig's search for humanity and love in an inhuman world while he takes part in ruthless battles with other survivors he also brings supplies to a gentle quarantined mennonite community he loves his dog deeply he feels guilt over the terrible things he's had to do but still holds onto a faint glimmer of hope he takes off on a quixotic journey beyond his plane's point of no return and finds love this is the most important message to me that in spite of all that goes on around us and in us we can still be human and still love ourselves and others

raw_text.847: this is a book that slowly reels you in and then grips you tightly at first there is a lot to pick up about the post apocalyptic condition of the world and the sort of life lived by the narrator hig his narration is simple understated and jumps from topic to topic in a believable stream of consciousness flow the writing style is choppy with minimal punctuation and takes a bit of getting used to the writing is clean and spare the descriptions of nature are beautiful yet hig conveys his heart and emotions without wallowing in introspection the heart of the book looks at what it means to be human many minor characters are just looters hig's partner is a survival at all costs guy who shoots first and asks questions later hig can appreciate the utility of that view but cannot embrace it because he yearns to live in relationship with others in a context of love and acceptance after a couple of tragedies hig heads out risking his survival in the search for other human relationships view spoiler he succeeds in finding not only acceptance but also love when he returns to his base his partner is at the point of death from wounds suffered in an attack hide spoiler the author shows that a survival at all costs attitude may not be the most effective survival tactic four stars seems a little low to me five stars maybe slightly too high i'd give this book 4 5 stars if i could

raw_text.863: my review i received an advanced copy of this book from the publisher i was concerned when reading the back of the book that this was just yet another end of the world story which the market seems so saturated with over the last couple of years but i could not have been more wrong this book is beauty personified in an anything but beautiful world that is left after a disease has killed most of earth's inhabitants and animals the writer was so bold in his vision of the ugly and the good left on the planet what i especially loved was the fact that this book never became too depressing but never rose colored glasses either to me these characters could not have been any truer in their complexity and their ever changing emotions and views i loved the main character hig and even came to love his neighbor the scenery described in certain scenes and the emotions it evoked in hig were heartbreaking and lyrical hopeful and dreadful all at the same time it is a rare talent who would be able to balance these extremes and peter heller is that master don't miss this amazing book

raw_text.877: sure this is post apocalyptic dystopian lit and sure there's a love story but the real arc of this novel follows the relationship between bangley and hig nine years after a flu pandemic sweeps the globe two men have carved out a perimeter in a remote corner of the midwest but when hig decides he needs something more even if it costs his life the men confront questions of love trust and loyalty they had never expected to face again heller's poetry training comes through strong in this novel the paragraphs laid out like stanzas and the imagery heart busting with deeper meaning heller uses planetary devastation to explore grief and love the beauty and solace of the natural world and the necessity of human connection his male characters may all be gun toting killers but they're also the most soft hearted guys i've come across in a long time beautiful choices on every page

raw_text.889: i have long been afraid of what would happen to the world of apocalypic fiction when the mfa's found it this is a good example the novel's premise and arc is fine and fairly ordinary for the sub genre a post apocalyptic survivor has a sidekick who proves invaluable he is equipped with some specialities that will suit him well in this case piloting small airplanes and trout fishing he grieves for much of the novel for his dead wife and the world they had until he finds a new partner to build a new life with the primarly turnoff for me was the emphasis on characterization to my mind tedious levels there are long passages of introspection and navel gazing in a narrative that in the first part of the novel frustratingly jumps back and forth between present recent past and distant past the introspectionis particularly hard to take because the author mixes his writing style with the terseness of a teenager texting and with faulkener run amok there are pages and pages of flying and checking out the cessna that are soon followed by equally florid descriptions of lovemaking the dialogue in the story can best be descrbed as recollected that is it is difficult to tell if the characters actully spoke were thinking or speculating aloud in any event it and the occasionally shifts from first to second person point of view at times made for some headscratching passages there are times when the plot of the story begins to get rolling but it is immediatly subverted by a long description of a trout stream or of the glory of flying it is in these passages that the writer seems to be torn between an homage to hemingway and a 5000 word article for outside magazine about fishing the backcounty in the the rockies
raw_text.890: i'm surprised to see this book compared to the road so much as the tone is quite different despite both books being set in the a post apocalyptic world in the new future the protagonist an amateur pilot who survived a flu epidemic which killed most of the us if not the world lives near an airport with his dog and survivalist neighbor who may be a former marine or navy seal and the two men while not friends have developed a relationship of mutual survival the man spends much of the book reminiscing about life before the flu and yearning to meet other people while i can sympathize with that the survivalist is a gruff man of few words not good companionship for the man who was also an aspiring writer before the epidemic i am not sure how he expects this to happen as he comes in contact now and then with stragglers who attack their compound and are shot and killed by him or the survivalist in order to protect themselves so why wouldn't he expect the same behavior if he were to stumble across someone else's camp or home base in any case the book suffers from lack of punctuation and dialogue it's often hard to tell what is being said vs thought by the man which is a sharp contrast to the flowery descriptions and imagery of the book in contrast to the road where both the dialogue and descriptions were spare allowing your imagination to fill in the gaps

raw_text.893: oscar wilde said when you assume you make an ass out of u and me i'm starting to think though that that's not quite correct we have to assume some things in order to function as a normal person we have to assume gravity will work that our relationships are approximately the same as they were yesterday that things will for the most part stay where we put them and that most of the things we knew to be true yesterday are still true today you start to make an ass out of yourself when you assume things that you have no basis for that a person will behave a certain way because of your own preconceived notions rather than because of evidence based conclusions or when you hold onto your assumptions too tightly like a good scientist you have to hold your hypotheses lightly ready to surrender them for new ones when they're contradicted by your observations i assumed that this book was a fairly standard post apocalyptic survival novel the protagonist is a male called hig who narrates in clipped sentences and thoughts he flies a plane with his dog jackson as a co pilot at that point i had a pretty good picture of the rest of the book action packed heroic lots of glorious fighting that was entirely wrong a science fiction book is usually a book about an idea this book isn't it's all about feelings it's about unexpected situations and tricky ethical quandaries that aren't all laid out in black and white that makes it sound insipid but it's not the clipped no quotes mark style of the prose and dialog have been as carefully crafted as any poem hig has suffered brain damage as a result of surviving the disease that has killed more than 99 percent as far as he knows of humanity he thinks differently now and he's been solitary for so long that thought and speech blend into one another this book is about what it feels like to survive the end of the world it's creative character driven and deeply poetic nothing is as it seems and nothing conforms to the stereotypes of the genre heller an author and a poet has thought long and deeply about his characters the love story when it emerges is far from simple like the characters experiencing it the story is complex and much more realistic for it if you were expecting the typical post apocolyptic survival novel and if you cling to that assumption you will be disappointed if you're open to reading a poetic and not the flowery kind deep thoughtful ambiguous novel then you're going to love it i certainly did it was honest true brutal and beautiful

raw_text.899: the dog stars is a beautiful poetic book written with a hypnotic cadence in a post apocalyptic world hig has taken up residence at eyrie a rich man's airfield at the foot of some mountains where people used to have houses next to their planes but hig's house is only a diversion he sleeps in the open with his dog jasper after the influenza then 'the blood' survival has descended into kill or be killed hig has formed an uneasy alliance with bangley who knows about guns perimeters and merciless killing though hig can never be sure when he will have outlived his usefulness in the battle for survival what he has to offer is his eyes from an ancient cessna with the cessna he can secure their perimeter hig cannot mourn his wife but he can mourn the last trout the earth too has endured an unexplained sickness although the blurb says this is a book about hope i think that it is really a book about humanity as in being humane despite the horrific acts of violence that he commits hig somehow holds on to some of his humanity through his mourning of the trout the elk and the forests when hig's dog dies he sets out from the airport in search of something he dare not even give hope a name at this point in the novel i was concerned it would descend into something too sweet and it almost does for a few pages but then it picks itself up and delves into the complexity of what it is to be human in a gritty and satisfying way i loved this novel

raw_text.902: the dog stars by peter heller takes place in the mid 2030s in the former state of colorado nine years before a pandemic swept across the country wiping out all but a few survivors most of them have survived by brutally eliminating anyone coming close to their territory and supplies there are only four major characters in the story the narrator hig has managed to survive because he still has a flyable plane and can patrol from the air and his partner has an arsenal of weapons and is eager to kill any trespasser when hig flies off following the siren song of a control tower in grand junction he finds a hidden canyon where a father and daughter are surviving by raising livestock and gardening the grim story turns more hopeful with the boy meets girl scenario but impending drought forces the trio to plan a return to hig's "home" this involves first getting to the grand junction airport to refuel the plane and it raises "grim" to a whole new level the focus on violence and mechanical stuff has the makings of a "guy's" novel but it also poses hard questions about the survival of the human spirit and moral compass when a civilized world becomes a chaotic one

of his range flying out of fuel range to follow a disembodied voice belonging to a stranger who may or may not be ill or dead would be madness and hig tries to put the experience out of his mind but raw_text.910: after kook i was interested in checking out heller's fiction the setting is post apocalyptic town in colorado nine years after a pandemic eliminated almost the entire population there are a few human survivors hig the narrator is a pilot who lives in an abandoned community airport with a tactical and weapons specialist named bangley the two have developed a successful partnership for their mutual survival as roving bands of marauders target the airport and the precious resources that hig and bangley have been able to cultivate the book is written in a stream of consciousness from hig's point of view his feelings of loneliness loss regret desire are powerfully rendered yet he still is able to recognize and appreciate beauty in the scorched and scarred places he inhabits like mccarthy's the road we are forced to imagine the end of the world as we know it go out way beyond our comfort zone and wonder what it might be like just to survive and go on living day to day this is a powerful and majestic work
raw_text.911: in one way i found this book very hard to read the post apocalyptic world it describes is so brutal and so bleak it was hard to swallow i really don't believe that human society would descend to an every man for himself kill or be killed mentality rather than working cooperatively to solve problems and share resources however in another way the book was quite easy to read and extremely enjoyable because the narration is told in first person the reader is privy to hig's many and intimate thoughts and reflections and i found them to be profound moving and entertaining at the emotional heart of the story is hig's relationship with his dog and that was quite moving however it is hig's attempts to form meaningful and peaceful relationships with the other humans including his violence loving partner and the peaceful but diseased mennonites and then later the father and daughter are what this book is all about i believe that ultimately hig shows us that the only meaning in life comes from connecting with others in addition there's a strong thread of respect for nature in the book hig's frequent ruminations on the beauty of nature and his love of fishing hiking etc are beautiful and profound i loved the fragmentary nature of the narrative incomplete sentences and almost poetic and stream of consciousness at times which beautifully reflected hig's inner thoughts also i might add i loved the bits of humor that frequently surfaced in the dialogue and in hig's narration in short although the world that is depicted in this book is harsh and brutal the underlying message is one of hope and humanity i ended up loving this book and highly recommend it

raw_text.926: the dog stars is a strange book in the sense that it has absolutely no right to be as good as it is not taking anything away from peter heller the man is an accomplished non fiction writer with countless best sellers it's just the fact that this is his first foray into the fiction realm is somewhat surprising he crafts a well paced interesting and fresh novel that exists in a genre that has been done to death 9 years after the combination of a super flu virus and a deadly blood disease wiped out a good chunk of humanity we're thrust into the lives of hig and bangley two survivors spending their time living in an old abandoned airport they're constantly fortifying their territory with extensive security measures when not wrapped up in that hig often takes to the sky in an old 50s airplane he has dubbed the beast visiting nearby communities and bringing aid to the sick content to just stick to his new home and take out any intruders bangley lets hig go off on these r u0026amp r trips with his dog jasper following an unexpected transmission received approximately 3 years prior hig often considers flying to its source will hig eventually seek out the voice on the other end and if so will the journey be worth it heller's prose was a little difficult to adjust to at first i've only read a few authors that have ditched the ever reliable quotation mark cormac mccarthy and james frey and it never really sits well with me when i'm first diving into a novel it's not that i have a hard time reading it i just prefer when i can clearly separate dialogue in my head his protagonist hig is quite the sympathetic character and heller doesn't really waste a whole lot of time in pulling at your heartstrings when the outbreak happened with the exception of his dog jasper hig lost everything while there are a few scenes of inner dialogue that really drive home just how lonely and depressed this man is it never seems sappy or cliche which is a plus his only friend and hig really wonders at times if they really are friends is pretty much the exact opposite while hig shows empathy for families living outside their compound bangley would sooner kill them off a tough self proclaimed gun nut bangley represents an alternative to hig's peaceful ways a good reason why the duo is still alive after all this time it may have something to do with the fact that i'm currently making my way through firefly but i kept envisioning bangley as portrayed by adam baldwin and hig as nathan fillion both seem to fit the bill nicely but it may have something to do with this scene i really enjoyed this novel while it's not perfect heller shows some promise for a first time novelist i'm interested to see what he has planned next

raw_text.949: a post apocalyptic hobbesian story set in the deep mountains in colorado two men defend themselves against what's left of the world one happy to be the last man the other searching for a connection in this hopeful adventure tale hig is one of the last men on the face of the earth a global flu devastating the population killing his wife and everything he knows the one thing that gives him solace that makes him feel normal is the ability to take his cessna up and go into the mountains with his dog jasper to hunt and fish it has allowed him to freeze time not to heal but to be numb it doesn't help that his partner bangsley is a crazy gun nut who enjoys shooting and killing on site anyone who enters the perimeter one day while flying hig hears a response call from a distant airport awakening his need to connect with others and thaw most of the story is contemplative with hig's inner thoughts taking up much of the story hig has to deal with the death of his wife and other tragedies the outdoors gives him peace and normalcy this aspect is beautiful graceful and cathartic not just for someone mourning the end of the world but just for anyone in mourning it's beautifully captured however some of the problems in the story is the "no holds barred" every man for himself attitude if banglsey shoots anyone on site then what would be the point of trying to make contact with others who will do the same thing maybe i am too naive but it doesn't seem like everyone would just kill each other on site no questions asked it makes the story a little uneven and the plot doesn't seem to fit the healing aspect the outdoors and the love for a dog are the best aspects the first third of the book reminded me of the art of racing in the rain and the book brings that aspect back around in the end

raw_text.976: compelling thought provoking insightful how well do we know ourselves would we devolve into a species without the humanity of civilization if as survivors we were faced with a world where the majority of the population has succumbed to a fatal illness looking at this possibility from the experience of hig and his small circle of fellow humans an imperfect kind of family is revealing in the stark portrayal of the difficulties the cessation of life as we know it could bring i was reluctant at first the pace of the audio book was slower than my previous audio and i had just read the handmaid's tale another post apocalyptic story of human perseverance in the face of profound change i am so very glad i stuck with this book sometimes too close to reality for comfort yet real and intense every action takes on an urgency and possibility for catastrophe and for celebration of the simple nature life represents view spoiler it was difficult to read of the loss of jasper to old age a loyal dog who was truly hig's best friend the passages regarding this loss were powerfully poignant and gut grabbingly realistic the suspense was palpable as we wondered what hig would find as he flew past the point of no return with the clear idea that he simply had to reach out and see what was out there so many human emotions the compulsion for companionship the adventuresome spirit the ability to adapt in a community of others taking on roles to support the group redefining what family means in a timeless way that harkens back to the beginning of the civilization of mankind even without hope or prospects we find hope and prospects hide spoiler
raw_text.977: cross posted to http light of day net 2012 09 book peter heller's the dog stars is one of those perfect books where everything work in harmony the writing is beautiful and lyrical and deft in tone the characters are complex layered and likable and the plot vacillates between nail biting action and thought provoking quieter moments striking a pitch perfect balance between desolation and optimism heller paints a picture of a bleak but beautiful and ultimately hopeful world that makes his vision of a post apocalyptic world stand out from the dozens of other similar books crowding the shelves right now the first thing worth pointing out is that heller's use of language is very unusual traditional grammatical rules go out the window in this new world as hig takes us through his thoughts and conversations with no quotation marks barely any punctuation run on sentences and thoughts that don't complete themselves before jumping onto a new subject it may take a little while to get used to but once you get sucked in it's nearly impossible to dislodge the voice of hig from your head as you read on personally i hear him with a hint of a southern accent hig's days and thoughts are quiet and contemplative befitting of a nearly desolate world wherein survivors have all the time in the world - as long as they stay alive the relationship between hig and his gun crazy neighbor ally bangley at first seems cordial and simply mutually beneficial but reveals itself in one of the best surprises of the book to be tinged with unexpected depth and emotion hig's love for jasper is simply heartbreaking especially when it becomes clear that jasper is not only a great companion but the only thing that hig still has left of the life that he had before the virus took his wife along with most of humanity sure enough as much as he loves his dog hig soon finds himself longing for more human contact the voice he heard over his plane's radio had always remind a symbol of hope for him and what he finds when he goes searching for it is a great illustration of the dichotomy between hopelessness and optimism that heller masterfully weaves throughout his book hig knows very little of the world as it is now being confined to within the limits of the beast's gas tank so as he explores beyond those boundaries he and the reader are buoyed by all the hope that still exists everywhere even as many humans succumb to their basest instincts there are signs of a better life charred forests with new growth animals still maintaining their migration patterns the world hig inhabits is still treacherous around every corner but heller leaves his characters and his readers with just the right amount of optimism that really elevates the dog stars above the typical doom and gloom inevitability of other similarly themed books there is much to mull over and savor from this book and it will stay with you as it did me long after you've put it down

raw_text.988: can a person find happiness after their whole world is destroyed this novel tells the story of hig a middle aged pilot that loses his wife friends and life style after a flu pandemic wipes out over 99% of humankind only his dog survives and hig is forced to retreat to a secluded airfield in colorado but this is not a book about the epidemic itself and does not dwell on the flu's march through earth or on hig's actions during the pandemic although some glimpses are given to us through the memories of the story's protagonists the novel is actually set a decade after the flu it's main theme is about finding the strength and motivation to keep going even after losing it all because hopelessness is only temporary and if we can endure it and adapt happiness can always be found again i think some people amongst those commonly referred to as preppers might find some of the elements of this novel interesting in particular bangley this character is the stereotypical doomsday prepper he lives next to hig in the airfield and helps him defend it from intruders this is the part of the novel i liked the least i did not particularly enjoy reading detailed descriptions of the weapons and techniques that hig and bangley used to protect their perimeter but i suppose it comes with the territory and it would be hard to write a credible post civilization novel without this and that's probably why i usually don't like reading books centered around these sort of cataclysmic events

raw_text.993: there's lots for hig the narrator of the dog stars to be nervous about living in the colorado mountains after a pandemic has wiped out most of civilization survival doesn't come easily and the threats are never far enough away one of the things that's great about peter heller's novel is that the tension the reader feels when hig describes something that could kill him is equalled by the tensions around moments when he could reconnect with another person the risk involved in reaching out to another is heightened and hig has to decide whether the reward is worth it in that way the book could almost be read as an allegory of adolescence emerging into a new world trying to figure out what kind of a person you want to be heller combines with that some wonderful descriptions of nature--from the stream as hig fishes or from the sky as he pilots his cessna to patrol for his safety--nature diminished by the lingering effects of climate change even after humanity has been decimated the result is a thought provoking story that i tumbled through quickly curious to see what would happen next i was not disappointed
raw_text.994: the dog starsby peter hellerin a post apocalyptic world hig is a pilot from colorado and lives in an airport hanger with the help of his neighbor bangley they try to survive this new world and cope the best they can it took me a little while to get into the groove of the writing style of this book but once i did i found this to be an enthralling read the story is told through first person almost like journal entries in that there were some fragmented sentences and thoughts i was thoroughly captivated by the plot of this story and i haven't read anything like this before which makes it all the more appealing to me hig is a character i liked a lot in that he did what he had to survive but kept who he was inside he adapted to the circumstances and how he lived his life was intriguing to me i was especially endeared to him by his relationship with jasper the author took hig on a journey struggling with the loss of his wife friends and dismal world i also appreciated the author's depiction of fishing and piloting a plane in a world of devastation death and loneliness there are vivid feelings throughout that will make you pause and wonder how you would handle such situations for me this was quite a unique novel and i recommend it highly

hig the narrator is a man who has survived a flu pandemic that has changed life in the united states as we know it completely wiping out most of the population those who have survived seem to be subject to some kind of contagious auto immune disorder of the blood as well that has continued to decimate the population and a certain amount of climate change has become noticeable as well hig is a very sad man having lost his wife but he appreciates the quietness of this new world he is a gardener and a hunter and has a strong relationship with the natural world around him as well as his dog jasper his little airplane the beast and bangley his neighbor in their isolated outpost bangley loves guns and does a great job of protecting them from the occasional marauders looking for well anything they can get their hands on food weapons etc and willing to kill and die to get it hig is tortured by a call over an airport he heard a few years back while out in his plane one day should he risk it all to try and find other survivors when just seeing another human being now almost requires 'a shoot first and ask questions later' attitude hig does not embrace that attitude although bangley an older man insists it is the only way to survive hig needs more from this life he sets out to find more after a revelatory week alone in the forest this was a heartrendingly beautiful story the writing is wonderful heller's descriptions of nature and of the human condition are gorgeous and moving hig's existential ramblings and thoughts while by himself also reminded me of antoine de saint exupery's the little prince and night flight this book is the definition of breathtaking my only complaint is that there are not another 300 pages too short i hope heller writes more fiction i raw_text.1027: i picked up peter heller's the dog stars knowing very little about it other than it was widely getting positive reviews the story ended up not at all what i expected and that was a good thing it turned out to be one of the best books of 2012 the dog stars is a post apocalyptic tale unbeknownst to me when i first opened it about civilization some time in the future after the world as we know it has been wiped out by a combination of some flu like disease and a blood disorder but the story's focus is not a post apocalyptic world which is what i liked most about it i think it's not gloom and doom and death and horror there are certainly some horrifying moments and cringe worthy occasions but it's really a story of hope and beauty in the most bleak of situations the story is told from the first person perspective of a character known only as hig who flies a 1956 cessna plane and has taken of refuge at an airport in colorado he and his survival partner bangley have turned the airport compound into a fortress of sorts and have learned how to survive in a world not conducive to survival the humans that have survived this long may carry a disease or may murder without thought survival of the fittest it's very clear that heller has a fondness for poetry he has an mfa in both fiction and poetry it seeps out of the pores of the book from the language and description to the way his narrator hig breaks up his sentences to the fact that hig himself has a fondness for poetry it helps to give a unique flavor to a post apocalyptic tale that doesn't feel like your standard end of the world tome hig is a very hopeful character who reveals the beauty in what's left perhaps making the ugliness even scarier and still seems to have room left in his mind to dream of things that would seem long gone in such a world the characters in the book are trying to find there place in the world and exactly what it means to live out your life under such circumstances what's the point in raw_text.1062: i'm glad i picked this up and i'm glad i struggled through the prose at the beginning as others have commented and many have complained peter heller's writing in the dog stars is stripped down prose quotation marks are missing dialogue is consistently left unattributed wait was that bangley or was that hig and yeah it's not always immediately clear if hig's inner dialogue is meant really dialogue or just narration these stylistic choices are arguably reflective of the new meaner world in which hig and bangley inhabit apocalyptic times call for a new way of understanding the world and how we understand the world is primarily through language the delicacies of the old world our world are gone and what we're left with is something that does resemble modernist realist prose but it's been shaken up abused with that said i get why people would want to turn away i can even get why people call this bad writing though i will steadfastly disagree with that argument but for me once i got into it once i got into the swing of the novel i thought it fit the novel well its spareness echoes the melancholic nature of the book overall the prose helps create a tone that works for this book reflective but thoughtful sparse but still rich there's a pretty good story too hig's search for meaning for something that will give his existence something more than just existing in this post apocalyptic world his desire for connection in whatever meaningful form it might take drew me in as proof i offer this anecdote about the end i won't venture into spoiler territory no worries but allow me to speak vaguely and cryptically about it i was as they say on the edge of my seat the book had me i could barely turn the pages afraid that i was going to see something i didn't want to see afraid that i would read something that i didn't want to this kind of engagement is proof positive that the writer has done something right the relationships between the characters were for me fully realized they all meant something to me in the end i think peter heller's is the dog stars is a post apocalyptic story with heart and a bit of hope okay fair enough there's great violence mixed in there too though but i do think that the book does a good job of looking at our inhumanity and humanity in thoughtful ways i really liked the dog stars and i'll raw_text.1102: it's fairly safe to say that mccarthy likes his apocalypse black as sin and bitter as poison brewed on an open fire to garner that acrid aftertaste with luck abetted with a drab of old whisky peter heller on the other hand is a starbucks kind of guy load in the sugar and a nice smattering of sweetened cream and perhaps a cookie at the side that's harsh this is a beautifully written book one full of love for landscape and the delights of piloting and trout fishing and the love of a dog and the missing of a dead wife and there is nothing wrong with that if that's how you like it there are smatterings of murder and a dog eating humans but in the grand scheme of things the central character hig gets away pretty lightly i'm starting to think there is a sharp division in the way the apocalypse is being rolled out in contemporary american literature there's the franzen style gentle pathos of ron currie jr 's everything matters and heller's the dog stars and then there's the gloves off guys ben marcus' the flame alphabet and blake butler's sky saw and a smattering of others sorry dog stars for all its sensitive writing is a starbucks apocalypse lacking both caffeine and whisky

raw_text.1109: the style of this book was somewhat unique it seems to have a stream of consciousness format the author doesn't use quotation marks when people are speaking i've read other books like this but it still takes a little while to adjust to the style as i'm sure other readers have said this book reminded me of the road by cormac mccarthy something horrible has happened lots of people have died from a disease and it's everyone left for themselves the main character hig is an outdoorsy guy it's no surprise he's survived the chaos he can hunt fish grow food and fly a plane he was a pilot for recreation and now this skill comes in handy hig has teamed up with bangley a survivalist who seems to almost enjoy the world in a state of chaos and of course there's jasper hig's canine companion even the book does remind me of the road it is unique in its own right the characters are very well developed and the world well described it's a place where a can of coca cola is like gold if you enjoy post apocalyptic stories you'll enjoy the dog stars

raw_text.1113: excellent story though at times not an easy one to read at its core this novel attempts to answer the question of what our most bare needs are in a post apocalyptic world where food and supplies are freely available to anyone willing to defend them from others think post world war z but pre the road a man struggles with the primal needs for beauty and connection the constant dangers and stresses of a defense focused mindset come through and make this an unsettling read because you are always worried about what threats are waiting on the next page i myself kept wondering whether the climax of the story would eventually be a sobering lesson or a hopeful one i'll leave it to the book to divulge that as it was too good a story for me to give away its secrets
raw_text.1114: some readers complain about the writing style of this book but i thought it was great the main character's voice is unique and authentic i enjoy post end of the world type scenarios so the survivalist aspect of the book really appealed to me the plot itself wasn't that original it's the typical scenario where adversity turns 95% of the population into ruthless killers even the good guys are killers in this book so as a reader it's choose your poison yet the main character goes against the grain by choosing to give where others would take by risking to love where others hate he rises above the selfish human condition the fact that he's a pilot and literally rises above it all in the beast symbolizes the indomitable spirit of the good guy i liked the message and would recommend the book
raw_text.1115: books about post apocalyptic societies are generally not my thing but the dog stars is one of my top ten favorite books of all time the story is frighteningly plausible a deadly flu and a blood borne disease have killed huge portions of the population the only people left on earth are ruthless survivors hig the main character lives in an airplane hanger in colorado scratching out a meager existence as a hunter and farmer when a nother tragedy strikes he gets in his tiny plane and flies out to grand junction where he spots two other survivors and decides to try to befriend them the book is deeply sad but it didn't make me feel sad it made me feel thankful that so many things that have disappeared from hig's world still exist in mine i loved hig the narrator the rugged mountaineer and hunter with a poet's soul i loved his dog jasper and his slightly unhinged companion bangley i loved his voice the language of the novel reflects hig and the world he lives in it's stripped of everything unnecessary and yet there is bittersweet beauty in it

raw_text.1129: first i would like to preface this review by saying i loved this book i loved it so much the plot was well thought out the descriptions stunning and his beautiful relationship with his dog all fabulous however i disliked all the cursing in the book the killing i understand the cursing i am trying to understand i suppose if the world ended i can't judge hig for a few f bombs but i still do deep down the sexual detail was rather in depth but not too graphic letting readers know what was happening and allowing them to understand how it related to the overall novel and hig's character i wouldn't say it was necessarily crass but it is from a man's point of view also the format of the novel was a little difficult to get used to at first it was hard to tell who was talking or when hig was talking to himself once into the book however it was much easier to understand i would recommend this book for anyone who has a few hours perhaps on a plane ride to read straight through i enjoyed the depth of the relationships both those enjoyed by hig previous to the flu and after i think this is an adventure book but with a plot like molasses delicious and deep and rather slowly poured out there are guns and planes and a type of magic that comes from recognizing our innate humanness

raw_text.1132: heller does a good job with the post apocalyptic tale that takes place in colorado specifically erie with a short hop by light aircraft to the delta paonia area then on to grand junction this first person account of the travails of existence following a flu pandemic and global warming provides a snippet of the worst and best of human behavior in the midst of horrible circumstances i'm not sure though what effect heller was trying to achieve with style other than perhaps he'd read cormac mccarthy's the road and thought the sentence structure there was kinda neat and he would emulate it the characterization was great the setting equally impressive and he gave the protagonist a dog jasper that is something guaranteed to please the title of the work the dog stars is aptly explained at the end i was a little disappointed with the uneventful i so wanted an event plane trip over the continental divide from erie to the grand mesa area of southwestern colorado i was curious with the route the protagonist took over the rockies gore range winter park that for a light aircraft would be quite harrowing and i believe not the safest or preferred route by most pilots but we're talking fiction here huh all in all this was a good read managing to encompass some heartening emotional content even to the extent of finding female companionship in the most unlikely of places
raw_text.1133: went quickly from this is one of the best books i've read recently to this is one of my favorite books of all time had me sobbing openly around page 100 grabbing paper and pen to write quotes down every few pages i want this book tattooed all over me it is the dog stars is what i wanted cormac mccarthy's the road to be it is in many ways similar it's sort of a travel narrative set in a post apocalyptic landscape that could harden anyone it's bleak and existentialist heller's use or lack thereof of quotation marks to denote who the fuck is speaking and what the fuck is being said is very mccarthyish but heller goes deeper where mccarthy is frustratingly spare heller fills his scenes and characterizations with detail where mccarthy is flat and emotionless heller puts the emotion right in your face like i said this is the book i wanted the road to be the road was too simple the dog stars is like mccarthy's book combined with some bukowskian syntax and details that stab you in the heart i could only get my hands on an arc there were a few pages that had me wondering if heller was doing something weird or if the weird string of non words and half punctuation were just the nature of an arc it doesn't really matter i guess all i can really say about this book is that even with the high expectations i had it came recommended very highly by someone whose taste i admire it blew me away i know this is one of those books i will read again and again as bleak as it is it restores my will to live fuck i love this book everyone read it now

raw_text.1137: the dog stars is a gripping novel of people who are just some of the survivors of a pandemic that wipes out 99% of the world's population many species of animals birds and fish are also eradicated a young man from colorado loses his wife family friends just everything one of the things he did pre pandemic was to be a hobby pilot owning a older cessna using his plane he goes to a different part of the country moving from airport to airport for gasoline he finds out quick that many of the survivors and infected and dying many others are marauders killing others for their belongings and food he becomes a survivor this is the story of his survival he never gives up his love of nature and mankind and searches for others people he can join with the writing is extraordinary it is what one must think of as common thoughts because most of the conversations he has is with himself he does find others and to see how things develop and what becomes of a few people is a novel that must be read i will read it again later after i have absorbed what i can remember read it you will be rewarded

raw_text.1152: as a huge fan of the post apocalyptic genre i was eager to read this one as soon as i heard about it i found this to be somewhat more hopeful than some of the classics of the genre the road comes to mind which was refreshing it took me a little while to get used to the way the story is written no quotation and lots of fragmented passages for example but i became accustomed to it eventually in fact i think the language quirks added to the realism of the novel and some of the writing literally made me stop and think wow the beauty of the writing simple and quirky really spoke to me and made this a special gem i really loved the characters especially hig and jasper who stole my heart i think the interplay of the characters and how they are all dealing with the aftermath of disaster was really interesting this did seem to be a new way of approaching the end of the world subject in some wasy but didn't quite offer me all that i hoped it would perhaps it was just that my expectations were high and i didn't quite get them met that is why i've given it 4 stars it was a hard decision however it is definitely worth a read particularly for those who love the post apocalyptic genre the story and its themes have stuck with me over the last few weeks so its impact isn't necessarily fleeting i'm pleased to say that hig and his world have stayed in my mind making me think and being a much more thoughtful book than it seems at first glance peter heller is obviously a gifted fiction writer and i'm looking forward to more of his fiction in the future

raw_text.1187: just barely four stars there are a lot of comparisons to make with the road one of my favorite books in the last few years it is post apocalyptic a man struggling to survive the tone is set with the language and its rhythms there are quite a few differences however i enjoyed that the dog stars offered a bit more hope it certainly wasn't pinocchio if you wish upon a dog star but it was a bit more relenting in its doom and gloom there were moments of wonder and peace and the language was much less sparse than the road more poetic the author has an mfa in poetry as well from iowa of all places go hawks anyway this book is much more flowery in its prose than the road while the road is sparse and rhythmic like a forced march the dog stars tends to feel like fast eddying currents of words flowing and then stopping and then changing directions dog stars is also more literal where the road is meant to feel like an allegory both feel like there may be a story to be told after the book ends however the road feels as if it is imparting a theme or a lesson though not in a heavy handed way the dog stars just feels as if there could be more to be told a sequel of sorts now i am not hoping for one just saying there is more of a touch of realism to this book the book has hemmingway's detailed depictions of fishing landscape and flying without his sparse prose i guess i would recommend it to those who enjoy postapocalyptic settings but for whom the road may be a bit too depressing
