raw_text.1199: 3 5 starsfirst let me clarify to those who haven't read the book that this book is not about a man and his dog living in the post apocalyptic u s i've read a number of reviews where readers claim that hig's dog jasper is the heart and soul of the book really my read of the book led me to see that jasper is actually a very minor player in the overall story instead the real crux of the book is the relationship between hig and bangley bangley is a great character and when he is on the page the story is at its best especially when his personality is contrasted against hig's unfortunately the time spent between these two characters in the book isn't enough at least not for me when they aren't together the storyline suffers as a result don't get me wrong heller's writing is beautiful and the way in which he describes the post apocalyptic setting makes me feel as if i were actually present however the large amount of descriptive prose slows down the pacing of what should be a very exciting edge of your seat kind of story overall i would recommend this book it deserves a look especially by those who are interested in this genre i enjoyed it and i thought that it was above average but i'm not sure that it deserved to be on all of the 2012 best lists on which i had seen it ps mark deakins is an excellent reader and i look forward to listening to more of his reads on audio

raw_text.1201: "the dog stars" by peter heller published by alfred a knopf category - fiction literaturea flu pandemic has laid waste to the world with only small pockets of survivors hig a survivor with his dog jasper live in colorado they have come across another survivor bangley and they fiercely defend the small domain that they have created for themselves hig is a pilot and does reconnaissance missions checking for other survivors food and intruders on one of his missions he hears a voice over the radio and is determined to find out where this other voice is coming from hig takes a calculated risk in flying beyond his perimeter and fuel capabilities to locate this voice it is one this flight that he finds an older man and his daughter although he has lost his loving wife to the flu he becomes infatuated with her and agrees to take them with him when he returns to his home base in the meantime they pursue the voice and discover that they should have left well enough alone a story that combines love humor danger and hope "the dog stars" is written in an unusual format that might be appealing to some readers although a good read it does not live up to the hype or expectation of the advance book reviews many will find in slow going and uneven in context
raw_text.1202: the flu killed nearly everyone it killed hig's wife and unborn child his friends and everyone except for his dog jasper holed up at an airport with a gun toting killer named bangley hig flies out on his 1956 cessna hunting fishing but mostly seeking an escape not looking forward to the future when all the fuel will be unusable he's aimless lost a dreamer who hates the killing he must do when armed people invade the airport even when their ill intentions are obvious hig hates to kill and bangley revels in it honing his weapons and traps one day he decides to fly past the point of no return with the hope he will find fuel at his destination an airport where he heard a voice as he flew over what he finds isn't at all what he expects but it might give him hope for a new life if it doesn't kill him first sad and wistful some of the book drags but much of it is a loner who talks to himself musing on the past and the possible future hig's melancholy is touching and at times heart wrenching lightened with dashes of hope here and there

raw_text.1205: dystopian novels aren't everyone's cup of tea unless you are really into the usual zombies etc but if they are done well with a literary quality like cormac mccarthy's the road or margaret atwood's oryx and crake they a provide a page turning and thoughtful reading experience this one falls into that category like those two novels the world has had some type of massive catastrophe in this case a flu like plague nine years ago wipe out most of the population and the few survivors are left in isolated groups fending off the changing environment as well as marauding groups attacking those who have found means to survive hig is a private pilot living in rural colorado who lost his beloved wife early on but has his old cessna and a dwindling supply of aviation fuel from the nearby erie co airfield he also has jasper his dog as companion he manages to join forces with a man named bangly who needs hig's help to defend a wide perimeter by hig who can fly in a 300 mile or so radius around their base to reconnoiter the surroundings for threats they are very different people bangly is a loner type military survivalist who is only concerned about survival hig is despondent about going on without human connection on one of his reconnaissance flights he picked up a faint radio signal coming from grand junction which is just beyond his aircraft's range he has also heard about the coming of the arabs from a band of marauders who he and bangly managed to fend off during an attack when jasper dies he decides to find if he can reestablish what had made his life worth living and heads out in his plane toward grand junction the journey brings him some unexpected discoveries the ending was left ambiguous as to whether there is a hopeful future or if there is further threat awaiting

raw_text.1211: "the dog stars" focused on pilot hig and his dog as they fly around the u s trying to survive after a deadly disease has killed most of mankind i connected with hig through his sarcastic and pragmatic opinions as he reminisced about his prior life and visualized the bleak future the novel followed hig as he defends his property and life by killing those who attack him but his softer side is revealed through the stories of his wife this dichotomy provided a perfect protagonist that was aimed at a mature audience the recollections of hig and his wife was my favorite aspect of the book because the author brilliantly used these reflections to show hig as a genuine and emotional character the scene where his wife dies was especially poignant he not only emerges as a round character who is enjoyable to follow he is brimming with depth and sincerity but there was plenty of action to keep the plot exciting his perspective of flight is an interesting addition to the end of the world genre and provides a humanistic element to the book the staccato manner of writing was reminiscent of "the road " but hig's perspective made the book far more manageable i wasn't a huge fan of the choppy format and lack of quotations marks which made the novel difficult for me to read but this was a solid novel anyone who is interested a quirky hero battling for his life at the end of the world would really enjoy this novel

raw_text.1223: in his haunting and poetic the dog stars peter heller sets up yet another post apocalyptic world full of survivors who aren't quite sure what happened or why as they try to avoid roaming bands of zombies heller's two main characters are hig a pilot who lost his wife in the plague and his neighbor at the airport where they live bangley a gun nut sitting on an armory of weapons the first 100 pages set up this world its routines and tensions its battles terrors and little triumphs with a real difference a significant part of hig's focus and his narration is the natural world so heller provides beautiful lyrical passages about how the changes in the world have also changed the landscape hig's perspective as a pilot provides a logical link to surveying the countryside some of these passages are breath taking in their ability to both evoke nature and echo the terrors in this changed world we climb along the creek as the grainy gray seeps between the tall skeletal trees the beetle kill ponderosa and lodgepole the branches without needles empty handed in death imagine i am vampire combined with a river runs through it hig's main companion is his dog jaspar and here heller excels at the mute communication between the two it never falls into mawkishness but heller's descriptions of jaspar interacting with hig are among the book's best about halfway thought the dog stars hig decides to try to track down the source of a radio transmission he heard years before and that really sets the main plot in motion without giving away much more of the plot i will say that there are parts of the plot in the latter half of the book that while maybe necessary felt tacked on and out of tone with the rest of the book ultimately the dog stars does not succumb to an easy resolution or for that matter a difficult one but in doing so provides something unexpected a broader comment on how to survive change on adapting to new circumstances and it is this thought that i have carried away from the book

raw_text.1231: i liked and disliked this book a pilot and his colleague a skilled gun nut defend a small airport on the east slope of the rockies in a post apocalyptic world the apocalypse is the result of a combination of changed climate and a one two punch of a virulent lethal virus and an autoimmune blood disease neither of which we know much about one day the pilot during a routine scouting flight hears a faint radio call from a distant airport and this makes him wonder about whether he should risk it and fly out there even though all remnants of civil authority and civilization have disintegrated that's the set up for the story there are a few things you should know if you decide to read this book first one character in particular has language that is liberally smattered with f bombs i didn't like that also later on in the book there is a prolonged description of intimacy that was imo too much i skipped over that part there is one other thing the writing style is highly unorthodox there are no quotation marks so you have to figure out who is thinking or saying what to whom and that actually was a bit distracting to me so did i like it i really liked the premise and the basic story line i didn't care for the language and i felt like the writing style got in the way of the story but then again it was perhaps a bit post apocalyptic in its own way all in all i'd say that i'm vacillating between 3 and 4 stars out of 5 i liked parts of it but was put off by others

raw_text.1240: definitely not a typical post apocalyptic novel "the dog stars" is more in the tradition of "earth abides" than "windup girl " the novel is set just a few years into our own future so there is no whiz bang tech there are no epic battles between gangs determined to control their piece of a destroyed cityscape because in "the dog stars" practically no humans are left alive at all leaving the protagonist hig to wander far and wide in the company of his dog jasper a lifelong hunter hig is comfortable in the wilderness observing how the ecosystem is changing in the absence of humans and tracking the continuing effects of global climate change many beautifully written passages bring the reader into hig's world describing trees and mountains streams and stars at all times of the day and seasons of the year that the author is a writer for outdoor magazines comes as no surprise and he employs his first hand knowledge of wild places to wonderful effect here he is able to do what many writers fail at--making me say "that sounds so beautiful" rather than telling me it is so hig also has lots of time to contemplate his own continued existence and the chain of painful and horrific experiences that have led him to this point that he only allows himself to fall into reverie occasionally is what keeps the book from becoming maudlin finally a note about the unusual writing style that was used the short choppy fragmented sentences felt awkward at first but i quickly became accustomed to them this stream of consciousness style made me feel like i was inside the protagonist's head so much so that when disaster inevitably befell hig i had an intense physical reaction to it okay i bawled my head off heller's ability to get me to identify so directly with his character is what bumps this from a high 4 star to a 5 star rating

raw_text.1246: one of the best books i've read in a long time it's not perfect but nothing is so i'm not going to even bother with nitpicks the language is at times poetic penetrating insight into people dogs and planes and hig's relationships with them and how these complex relationships can balance on the head of a pin the detailed and beautiful observations of nature the colors the reflecting light the shapes the texture and although it's a well tread thought how we take it all for granted and find it hard to notice and appreciate the finer and simpler things around us maybe until we find ourselves in a post apocalypse i can see readers saying whatthefckisthis after the first few pages i did the writing is unorthodox but by the middle i was mostly flowing along like a cool stream on a colorado mountain it's like letter of the law proper grammar would have gotten in the way of hig expressing his thoughts accurately and as they happened maybe quotation marks around dialogue would look artificial that's stretching it i know but either way it all worked for me and made sense and it doesn't come off as pretentious thank god for hig's sense of humor too it allows you to breath and let go of some of the despair about the situation i laughed out loud a few times overall a unique and lasting reading experience and i'm curious to see what peter heller comes up with next

raw_text.1253: just when i had falsely assumed that cormac mccarthy had given us the last word on the post apocalyptic novel along comes peter heller with something fresh written in an unusual abridged stream of consciousness style format heller's prose is lean and muscular his protagonist hig or big hig is a sensitive guy who has survived a nameless pandemic that has wiped away the better part of the world's population despite the fact that he's daily living in a combat zone tenaciously guarded by he and a paramilitaristic partner bangley who's name becomes increasingly appropriate as the novel progresses he has not allowed himself to become completely hardened by this brave new world remembering the gentleness and poetry of his life before with a sense of longing he reads cooks tends his garden and daily flies a perimeter with his canine co pilot but unable to escape a haunting message picked up years earlier on his cessna's radio he chooses one day to fly away from the safety of his new home past the point of no return risking everything to discover the source of the mysterious transmission it may take a few pages to adjust to the unusual prose style but in reflection it's not only appropriate to the work but difficult to imagine that the reader could be as submerged in the dog stars had it been written any other way it might be gritty and absorbing but the real beauty of this novel is its cautious analysis of the guarded way people relate to each other in a world where close human relationships are increasingly uncommon a terrific book on many different levels

raw_text.1265: apocalypse novels are currently in vogue again thanks to the sustained success of the walking dead and all other things zombie but peter heller is up to something different in the dog stars and it's a refreshing take on what happens when the world goes to crap first of all there are no zombies the story takes place outside denver colorado ten years after a devastating blood disease has decimated the human and animal population those who survived have formed small tribes that do whatever they can to survive the narrator of the story hig has made his home in a former mcmansion close to an airport where he keeps his cessna airplane along with another man named bangley and his dog jasper he hunts fishes and kills anyone who wanders onto their property hig and bangley are a dystopian odd couple who rarely agree on anything - hig is more apt to consider people as complex individuals whose interests just happen to clash with their own while bangley only sees people as vermin to be exterminated as quickly as possible no exceptions for the sake of their survival hig doesn't exactly like it but bangley's code has kept them alive in a world that has all but forgotten the social construct of their former civilization it's this conflict between hard won survival and the human need for socialization that really drives the story and gives the important scenes such impact the story is a little slow to get into because there is no big conflict up front just two guys surviving day to day in a cold heartless world but hig is intent on finding something else other than just mere survival about halfway through it starts to get interesting and by the end i really appreciated how the story had all come together and everything from the beginning hit me with more impact the conclusion made everything worthwhile and revealed what the author's intentions had been all along i have to admit that some parts were a little difficult to get through because the narrator talks almost incessantly about fish fishing and various plants and bushes it had its point to be sure but eventually the constant yearning for trout became a little tiresome heller's minimalist voice does little to help in these spots almost extending the agony with short sentences overall i appreciated the tone of this book and its contrast to most 'end of the world' stories many parts felt very realistic and if the world goes down this way it will be up to the higs and bangleys of the world to sort things out i listened to the audiobook version of this story narrated by mark deakins who did an exemplary job of interpreting heller's minimalist prose with maximum impact and gravitas

raw_text.1280: picked this book up on a whim when i had one of those buy x get 1 free kinda thingies and didn't have anything specific in mind i've read quite a few post apocalyptic books including the road and the postman which stand out this book more than holds its own heller has an interesting voice sort of stream of consciousness i think it works pretty well in this setting in particular because you're in a world where the protagonist spends so much time alone that you can easily imagine him talking to himself either out loud or to himself the tone of the book is melancholy as it should be in a post apocalyptic world without being overly dramatic or mad max there are however some truly touching moments in the book it's a book that is more about hope than about despair i think the characters in the book are well done they seem alive and yet are varied enough to be convincing they aren't cardboard cutouts and you learn more about them gradually throughout the story one kind of quirky thing that distracted me a bit heller doesn't follow standard quotation grammar so i found myself having to back up and re read paragraphs occasionally to try to figure out who had been speaking and if it was out loud or in thought it's not long and i burned through most of it on a single plane ride overall while i wouldn't say this is one of my favorites of all time i really enjoyed this read and would definitely try something else by heller

raw_text.1288: one of my favorite classes at college had nothing to with my major my minor or my attempted and eventually jettisoned music minor that's right one of my favorite classes in college was a film class looking at horror movies not the gross out torture porn we've seen the last few years or endless spin offs but horror movies that tried to say something within the horror genre stephen king is great at doing this with his horror novels the shining really told a story about alcoholism destroying a modern family through a haunted hotel driving a man crazy the cell told a story about the lemming culture of technology through cell phone created zombies i love the boundaries genre fiction provides and the creativity authors have within those boundaries to create different messages my love of genre fiction while explaining my love affair with superhero comic books brought me to the dog stars by peter heller end of the world fiction is pretty popular right now and there's a lot of themes running around as authors wonder what the heck would happen if 99 9% of the world suddenly died turned into zombies got nuked moslty as one would expect things get really f ed up suzanne collins the hunger games imagines that america would get pretty totalitarian and hyper focused on violence as entertainment cormac mccarthy the road sees a father's bond overpowering the horrors of a lawless america robert kirkman the walking dead looks at everyday people struggling to make sense of their world and cope with their own horrific actions needed to survive heller takes a different approach and instead looks for hope and vitality in his novel about a small aircraft pilot living in colorado after 99 9% of the world dies of the flu sure there are some tragic scenes a flashback to the main character's wife dying in an overcrowded hospital but heller doesn't dwell on the awfulness in fact the novel opens after the plague and the ensuing lawless chaos has already died out heller's characters have survived and are searching for what comes next finally when heller isn't writing novels he's a regular article contributor to a lot of outdoor magazines his love and familiarity of nature offers a wonderful backdrop for a lot of the novel both for it's safety and the healing nature of it's rhythm fishing hiking gardening and sleeping outdoors all make appearances in the novel and always seem to herald some level of healing and normalcy for heller's characters

raw_text.1327: i don't give out 5 star reviews very often so when i do i really look forward to clicking that fifth star now i don't believe that everyone is going to think this is five stars but this author nailed it in almost every area of fiction writing that i enjoy this book contains very few characters who are introspective and ask big questions about what the world is going to be like now that most people are dead more importantly though this book has many layers and contains great scenes in nature and exploring the depths of human love some of the scenes between the main character and his deceased wife from memory are hauntingly beautiful and sad plus the main character has a great dog who is one of his best companions for me a great fiction rattles me to my core and makes me feel like the actual character in the book i feel as if i have been there with him in his skin wondering about the world around me the dog stars is definitely a book i'm going to buy and keep in my collection because i can see myself reading it over and over again playing with the metaphors in my mind and exploring a new world through the characters this was a tremendous read that i did not want to end

raw_text.1329: this is one of the best books i've read in a long time a new view on post apolcolypse this book is beautiful digs into the many and varied emotions of someone who has survived a tragedy we see hig's denial and anger his love and hope we see him mourn what i found touching is that he never quite loses hope this book does not have the extreme sadness of cormac mccarhty's the road also an excellent book there are moments of profound sadness but also uplifting moments we are focused more on hig's story not just what has already happened but happens next
raw_text.1330: i read this book because author peter heller appeared on the radio show that i produce and his interview was so engaging that i could have listened to him for hours i normally gravitate away from anything apocalyptic so this was a big stretch for me the book is written in three parts and i have to say the first part was a tough slog it's very violent one can imagine it as the first third of an action movie and i wonder if it's this violent in part to get attract movie producers but hig the first person narrator is very thoughtful and thought provoking and i liked him in spite of the violence once past the first section the book became far more of a page turner the writing especially in the second and third sections of the book is beautiful heller's descriptions of streams of his dog of the woods and of a beautiful woman are practically photographic you can almost feel his heart breaking from a combination of loss and joy and despite the fact that this book takes place in a world that has just about ended it's a book full of hope which is no mean feat this would be a great book for a book club days after finishing it i'm still thinking about it here's our colorado public radio interview with peter heller http www cpr org #load_article|colo

raw_text.1333: a flu pandemic wipes out 99% of the population the story starts nine years after the pandemic hig survives in rural colorado and has an alliance with bagley his neighbor bagley shoots anything that moves they're an odd couple hig and his dog jasper fly the perimeter in an old cessna and defend their land with bagley their area is ideal because they have a creek shelter and a watchtower from a nearby hangar while hig does surveillance he gets a radio signal it continues to haunt him and a few years later he decides to find the source hig never loses his humanity while he encounters good and evil survivors this is a post apocalyptic novel but it's not about gloom and doom it's lovely and poetic hig still finds joy humor and happiness in nature and in his life http catoverlord blogspot com 2013
raw_text.1334: set just a few years in the future the dog stars portrays a diminished earth where the rivers are drying up the trout are gone and many large mammals have gone extinct adventure writer peter heller's first novel grips the reader from the first page as hig the pilot of an old cessna describes his life before--and after--a plague wiped out 99 percent of the world's population like earth abides and the road this post apocalyptic tale of survival takes place after civilization has failed and it's every man for himself but the dog stars is ultimately a story of what matters in life and why we are here it's a great read right from the start

raw_text.1342: i read a quick review of this book in the costco monthly that comes out and it was enough to make me request it from our local library i am certainly glad that i did read it and it's a rather quick read but tells so much about humans and our urge to find meaning and connections with life and our all that surrounds us hig has survived a super flu that killed about 97% of the world's population his wife family and friends are gone he finds himself living with another survivor in an abandoned airfield they become family of sorts looking out for each other and doing the dance humans do so well with trying to figure each other out they do a great job of protecting each other hig flies around in his plane at least as far as he can while saving fuel for the return trip one day he hears a voice over the radio as he passes over another airport but doesn't do anything about it for 3 years things get very interesting after that but because i don't want to give anything else away you will just have to read it it's scary knowing that this could possibly happen at sometime in the future especially since it's not clear whether it was a true flu bug or whether it was caused by some chemical being dropped by plane
raw_text.1343: it takes a bit to get used to peter heller's unique writing style in this debut novel but soon you get into its rhythm which suits hig the main character a man who has survived a pandemic with only one taciturn and cranky old man to talk to occasionally well him and shouting across a field to a mennonite group living a short plane's ride from the airport hig has made his home they are sick carrying the blood disease that many of the sparse survivors of the flu contracted which is why he must keep his distance he maintains his 1956 cessna using it to patrol his area watching for bandits and thieves trying to ambush him and the old man bangley who knows how to use a gun to protect them both for nine years they get by surviving day to day hig keeps his sanity by talking to his dog jasper when jasper dies of old age hig pounded with grief decides to fly farther than ever before to see what might be left he'd heard a voice on the plane's radio a few years back and he figures it's time to look into it what he finds changes his life this is very much a dystopian future one that is not all that difficult to imagine coming true but for every dark moment there is a a bright beam of hope renewal recovery and a possible future for the planet heller has an impressive standing as a non fiction writer and he's brought that insightful eye and layered creativity to join the fiction community in a very impressive and memorable way everybody is talking about this book already read it and you will understand why

raw_text.1379: minor spoilers alertthe dog stars blew me away i read it and then i bought it again on audio and listened to it on a few long runs through the palisades the road is one of my favorite books and i felt in peter heller's story that same gritty beauty cormac mccarthy gives us but the dog stars went deeper into beauty i think peter heller must have a huge heart when jasper died my heart broke the description of that bond between man and dog felt just right to me but more the way over the course of the story our narrator hig grew to care for bangley the love he let himself feel at the end of the book really moved me he just never let the horror crush him well at times it almost overwhelmed him but he was always creative and bighearted enough to find something to hang onto though all those crazy marauders aside hig's world seemed like a perfect place to me a dog a plane a dude who lives to keep your perimeter clear plenty of homegrown veggies a good supply of venison and fish the mountain hikes the streams and cool pools there's a line in the curious incident of the dog in the night the kid says something like i wouldn't mind if i was the only person left in the world i wouldn't mind at all i definitely feel that way too sometimes probably not the healthiest mindset but the description setting was in some ways so fiercely beautiful i could see how bangley didn't mind being cut off from what little remained of civilization i loved the name hig that idea of higgs boson that it's the god particle that binds all matter seems just the thing to incorporate into our narrator's character the way he binds himself to all that he sees and allows himself to be a part of it to acknowledge that magic that connects all life all matter that bond even to the bad destructive stuff though when hig is feeling low in that shangri la valley in the last third of the book the old man keeps calling him higgs and hig keeps telling him not higgs hig just hig the everyman god particle nice touch apparently the scientific community per wikipedia anyway disapproves of calling the boson the god particle and maybe peter heller had that in mind as he was writing given his attention to detail his nailing every sentence with clarity no frills i'm guessing he did enough about the hig higgs thing the dog stars was a truly great book and i'm putting it on my favorites shelf and hey look at that it rests somewhere between faulkner and hemingway right where peter heller should be

raw_text.1389: the dog stars is a unique story told in a unique style the story of a man left nearly alone after a virulent flu has decimated mankind is painful beautiful ugly aching and finally hopeful in some ways heller's writing reminded me of the book thief but while that book's style of playing with language makes it my favorite of all time this one left me feeling a bit distracted by the fragmented sentences and thoughts yet by the end of the book as hig was healing and beginning to reach wholeness his thoughts coalesced as well so this mirroring of hig's mental and emotional health with the story pushed this book from three stars to four for me this is a book about big themes it asks you to ponder questions like what would i be willing to do to survive what makes life worth living is surviving at any cost really living what keeps me sane some of these questions especially the last one are particularly relevant to my everyday life and while i enjoyed hig's story i do not recommend it without reservation there are hard and harsh things in this book heller balances many of them with moments of beauty but examining the human psyche is a messy business if you're in the mood for a book that will make you think look no further than the dog stars if on the other hand you're looking for a book that will transport you to a more pleasant world than our own look elsewhere

raw_text.1413: i really struggled with this book after glancing at other reviews i noticed that the majority of people who rated it 1 or 2 stars did so based on issues they had with the stylistic writing approach the author employed my 2 star rating had nothing to do with fragmented sentences incomplete thoughts or the lack of parentheses around dialogue within the story though in a nutshell i couldn't connect with any of the characters in fact i cared for jasper the dog more than any of the humans in this story upon reflection i might have liked bangley hig's human counterpart in survival if he would have stayed on as a more central character in the book unfortunately bangley is present in the beginning and then falls off the radar forgive the pun when hig takes his plane on a trip to explore the outlying areas in search of other survivors i had hopes that once hig encountered other people the story would pick up it really didn't more descriptions of scenery and lots of reflection on the past but nothing earth shattering or exciting enough that left me yearning to read more i'm really not sure why all the hype about this book i will say that the one thing i actually did enjoy about the dog stars was the writing style i thought it made perfect sense for a post apocalyptic novel anyone who survives and endures such pain loss and misery is bound to be broken to some extent wandering thoughts and questions about what one may have done differently throughout life are bound to arise therefore incomplete thoughts seem the norm to me i have seen this book frequently compared to the road which i actually enjoyed reading the road was definitely darker but it seemed to have more purpose and meaning in the end this is all just my opinion so you'll have to read the book and form your own

raw_text.1429: in "the dog stars" narrator hig reflects on his life before and in the nine years after a flu pandemic decimated the world's population he shares his deep losses his good heart and his thoughts about death and the apocalypse all while living day to day in survival mode one of the few survivors of the flu hig has made his way from his denver home to a small and well equipped airport here he finds fuel to fly a 1956 cessna grows vegetables hunts and contemplates the changes in his life his aging dog jasper is his constant companion co pilot and guard against roving plunderers when a man named bangley arrives at the airport alone and with a huge arsenal his and hig's incompatibility is obvious hig is too trusting bangley too eager to shoot no questions asked but the two develop a symbiotic relationship "saving my bacon is his job " hig reports "i have the plane i am the eyes he has the guns he is the muscle "so hig accepts bangley even as he finds him incomprehensible in his love of killing and weaponry hig is the anti killer a poet with a deep appreciation of the cycles of life and the earth he offers some beautiful observations such as "it caught me sometimes that this was okay just this that simple beauty was still bearable barely and that if i lived moment to moment garden to stove to the simple act of flying i could have peace " just as hig made up names for the sky's constellations as he lay outside each night he had to make up his path to a new life as he journeyed through the post apocalyptic years and when he reaches a crossroads in this life and decides to venture further in the plane leaving bangley on his own the narrative becomes more suspenseful tired of the dog eat dog existence hig follows a sign of hope a partial radio message from the grand junction airport three years earlier he is willing to risk his life to search for people he can care about who share his joys about life and hopes for the future if such people even exist anymore although hig's style sometimes resembled a sort of stream of consciousness that forced re reading to be understood his musings were often breathtaking i cried i laughed i was riveted and i came to care very much for this wonderful character enough for five stars

raw_text.1433: though slightly reminiscent of the road this post apocalyptic novel is both more hopeful and all the more devastating for that hope after a virulent flu has killed most of the population the living descend into a brutal existence the story starts 8 or 9 years after the fact and finds our hero hig bunkered down in a regional airport in colorado with his dog jasper and bangley his survivalist and slightly off kilter neighbor together hig and bangley have managed to keep human predators at bay though that has involved a lot of firepower and killing something bangley seems to relish a bit too much hig takes regular flights in his 1956 cessna viewing the devastation from above and looking for signs of life he fishes and hunts deer and elk and things have seemed to reach a sort of stasis however a series of events push hig to fly his plane past the point of no return in pursuit of something more heller is an amazing writer and one clearly familiar with the colorado landscape descriptions of nature are all the more beautiful when contrasted with the brutality of hig's life and the fact that even these more permanent feeling things may be fleeting

raw_text.1451: i've been reading a lot of post apocalyptic novels of late i'm not sure why but they interest me in some ways i think it's a way to imagine a much simpler world i could read historical fiction but those stories all lead here with computers and global warming and globalization but books that imagine the breaking down of all of this imagine it just gone and who knows what's ahead of us i have always also felt torn between city life and country life but these books would take that choice away and i would be good at country life successful and it's nice to know that about myself if i could gather a few folks together and just make it to a defensible place with water and good soil i would make it i think i like the simplicity of it the getting to have human emotions tied to actual things survival love of family and friends hard work instead of to things and technology the dog stars is the best i've read outside of the the road not as bleak but occasionally just as sad also i have learned from this book and others that should the apocalypse come you'll want a dog and because dogs are finite things i might literally in my flee from the city stop by an animal shelter and scoop up a few non spayed and non neutered pooches to keep the dogs in my life going no lie they're early warning systems they're hunters they're soldiers they're bed warmers they're babysitters and while being all of those things they are also capable of being your buddy cats are fine for the modern world but when all of this comes tumbling down a dog's the thing i don't want to say anything about this book you should just read it

raw_text.1459: first of all this is another post apocalyptic vision of the world but in the dog stars the writing itself sets this book apart the language is robust and experimental with short machine gun like bursts and haiku like prose it is also dream like and often beautiful it is about loss and survival and hope and it scared me made me cry and sometimes gave me a laugh there are no zombies no vampires no monsters just us and we're terrifying enough it's also a story about finding love in what seems a loveless world it is about friendship between men when it seems all men must be feared i love the part of the book that is about the bond between a man and a dog there are some truly gruesome elements to the book and quite a bit of violence but there is also the beauty of the remaining natural world it's streams flowers trees and animals all disappearing but in enough evidence to invoke nostalgia and appreciation in the end this book is about what it really means to be a human in and of itself recommended to anyone but especially those who admire post apocalyptic novels
raw_text.1460: 4 1 2 i loved this book would have gone for 5 stars but for the ending i can see where some people may not like the somewhat poetic writing style of this book but you do get used to it i chose to listen to the audio version and the narrator was really good he changed his voice to suit the different characters which made it easy to follow to be in the situation that the protagonist hig is in is to me unimaginable he is alive in a world where very few people survived and he is constantly worried that those who do probably want to kill him yet he keeps a pretty positive attitude to me there were quite a few unanswered questions and that left me a bit frustrated at times but all in all i could hardly tear myself away from the book and was sad when it ended
raw_text.1461: to start with the writing in "the dog stars" is experimental it is written in first person past tense but the sentence structure is often broken and disjointed thoughts will sometimes stop without logical completion there are also no quotation marks around dialog sentences the only other book i can compare the style to is "the sound and the fury" by faulkner the style is partially explained as being because the protagonist had a disease that may have damaged his brain i have nothing against experimental writing i've done a bit of it as an author myself but to be honest even though i frequently write in first person this book took me awhile to adjust to it is just that different so be warned the jacket cover describes the book as "spine tingling" i'm not sure to what extent that is true the first third of the book moves at a fairly slow pace the context was interesting enough to me not being either a pilot or a hunter camper fisherman that i kept going just to enjoy at least the glimpse into those worlds the action speeds up as the novel progresses of course but i don't think it ever reached the point of "spine tingling" aside from writing style and the protagonist bent for the outdoors there wasn't a terrible lot that was original here either yes at times the writing was poetic but the text also essentially used the f word as punctuation seriously i don't think i've read a sci fi novel or even a post apocalyptic novel that used profanity so liberally again maybe that's the protagonist's brain damage but my gut feeling is it the writer trying to make the work feel "gritty" and "real " i read an advance reader's edition so maybe that will be toned down some there's a lot of violence here too the world of "dog stars" is strictly one of shoot first and ask questions later regardless of the age or sex of the assumed perpetrators yes the protagonist feels some remorse but he still kills a lot of people and it isn't just in self defense everyone is a threat regardless except a group of mennonites that i'm still unsure plot wise what the significance was there is some sexual activity depicted i don't know if i would call it graphic but the description is fairly clear essentially it is world devoid of any morality aside from what feels right at the time there is only a passing reference to a christian in the book aside from the mennonites i assume and that one allusion paints christians merely as "simple" so what am i left with here "the dog stars" kept my attention through the end and there were some redemptive and moving moments in it i credit the author for being experimental and for crafting a believable yet vile world but i can't recommend it i don't know that the ending was big enough or bold enough to justify the journey

raw_text.1482: no spoilers in this review i don't usually read listen to fiction and generally avoid post apocalyptic fiction so i don't have much to compare it with i was aware this was heller's first fiction novel and that he has a background in poetry i appreciated the poetic style of the book rich with philosophical musings considering it was heller's first novel it was very good but i would expect more writing quality from a more experienced writer i listened to this audio book after pulling it almost randomly off the library shelf going into the book knowing nothing about it and having no expectations contributed to it being an enjoyable listen i highly recommend this book be read listened to first before reading any reviews and potential spoilers after listening to the book i read the reviews and discovered there were no quotation marks in the book i would likely have found this challenging to read the audio book used different voice intonations for the dialogue of different characters so the lack of quotations was irrelevant to me the book triggered many interesting reflections for me including the current human enterprise in relatively stable first world countries is more fragile than we often realize once this fragility is upset it could be a difficult and long long road to rebuilding if even possible in some cases this book helped me understand what it would be like to live in some parts of the world today such as parts of some developing nations this book helped me understand history a bit better how bustling wealthy cities can become ruins in a relatively short time how cities are not generally a safe place in a world in upheaval on one hand the urban homesteader in me was motivated by the survivalist themes in the book on the other hand i realized that in a major upset to human civilization i don't likely stand much a chance of surviving for long anyway and that is not necessarily a bad thing

raw_text.1498: i'm a post apocalyptic fiction junky i go through phases where i'll read two or three books at a time i'm always looking for something new in this sub genre so when i saw this book pop up on my amazon recommendations i jumped right on it i'm also not afraid to stop reading anything from the genre if the writing is too bad or the story is too weak neither are the case with this novel heller is a good writer and the story while sharing elements with many other books from the genre is a relatively fresh take on the survival narrative hig the main character flies a cessna on recon missions around the area where he lives on a private airfield with one other person between the two of them they have been able to pool their skills and resources and survive but that's about it heller comes at the story from an oblique angle like cormac mccarthy's the road there's not a ton of back story and the back story really doesn't matter it's about the present and the past's effect on that present there's some truly beautiful writing here heller has a gift for describing nature so that even the dead or dying landscape has an austere beauty and his characterization of hig is often very satisfying in it's obliqueness hig is an interesting guy but heller's a good enough writer to not to make him the two dimensional interesting quirky guy of a typical science fiction novel hig has thoughts and ghosts and is unsure of the what and why fore of his continued existence and he loves his dog where the novel dips comes in the last third i'm not going to risk spoilers and ruin what is for the most part a really enjoyable readable book for folks except to say that i felt the cold commercially driven hand of an editor in there more concerned with selling the film rights of the book than allowing heller to finish the work as he might have intended so that's what kept my rating down a bit so if you love apocalyptic fiction or appreciate good writing the dog stars is well worth the time it takes to read
raw_text.1499: the style of writing took a little getting used to but eventually i was going with the flow actually the first half i would rate 5 stars and the second half 3 stars i really loved the bond between the main character and his dog it was a very interesting post apocalyptic story more so since i actually live in western colorado where the story is set i could see the places he referenced in the story but mostly the whole time i was thinking about how it was like a movie and wondering who would play the main character hig the author and this book are coming next month here for a book event one book one county and i'm looking forward to hearing him speak and getting my book signed
raw_text.1500: a novel is narrated by hig one of survivors of flu pandemic who along with his dog jasper and a gun obsessed neighbour bangley has taken refuge in an abandon airport in a post catastrophic world where self protection and kill or be killed are the main thing hig wants more than that longing for human connection and life he used to live hig takes frequent trips in his cessna looking for something or someone the book is a deep and provoking exploration of human nature both terrifying and helpful for fans of dystopian novels
raw_text.1501: i am a fan of post apocalyptic fiction and i so wanted to like the dog stars i in fact still gave it 4 stars as i think the problem is with me not the book but all of that said i nearly gave up during the first half of the book because the prose was so very spare and the tale so flat and when the action as it were picked up in the 2nd half of the book i found it too predictable too formulaic and the ending by far too neat ie once i finally got the sort of happenings i preferred in the book i found it dissatisfying the entire book really was somewhat dissatisfying and yet the protagonist hig and his small world have stayed with me i've thought of him often over the past few days and all that he loved and learned about himself i think about his dog and how that devotion and then the loss opened him to the world and thereby i get to a 4 star rating on a book i wouldn't recommend to myself if i had it to do over and just smile at the mystery of the written word

raw_text.1505: after hearing only good things seeing the high reviews reading all the rave reviews i ordered the dog stars on a whim i was craving a new book and i'm a sucker for post apocalyptic drama plus it just so happens i love dogs unfortunately this book just didn't cut it for me not only was it inundated with swear words and general awkwardness it just didn't do what it promised to set out to do while there was a dog it played into the story about as much as the arabs did as in not at all sure a dog is man's best friend but to name a book after a character and a hobby that goes pretty much unmentioned unless convenient it seems a little bit like a trick and the joke is on us as readers because this book isn't about finding a new life from a returned call on a radio not directly anyway nor is it about the better or worse the main character hig encounters and what he must face as the blurb would have us believe really it's about an f word happy guy living in a sucking world and finding a pretty girl to make it suck less maybe that's what the author meant for it to be all along fine just don't string us along with the promise of some rediscovery of hope love friendship and all that it was a first person novel that in heller's defense felt very real but it wasn't anything as inspiring as all that but let's focus on the good the good writing the clever craftsmanship with which heller spins his hemingway esque prose you get into the swing of it you forget the confusion of the jumbled text unclear dialogue it feels confused and desperate just like the world heller has built and it's a terrifying world one real enough to taste imagine weep for there's little justification and no real rhyme or reason to why the people he meets or rather destroys are the way they are but that adds to the realism just not to the plot because everything that happens in this book feels jumbled messy irrelevant that makes for a great world what it does not make for is a good plot because nothing happens and nothing is concluded it's not that i was expecting a neat bow to be tied at the end on the contrary i love my endings a little messy but this whole book was nothing nothing but a way for heller to get his horrific post apocalyptic world across in realistic and hopeless detail as a story it read like a travel log of some guy desperate and broken it was well crafted in that sense but it didn't give me anything to cling to after once i finished it was forgettable because hig was forgettable because the world for all it's gory detail wasn't touching i can't say i liked it but i also can't quite say why oh wait i know why because in the end i just didn't care not about hig not about his dog and not about those barely mentioned stars either read more at my website www by its cover blogspot com
raw_text.1506: this was a solid above average read as a former semi pilot not having flown in over a year and only having achieved private pilot license means that i am very much a novice in the world of aviation i enjoyed all of the plane details really made me think about taking an instructor along and going up again soon just for the views and the disembodied detachment you get flying like the world is as perfect as a train set and nothing bad can touch you i liked hig's independence throughout the novel he is very different from bangley and pops who might be too similar and stereotypical to be real people but he never wavers in his dedication to being human in this post apocalyptic very non human environment maybe it is because he was a poet and a naturalist but i liked the softer side that he sticks with even in cold blood i was reminded of enders game maybe because i just read it this past month because the moral is similar maybe we shouldn't assume all unknowns are enemies and instead think about how to communicate with others better i wondered how hig and bangley met originally they met up after the end of the world as we know it but bangley's motto is shoot on sight never negotiate i was very curious and would have liked to hear the story of their first encounter i didn't like the religious undertones no surprise there hig is not overtly religious but he thinks about god enough to annoy me i also felt like he was a jesus rescuer for cima and pops just when they are going to have to abandon their home anyway someone comes out of the sky to save them and bring them home to his promised land a bit too annoying and then a few pages after i had this thought hig describes himself as a descending angel for the families there were two discrepancies that bothered me first hig talks about locking the plane when it is parked at the ranch just after he lands there but the window was shot out so a locked door would be useless second when he is weighing and figuring to make take off calculations which i did enjoy as i can remember looking at my poh and trying to figure minimum distances for clearance he dumps a gas can so he'd have an empty lighter can to fill with gas later but then he leaves a second full can sitting in the field my question is this why does he just leave it there why doesn't pops carry it with him on his hike to the road where they could presumably pick it up along with pops and similarly why does pops leave a whole day ahead of them to hike to the pick up spot when earlier he went out for the morning to check and confirm that the road was safe for landing and in fact if the road was that close pops could hike there for a morning's work why didn't hig land there in the first place i think that the road is in fact a day's hike away and the error lies in the scene in which pops makes it there and back in one day but i just hate these sort of discrepancies overall it was well done certainly action packed and compelling storyline but also very lyrical and poetic
raw_text.1507: lots of comparisons to the road to make about this book post apocalyptic check odd writing style check difficult to figure out who is speaking due to lack of quotation marks check people get eaten checkthe main difference for me between the dog stars and the road is that i actually enjoyed the dog stars the odd writing style didn't put me off like cormac mccarthy's does the hopelessness wasn't as hopeless and the action sequences were incredibly compelling typically i don't say i couldn't put it down about a book because well obviously i am always capable of putting a book down however there were several sequences in the book where i would have normally taken a break from reading but i kept going because i couldn't stand not knowing what was going to happen next one thing i didn't like the love story that felt unnecessary and the way it was handled was occasionally a bit much for me the flowery prose style suited much of the story but once it was applied to the romantic aspect of the story it soured it for me just a bit one bonus thing i liked the cover art which fit the style and content of the novel perfectly
raw_text.1508: i had to think about this one for awhile before writing a review it sticks with you in unexpected ways heller's descriptions of flying fishing and immersing in nature are written with the passion that can only be autobiographical your heart breaks for hig who wants to do more than just survive in post apocalyptic colorado and actually live very good
raw_text.1509: having read cormac macarthy's the road this was not unfamiliar territory for me neither in the setting nor the writing style i personally find the no puncuation style to be irritating and distracting at the beginning of the book i was particularly confused as this book opens with an immediate introduction of the three main characters and being distracted by the lack of punctuation i found myself rereading the introduction to make sure the characters were solidified in my mind of course once i was in the groove i found the story to be engaging and it read rather quickly i am very familiar with the terrain of the story having spent time in many of the book's locations i have an interest in canine human interaction and am also familiar with security techniques and the shooting and fishing arts so this book didn't leave me guessing on any elements the story is short and i might like just a little more backstory with his wife but other than one expectation at the end having not been met i was pleased with this story and would recommend it to anyone who likes colorado survival fishing dogs planes and using one's wits against the elements

raw_text.1517: i'm usually not one for post apocalyptic novels so i previewed this one first before putting it on my tbr the language on the first page drew me in and i was hooked this story of hig big hig if you want two names his dog and his neighbor bangley hig and bangley survived the flu that killed hig's wife and most of the rest of the country and they live at a small deserted airport hig owns a cessna and he and his dog jasper make reconnaissance runs during one of these runs he hears a radio transmission and wonders if there is someone else out there the trouble is that if this transmission is real the person is outside the point of no return the distance that hig can travel and have enough fuel to return yet one day he decides to take the chance knowing he may never return the language is beautiful the story is compelling and hig is a character that you'll root for from the first page this is one of my favorite books of 2012
raw_text.1518: i actually listened to this book on cd in the car but am sorry that i do not have a paper copy so i can underline some of heller's beautiful descriptions the way he wove the future with the past science and nature with humanity and how he wrote the characters was all amazing his organic descriptions were spot on and lyrical to say the least heller's description of hig's major loss was poignant moving and eloquent i loved this book the main characters and especially jasper it is nearly a 5 star book form me which i rarely if ever give out as a rating however the end seemed abrupt though still moving and it still made sense only an ambiguous ending could have worked here my complaint is that it simply ended too quickly and did not give the reader enough time to get used to the new normal of the group still very good and highly recommended a note i loved his descriptions of nature and was not surprised to find out at all that although this was heller's first novel he has nature writing which i now have on hold at the library

raw_text.1522: loved the stylized prose used by peter heller to give us the thoughts feelings and emotions of one man surviving in a post apocalyptic world sparse yet rich and quotable insights into the human spirit that apply to life today the story may superficially revolve around survival a theme admittedly that might turn some readers away yet the underlying struggle of the protagonist throughout the novel concerns how to make meaningful connections to the people around us making heller's story one that most anyone can relate good writing leaves me feeling satisfied the dog stars is the most satisfying book i've read in several years

raw_text.1528: there's a line from an old movie that when a man is young he mourns the loss of a single woman when he's old he mourns the loss of all women he mourns the loss of the concept of love in his life this book is set far enough past the apocalypse that we're for the most part past the upheaval and violence when the small groups of survivors have knuckled into their niches and spider traps and have their rituals and routines all set in place to defend themselves without thinking too much about what they have to do to survive but it is an incredibly sad story it's the story of what it takes to get out of bed every morning after the end of the world and justify your life in the face of grief and guilt and despair of the people you loved and all the people you didn't and oh you have to kill people rather methodically to suffer along well written ends on a moment of peace which it hints is about to be rather disturbed in the sequel

raw_text.1538: i am in love with this book just when i was beginning to think that the post apocalyptic story was tired and a bit overdone tho wonderful little gem fell into my lap and boy what a story what a refreshing point of view one review that i read for this book said if you liked cormac mccarthy's 'the road' you will love this book if you didn't like 'the road' you will still love this book like the road the narration style of this book is unique i'm not going to lie it took me a bit to get used to the way it was written and up until a significant event about a third of the way through i wasn't fully committed to the story but i am glad that i stuck with it the main character is so complex and his relationships to other characters both on the page and told in flashback were very memorable and some of the situation and setting descriptions were so powerful and intense that i will be thinking about them for quite some time this is one book i would highly recommend

raw_text.1544: lukewarm start that really picked up after the first 50 pages and turned into a rousing intimate suspenseful novel set in the end of the world genre it seems a super virus has taken out 99 of the population in the world and those that are left are few yet looking to get food weapons etc etc you know the usual sort of things that people want in a post apocalyptic sort of setting two men are holed up at an airport in colorado and they have plenty of food water and weapons but one man hears a message on the radio while flying his plane and goes off on a quest to find that voice both their lives will be endangered if he does it the dog stars is a pretty gripping take on the end of the world genre it's no the road but what is i do wish that heller would have used quotes when people were talking that always kinds of annoys me cormac does that too dialogue kind of blurs into the thoughts of people and you have to sometimes separate what is being said and what is being thought it takes a bit of time to get used to that stylistic choice by heller but overall this is a quality first novel that i read in less than two days over a holiday weekend

raw_text.1561: spoiler alert this review is almost all about the last third of the book after reading countless reviews i was surprised no one else had commented on the shift in hig between the first two thirds and the last third of the book for me it went from i'm a grieving widower haunted by the memory of my dead wife whom i loved more than anyone and my only comfort in this post apocalyptic hellscape is my dog flying and the sounds and smells of nature to ahhh ooo ga hubba hubba a working vagina i'm still sad but it's way better now that i know i'm going to get laid on the regular and there's a woman can fill the void left by my dead dog hig's character is completely ruined for me in the third book he's still sort of the compassionate reluctant survivor we've come to know and if not necessarily love at least sympathize with but as soon as a little estrogen is thrown into the equation he becomes a horny macho man who decides to repress the memories of all that before stuff he dwelled on before he found another consenting female in the world i could probably forgive him this flaw since i recognize my desire for hig to stay true to the memory of his wife as sentimental if heller had given cima the living breathing assembly of yummy mounds more than a speck of agency but he didn't sure cima initiates the sexual relationship between hig and herself which is an important detail since most women who survived were presumably raped and murdered but other than that she's not much more than a physical manifestation of the landscape hig admires plants his seed in hunts on slash jasper's replacement she's frail because she barely survived the flu and she bruises so easily that they have to put their love making on hold for a couple of days because of how banged up she gets when he's on top you'd expect cima to be a bad ass considering the fact that she's a brilliant doctor immunologist actually how convenient tough country rancher who is perhaps even more well versed in loss than old hig but when they survey the ruins of grand junction and almost get murdered she's too in shock to leave the plane but she doesn't need to keep her wits about her when there are two strong men who can take care of everything right she'll contribute to their survival later when someone needs a caretaker when bangley first sees her he assumes she's mrs hig and a laughing cima responds dr hig to you i know they've finally found another person after nine years of miserable loneliness etc but after just six weeks she's ready to symbolically renounce her own identity to become an extension of our protagonist who with his wonderfully still functioning wanger yeah he actually calls it that once is able to pull some of the pieces of his twice shattered life back together after the unfortunate but timely death of his best friend jasper i give it two stars for the first two books alone other than that hig just reinforces the idea that in the end we're all just base animals doing what we need to do to live another day and his constant struggle to differentiate himself the poet from that innate violent desire i e bangley falls short how is that supposed to be an uplifting chapter in the world of literary dystopia

raw_text.1570: it's sometimes hard to separate the life of an author from his her works this was certainly true of james joyce norman mailer and ernest hemingway and heller's tale here is of that tradition it's a dystopian tale of survival following a worldwide apocalypse it's not however as bleak as cormac mccarthy's the road as heller's post apocalyptic world tends equally toward human compassion and caring as much as it's about survival the first person protagonist is simply called hig a man who lost his wife and unborn child to a plague of human making and he now lives with a survivalist named bangley the contrast between the two men couldn't be more glaring in this world survival is paramount and bangley is more than up to the task he's loaded with guns makes grenades and other armaments and doesn't blink an eye at killing interlopers even children hig on the other hand can kill but it's far from easy he's a pilot who makes reconnaissance flights to help inform bangley and he raises a garden and cooks and keeps a pretty tidy place it's hardly an aside but halfway through the book hig leaves his colorado airport haven in search of what he doesn't know he comes upon a father and his grown daughter in an idyllic valley and after quite a hard time of convincing pops that he comes in peace he helps the pair leave this edenic place for what they aren't sure this book is hardly the normal story of the apocalyptic genre it's almost a biblical parable of the finer and baser human instincts these forever coexisting as well it's a replay of the biblical exit from eden these remaining scraps of humanity thrown into the unknown and hopefully finding a certain peace that perhaps wasn't present in the closeted world they left behind heller's writing here is excellent there's humor albeit often of the darker sort and through hig heller informs us of the hows and whys of human strengths and frailties

raw_text.1575: now here's a book i could take to a desert island with me here's a book that tugged at my senses my heart and my mind and seduced me to keep reading it until i finished once i finished i wished i was still reading it the book is the dog stars by peter heller mr heller is a kayaker a man who wrote about fly fishing who wandered the streams rivers and mountains of the american west and other places where nature calls out to men and many women also he has contributed stories to npr and has written about his treks in periodicals like outside magazine and national geographic adventure this is his first novel and it's a story that makes sense in terms of heller's life and his previous work we have a post apocalyptic world this one a result of a pandemic of flu a mutation of bird flu perhaps which is followed in many people with no genetic protection by an affliction of the blood something like aids and passed from person to person in similar ways the world is also in the midst of its response to decades of global warming and climate change it is a world of out of whack seasons which are wreaking havoc on animals plants water drought and therefore on mankind it is a world that is not safe a world where desperate people wander america and kill anyone with resources that they can consume or who are infected with some sort of blood lust that leads them to kill and eat the healthy humans they encounter bangley hig and jasper have banded together near a suburb in colorado because it used to be home and they have found it expedient each seems to have skills that complement those of the other actually bangley is a taciturn strict survivalist with a huge weapons collection and hig once the husband of his beloved melissa is a pilot who lives in the nearby hanger at the small airport home of private planes now ruined by wind and weather except for hig's cesna which he keeps in top condition there is plenty of gas available and although regular gas has timed out and can no longer be used as fuel airplane fuel is proving to have a longer viable life span jason is hig's dog a dog who helps bangley and hig defend their little domain and who helps hig hunt and fish bangley and hig have built a tower from which to keep a lookout for intruders and there are intruders bangley insisted they build this tower and he insisted that it be built in a certain way hig flies his plane on frequent excursions to get away from the single minded bangley and to keep an eye on the "perimeter" as bangley demands he also brings back the occasional cases of soda for himself bangley and for the small mennonite community a community whose member have the blood affliction and are therefore given a wide berth by predators bangley hates that hig visits the mennonites he feels that it puts them in danger of attack and of contracting the blood affliction even though they keep a safety zone which hig never violates bangley is all survivalist all the time hig is never welcome in bangley's home or even in his workshop without an appointment but bangley likes to act in a mildly threatening manner towards hig at all times keeping him unnerved and wary even popping up behind him in the hangar where he now lives without any warning whatsoever bangley stresses the importance of being able to take that "kill" shot without hesitation he has his work cut out for him with hig an ex contractor who actually wanted to be a poet hig does not like to kill first and ask questions later he likes to give intruders time in order to see if there is any humanity left in them bangley assumes that all humans are predators and he believes that hig will get them killed because he is "soft" they have an uncertain and somewhat hostile alliance bangley is the head and hig is the heart and the contrast between them works well in the novel in the world that was hig a social being had the better survival skills and bangley would have been the fringe loner in this post pandemic world it is unclear whether hig could survive without bangley the other character in this story is nature nature which is unspooling into draught and desert through climate change which continues unabated by depopulation peter heller makes us love an america that is so beautiful and which gives us cycles of seasons and bird migrations and fish migrations and insect migrations and water cycles involving snow falling on mountains and then spring melt roaring down to replenish streams rivers and lakes he gives us his memories of trout fishing which haunt him now that the trout are gone he makes us feel as if we ourselves are in imminent danger of losing all the rare and wonderful beauty of nature as it unfolds in america and ironically although not quite as powerfully as for hig et al we are in danger of losing it all he makes us miss the america we didn't even lose yet there is a lot more to this story don't worry i didn't reveal everything follow hig out in his plane when he goes to look for someone he heard on his radio while flying one time this story gets even better peter heller wrote a very good book
raw_text.1576: heavy stuff this book main character higg is trying to navigate the new world after the apocalypse both literally and figuratively in the flu pandemic he lost his wife and unborn child and now calls an airport hangar home when the book begins he has entered into an uneasy partnership with a man he does not exactly like the only things he has left that are dear to him are his dog jasper and his cessna airplane the beast he spends his days flying the perimeter of the compound to check for marauders and catching fish in what's left of the mountain streams however something is clearly missing from higg's life and not just those he lost in apocalypse eventually higg leaves the airport in search of something higg does not seem to know what he is searching for but it was clear to me he went in search of his humanity it is hard to say more without including spoilers but i liked the way the book ended i listened to this on audio book and very much loved the narrator's voice however the first 40% or so really dragged picking up pace once higg left the airport i really enjoyed the last half of the book and would recommend it to anyone who likes this genre

raw_text.1586: this book is so damn good its minor missteps really annoyed me set in a post apocolyptic colorado it follows the inner thoughts and actions of a poetic and rugged survivor sometimes the writing channels hemingway which i mean in the best way imagine big two hearted river but with a dog here is a rugged and violent landscape but its very familiarity means hig sees every hill and river as emblems of nostalgia and loss dwelling on these feelings is impossible in more than glimpses however because lethal threats hide around every corner my quibbles the nature writing goes on too long sometimes there is little suspense and less narrative in landscape a character falls asleep at a moment in which no human being would ever do so purely to fit the needs of the plot but the main thing is heller's decision not to use quotation marks when cormac mccarthy does this the reader always knows exactly who is speaking with this book not even close often i had to stop midscene to parse it out sometimes heller even had his narrator do it too making sure we knew he thought something but didn't say it if it sounds somewhat amateurish you're right especially in a book that otherwise shows such high craft these stumbles detract only slightly from a novel that otherwise is compelling lyrical full of toughness and heart sudden and vivid violence precise language and well evoked characters the protective papa who's a former seal is so skillfully rendered i know what he smells like the story's finish gave the thing i least expected a happy ending missteps aside this is a fine novel and definitely worth a read
