raw_text.1591: i don't know what mystic elements have been guiding my reading choices but i think this is the fourth peter heller book i have bought and read i think that the choice to read each and every one of them went something like this i am standing in a bookstore alright i am clicking through amazon thinking "duh what the hell should i read " i walk around i pick up faulkner "well that's not going to happen " i put it back on one of nora roberts's many shelves hoping that somebody will buy it by mistake i walk around some more "hmm what's this a post apocalyptic story about a man a dog and airplane that's gotta be good plus the cover is dark blue " i take it home crack it open and tear through it about half way through it i stop and i realize "this could have been better " i turn to the spine and look at the author peter heller then i finish it this is my experience of peter heller in general and the dog stars his only fiction i have read in particular i think that on some mystical level i keep choosing his books because i kind of want his life he was on whale wars enough said he surfed in the baja he worked for outdoor magazine and he wrote a book about a post apocalyptic nightmare and got it published aaawesome and don't get me wrong i am not jealous i am not a life prude i've done some stuff but his stuff is cool too and it makes me reflective and so i buy his books because i stumbled upon them and they look awesome but and the 'but' has been looming i don't think he is that good of a writer sorry dude the dog star is overly terse the ending a love story is kind of boring and the post apocalyptic nightmare is kind of like farming while living in west oakland i enjoyed it and i will buy his next book but it's definitely not one of the best things i have read
raw_text.1592: the dog starsthis book is beautifully powerfully written in a fragmentary quotation mark less style that emphasises the feeling of post apocalypse of the slow withering of one's own language and culture of the narrowing of one's world view into something that contains only oneself unfortunately the plot beneath the words failed to hold my interest while the story itself is not without interest i have a weak spot for post apocalyptic and survivalist settings it felt as though heller has taken what would have been a very good short story and then stretched it out to make a novel of it a rather short novel but still the result is a book that sets up its characters and premise very well and manages to evoke some feeling and then falters becomes needlessly repetitive and stagnant i'm sure there is a reason for this choice of pacing perhaps even a good one but it failed to deliver at least as far as i'm concerned in summary not without merit but far too stretched out for my liking

raw_text.1647: i really really liked this book and if i hadn't just read the road by cormac mccarthy i think i would have loved it the plot is a good one and i loved the characters their post apocalyptic world is not so bleak it's beautiful and a place of self sufficiency and possibilities i loved the setting in particular i spent a formative 6 weeks in colorado in college and peter heller took me back there with vivid precision his descriptions of colorado's wilderness are perfectly on the nose even soothing in a strange way the only drawback to this book is that it was stylistically so derivative of the road it kind of made me crazy reading it the choppy fragmented somewhat stream of consciousness prose the dialogue without quotation marks even a reference to carrying the fire i'm sure peter heller was intending to pay homage to one of the definitive works in the genre and maybe this is just his writing style anyway but it felt too similar too soon for me to the point of being a distraction otherwise a great book

raw_text.1674: cormac mccarthy's the road has invariably been mentioned in much of the write ups and interviews with peter heller concerning the dog stars and indeed the fisherman in heller may have took to heart one particular passage in the post apocalyptic novel and sat down to write his own for the amateur aviator dog lover fisherman or otherwise apocalypse enthusiast heller's book sets itself apart by refusing to acknowledge a future of dread without happiness or a world now void of people without moments of humanity however rare heller's enthusiasm for the outdoors and past writings for the national geographic come into play often and he proves himself to be a great writer of landscapes and full of practical knowledge for surviving the end of humanity he writes in a flow of consciousness style that may drive some crazy but lends itself well to a book about what must be a troubled man trying his hardest to maintain in the end times that man is hig early on he confesses himself a lover of poetry and also a bit of a poet himself of which he suffers the normal trappings of a romantic this is interesting considering the world around him his more practical skill and the one to which he most likely owes his survival is aviation the first and very memorable lines establish this and his current home at a small airfield in colorado along with hig lives his loyal dog and a gun nut bangley who may very well be heller's caricature of those crazy bastards on tv collecting ammo guns and supplies for the impending apocalypse let's hope their prediction is not self fulfilling the poet and the gun nut trapped together in the apocalypse without law makes for quite a pair and an opportunity for insight into the nature of man who is better suited for this new world or do both need each other a repeating radio signal having long driven hig mad with curiosity sets the story in motion and causes many more vexing questions is that very curiosity integral to hig's sanity something about the concept of apocalypse in general either makes a book brilliant or campy but maybe i'm just a sucker for the sub genre like the road it's a page turner heller has some trouble maintaining the consistency of the style in the beginning but finds his legs hig's reluctance to confront some of the realities of the world are charming and ultimately makes the book but at times it's unbelievable none of these faults bring it down to anything less than a good book however i have read several of heller's articles and after reading this book wrote him this past summer he wrote back a short while later answered many of my questions and offered some advice told me of his unique approach to writing he said always stop in the middle of a thought scene etc so i can't wait to get started the next day definitely an interesting approach and one i had never thought of he is a genuinely good person and one funny dude can't wait to read his next book

raw_text.1695: the world in peter heller's the dog stars is a lonely place a virus has decimated the us population in a small airport in colorado hig along with his dog jasper and fellow resident bangley persists he sleeps outdoors with jasper snuggled on his leg he flies his cessna around on patrols once a day playing through loudspeakers that anyone who comes near the airport will be killed sometimes he helps bangley enforce this death sentence they don't trust any of the few other survivors who come near the airport hig hunts and fishes he flies to a nearby mennonite village to visit and deliver sprite but keeps his distance signs up warn that they have the blood three years ago while flying hig picked up someone on the radio at the grand junction airport events in his life make him want to fly out now why bangley wants to know what do you want that's the most important question of the book it drives the narrative hig is alive almost without reason he loves nature and poetry he's not cold enough to be the sort of relentless killer bangley is he may not have survived to this point ten years after the virus hit if it weren't for bangley's outlook but what is he doing surviving what does he want to continue living for the story answers the question satisfactorily heller's writing conveys his own love of nature i confess to skimming his descriptions on occasion i wanted to get back to the action he also writes skillfully from the first person perspective of someone who's been mostly alone for a decade hig's thoughts wander and sometimes it's hard to tell if you're in the present or past but it's not confusing for long dialog is not indicated in any way and this is useful at points in the story for showing hig's mind if you enjoy nature writing and outdoor survival or end of the world stories with a human slant like the age of miracles or the road you might see what you think of the dog stars

raw_text.1702: peter heller is something of a mystery to me the man can clearly write and this book contains some beautiful descriptive passages and the occasional line that begged to be reread and felt like it belonged to or had been stolen from a far better book but then he decides to set his poetic prose in a post apocalyptic america yawn and write it with so little punctuation that the reader and occasionally the book's characters are unsure who is speaking or thinking at any given time once you get over the bizarre and totally unnecessary style you find that the characters are actually a bit thin and you don't care if they survive or not the plot itself seems to realise this and so half way through goes cross country in a plane to find new characters it picked up pace towards the end but the whole affair smacks of a talented writer crowbarring a disjointed medley of musings into a hurried and childish story in order to get published a few superb passages that i wish i'd read in a poetry anthology about the countryside in a style whose motivation was more apparent
raw_text.1703: i was far more intrigued by the events leading up to hig's departure than by the events that followed it his changing relationship with his neighbor as that character is gradually fleshed out as more than just a stereotype was pleasantly surprising his struggles with what it means to be a compassionate human in a post apocalyptic world as he's faced with challenges both natural and man made are the best parts of the novel after he departs from his home base i found the plot and characters becoming a little too cliched to fully appreciate view spoiler the plot line with cima though poetic at times reduced the book to a happy ending through sudden romance rather than a happy ending through self realization or happy ending through deepening relationships the latter are harder won but would have felt more natural and rewarding hide spoiler

raw_text.1707: i really enjoyed this story which looks at the world post an apocalyptic event it's not filled with zombies and radioactive fallout though the world is different as a result of disease and a suggestion of mankind's misuse the author never really explains the main catalysts for the current state other than a blood disease killing people and the abuse of natural resources the story follows one man's life as a survivor immune to the catastrophic disease and how he his dog and his plane make do
raw_text.1708: for a book with so many things i typically don't like i ended up enjoying this quite a bit there was a lot about airplanes which i wasn't really expecting but found interesting my husband is a private pilot and we do a lot of flying so i'm familiar with the cessnas runways flight calculations etc it did take a little while to become invested in the book but once i did i raced through it dystopia usually too bleak for me but heller's world felt real and captivating instead of everything being completely desolate we got to see the changes little by little little hopes lost daily made it a more personal experience content swearing sex there's really only one sex scene but i tend to think that sex scenes are in general gratuitous or even a detractor from the story at hand this one wasn't as bad as it could have been and maybe even more part of the plot and character development than most there was swearing throughout but then i figured that was probably pretty accurate the world is falling apart you probably swear a lot more than usual right no quotations dialogue tags and very choppy sentences i listened to most of this on audio so it didn't really bug me i finished reading with my physical copy and my brain definitely didn't do as good of a job reading as the audio narrator but i'd gotten enough into the swing of it at that point that everything was good
raw_text.1709: this is my first review for goodreads and it's because i feel so strongly about the beauty that is peter heller's novel i re read books often but never do i finish a book and go right back to the beginning and start over immediately but that's what i have to do with the dog stars it is just that good once i got over the ragged punctuation the perfect rhythm of the writing came through this book reads like an easy conversation the style might not be for everyone but it was definitely good for me

raw_text.1722: this was probably a 3 5 star book but i had to make a choice so i rounded up the dog stars follows the life of hig and bangley two survivors of the worldwide flu epidemic and the blood disease that followed as they cope with life after they are an unlikely pair hig is still human wanting to give the stragglers who wander into their orbit a chance before shooting them he has a dog that he loves and also takes care of a mennonite family nearby who are slowly dying of blood disease bangley is older and hard as nails he appears to know nothing about using his hands except for making and fixing guns and he has an encyclopedic knowledge of military strategy and weaponry and explosives he never rests never stops looking for stragglers to shoot he and hig have a sort of post apocalyptic family though hig never really knows when he will become a liability for bangley so he keeps one eye open in case he should become the next straggler in bangley's eyes hig was a carpenter a fisherman a gardner a man of all trades who lived with his wife near denver he and bangley occupy an airport where hig a pilot hunts fishes and scouts the surrounding area for intruders in his old cessna so you know where this is going their idyllic life is changed suddenly choices have to be made life such as it has become goes on this is not a challenging book but occasionally the writing which is in hig's voice becomes tiresome or even unintelligible you see hig had the flu he sustained a 105 degree fever but it left his brain somewhat fried and not all his thoughts are complete the love stories are wonderful and warm and the ending was satisfying to me at least i would recommend this book as light reading with some wonderful insights on humanity that kind of sneak up in between the very engaging story

raw_text.1726: it's pretty rare that i find myself picking up a book about an apocalypse way too many shows and movies with zombie apocalypses and whatnot but this book caught my eye at the bookstore split into three parts this story follows hig a pilot whose post apocalyptic life has become living in fear haunted by memories of his deceased wife and taking lives of predators without thinking twice the death of hig's dog jasper and a near death experience pushes him over the edge and he decides to leave the security of the life he has built over the last nine years in search of something more even if he has no idea what it is i really liked reading this book because the live hig is leading after the apocalypse really seems secondary to his battling of inner demons and is a great way to show that any kind of routine can become monotonous by opening himself up hig finds a way to move on from the horror of 'the end' and what he left behind and find comfort in the new world of circumstance that is created around him definitely worth a read

raw_text.1753: the dog stars is technically a post apocalyptic book though it rarely goes into the kinds of details that you often find in those kinds of books there was a flu pretty much everybody died the world has moved on as stephen king might say and humanity with it hig's a nice enough guy who has killed men and women and children but hey at least he's not as bad as his friend bangley who seems to revel in those acts as they defend their little fiefdom of an airport that last bit is important because hig knows how to fly planes and does so it's a device that allows peter heller to forgo some of the typical wandering of the genre and get to business quicker it also of course sets up some nice metaphors late in the book hig describes flying like being in a painting moving quickly but without much sign of velocity it's what has happened in the nine years since everybody died the first half or so of this book is about loss there's little point in making new friends when they will inevitably try to kill you everything you've loved is gone except for maybe your trusty dog later hig goes out exploring trying to find a signal from years ago it's hope really but a blind hope which is the only kind that can exist anymore all is loss until he comes across a father and daughter holed up in a secluded canyon it's here that the book finds its real purpose as hig becomes a person again he interacts with real people that have real emotions though they hide theirs as much as he hides his for fear of that constant loss heller uses nature perfectly here twinning the natural beauty with that of the woman he meets cim wonderful stuff excellently realized through hig's clipped meter how idyllic and sad a place can be at the same time other things happen of course and the action scenes such as they are work surprisingly well for a book with the literary bona fides displayed throughout the rest of the text but it's that middle third that makes this book work and shows us that even among great loss hope can still exist
raw_text.1754: on the scale of post apocalyptic novels this one is very high on scientific realism no zombies just flu and disease and very good estimates of what would and wouldn't work after a decade of neglect very high on the depravity of man one must be absolutely ruthless again and again and very high on poetry oh and it may be the best written example of the genre i've read in terms of both description and psychology makes you really think through what that if you were the last person on earth phrase would imply and the long impact of devastation even for the survivors i don't want to give away too much other than that it's intense and well written but i didn't quite connect the way i did with age of miracles maybe someone who's more into dogs flying and the outdoors would connect better it's also not half as gentle as age of miracles this is walking dead style intensity i understand why it was a staff pick at my local library but it doesn't make the cut for me just for personal reasons i don't really control yet there's three or four moments phrases that are just crystalline perfect one involving the book of lamentations and ultimately i genuinely like what peter heller does with the story compared to all the other examples out there of the genre high quality writing and you may like it even more than i did if you have a dog maybe

raw_text.1758: i had high expectations for this book due to the reviews i think it was pretty good but wouldn't rank it as highly as many have the dog stars is a post apocalyptic book about a man named hig who struggles to survive and find meaning with what's left of his life in the middle of nowhere with a crazy neighbor a loyal dog and a small airplane i almost stopped reading this in the beginning because i hated the writing style and found it so distracting i'll all for different writing styles but not when it hinders the reading process and here i kept stumbling over odd sentence fragments instead of adding to the reading experience it interrupted it this did improve as i got further into the book but i found that anytime i had to put the book down it took a while to get back into the writing when i started up again it's not the best post apocalyptic book i've read and i didn't find any deep meaning or amazing can't forget characters but in the end i'm glad i pushed through because i enjoyed the book overall

raw_text.1770: this is fabulous on audiobook the reader is terrific highly recommended other reviewers have said the written style drove them nuts so i'm glad i read this on audio our reliable narrator is hig a steady normal guy who worked as a contractor loved his wife was going to be a father loves his dog loves to go fishing and hunting and be in the outdoors now he's getting by at an airfield in kansas one of the few survivors of a pandemic flu he has help from bangley another survivor who has hig's back and vice versa the whole book is hig just thinking and talking to himself as he goes about daily life doing the things he has to do hig's descriptions drew me in i was moved by his language when he's being thoughtful lyrical poetic often he's matter of fact and sometimes he's freaked out comparing his 'now' with 'before before ' as any human would be i liked this book quite a bit it's like a less brutal the road crossed with the little prince as much for the aviation lovingly detailed which i enjoyed as for the optimism hig rarely loses i'm loathe to write more about it i wouldn't have wanted to know anything that was going to happen walking alongside hig as he lives his life is the only way i'd want to learn how things work out he's a reliable narrator and i care about him fuckin' hig as bangley would say and i wish him well

raw_text.1772: originally posted at my blog here it's a dystopian world out there and there are few survivors most of the world's population and wildlife having succumbed to a fatal flu those that remain remain only because they are hardy and resourceful or because they have "the blood" and nobody can come near them for risk of infection our hero is big hig who has lost wife and unborn child to the flu he survives because he has combined forces with terse neighbor bruce bangley to keep the predators at bay one day after one more unexpected loss hig in desperation decides to fly out in his cessna beyond the point of no return - the point at which he would not have enough fuel to get back - to find other survivors hig's story because that is what "dog stars" is boils down to one main idea - that of hope even after devastating loss in dire desolation and faced with lonely reality hope survives hig must chance the one thing left to him - his life - to justify that emotion this is a magnificent novel and an uplifting read highly recommended

raw_text.1774: the dog stars is a book about postapocalypse and many many other things as well this is a book about survival about friendship about flight about fishing and essentially about human needs the dog stars offers one of a kind story while most of postapocalyptic stories i've read present wandering characters travelers adventurers or nomads this book took a slightly different path hig the protagonist along with jasper the dog and bangley his neighbor were the few survivors left on earth after a worldwide flu pandemic wiped out the population unlike other postapocalypse wanderers hig and bangley camped on a fixed post they sheltered themselves in an airport hangar so that they can protect themselves and their food supply and a cessna plane from raiders and looters this was a sensible strategy traumatic events like disaster or apocalypse are emotionally devastating people who've been hit by disaster usually reserved their energy for a more basic needs taking trip far and wide isn't one of them human is a homeostatic creature we form refuge we build shelters we seek counseling or social support we create stability among chaos took a quest for a grand adventure is a much more later urgency in short after a traumatic event we're most likely to prevent ourselves from getting traumatized again instead of taking risks and exposing ourselves to more danger that's where the dog stars hit the spot the book depicts humanity in best way possible human is a complex creature whose needs aren't only biological but also psychological hig and bangley had their biological needs covered they got food and water they got security in form of bangley's deadly arsenal they got clothings and shelter but they still lack some fulfillment stripped away from daily occupations and activities from the wealth and prestige all human actually crave the same needs the most basic need for every social animal out there is to connect with other people hig found social support in the form of a loyal dog jasper and a gun nuts neighbor bangley by any standard these two would never be sufficient but this is all he got but again isolation is a painful friend to have to cope with all of the losses and tragedies hig chose to fly away from the airport he's been living in for 9 years he flew to find yet another soul another person who could fill his lonely days he flew to search for a meaning and ultimately to become human once again the dog stars is a truly moving story this is by far the most humane post apocalyptic story i've read the way it reflects humanity is unparalleled though the stream of consciousness writing style seems odd at first i promise myself to reread the dog stars again and again

first book pretty much ripped me apart and without giving it away i feel that i can relate well to it at this point in my life...i absolutely loved the end of this part part two of the book is decent albeit a bit forgettable part three is just what this book needs to make it work as a complete tale in part three i was blown away by the way that heller pulled the pieces together and changed this book from what could have been a bit too perfect and too cute of a story line considering these peoples circumstances and made into something more some are comparing this book to cormac mccarthy's the road and that is unfair on both of them they are very different books my favorite thing about this book is how out of nowhere it would become incredibly poetic and outright profound these passages are amazing unexpected and damn it they just work one passage that i chose really reflects on what i am talking about there are many more "when you walk you propel it forward when you let go the sled and sit on a fallen log and you imagine him curling beside you in the one patch of sun maybe lying over your feet not feeling so well then it sits with you the pain puts its arm over your shoulders it is your closest friend steadfast and at night you can't bear to hear your own breath unaccompanied by another and underneath the big stillness like a score is the roaring of the cataract of everything being and being torn away then the pain is lying beside your side close does not bother you with the sound even of breathing "a fantastic read that will sit well with you long after you finish it a top 2012 read for me

raw_text.1798: the dog stars post apocalyptic vision of the future is reminiscent of cormac mccarthy's the road however in this book the apocalypse is caused by a violent flu outbreak that leaves most the population dead the main character hig a pilot lives at an airpark in erie colorado with his macho friend and his dog jasper together they are mostly able to protect themselves from the violent people they encounter this book has particular relevance to me as i lived in an airpark in brighton co about 30 miels east of erie in high school i can therefore easily imagine the settings and the scenes as hig flies over the neighboring countryside teh book is written very poetically heller has both an mfa in prose and poetry from the iowa writer's workshop the language is terse often with incomplete sentences but surprisingly rich and readable given its sparseness this book may be associated with science fiction but it really isn't this is a very possible and very realistic version of a possible future just a few years away which is what gives the novel much of its power

raw_text.1830: from my newsletter number 44 this review is on the dog stars by peter heller a highly acclaimed best seller according to many reviewers it was released in august 2012 after reading the road by cormac mccarthy twice i realized i had been anxiously waiting for the paperback version to come out the ebook version was only one dollar cheaper so i bought the book the story starts out with a guy named hig his dog jasper and his airplane called the beast they are all situated at a small country airport in colorado hig has one neighbor a guy named bruce bangley together they protect an eight mile radius around the airport i mean they kill anyone who attempts to approach them day or night as many have over the last nine years since the flu epidemic wiped out 99 percent of the human population hig and bangley are survivors and they mean to stay that way hig flies his plane every day or so with jasper checking the perimeter of the airport to make sure no one is sneaking up on them hig also hunts and fishes bangley is the survivalist type and an expert rifleman he shoots to kill they are a team and they depend on each other for their lives on one flight hig hears a voice on a radio broadcast from another airport maybe grand junction which is too far away to fly on a full tank of fuel years pass and the terrible things hig and bangley must do to stay alive finally drives hig to find that person who may have survived and help ease the loneliness and despair of just trying to stay alive the journey proves to be more eventful than hig anticipated the writing style is similar to the road in that there are no quotation marks in the dialog to identify when one is speaking this causes some confusion to the reader especially when emotions are running high and you are trying to decide if the characters are speaking or not many of the sentences are written in fragments or incomplete thoughts you could say the writer uses poor grammar and would not be wrong however i am sure it was done on purpose to heighten the emotions and develop the characters in a more meaningful way it actually gets better as the story progresses peter heller ensnares you completely into a world gone awry where people are just trying to survive day by day and find hope where none seems to exist in comparison to the road this book has more enduring characters with emotional attachments on a very personal level in the end you actually feel that things will get better over time i give this book four stars because it is a story about love endurance and hope in a cruel and deadly environment very thought provoking you will remember the characters in this story i look forward to reading more novels by this author don viecelli

raw_text.1840: this book is messy confusing but ultimately worth the read or listen as it was in my case hig sees himself as a poet a could have been high school english teacher who simply cannot let the apocalypse separate him from the freedoms he enjoyed he hunts in the mountains fishes but ultimately he finds freedom in his 90 year old cessna which he uses to fetch cokes care for an ailing clan of mennonites and protect the perimeter of the compound he shares with bagley who isn't a poet who adores guns and who basically looks out for hig ultimately hig will take a desperate gamble fly not only beyond the perimeter but also beyond the distance where he has enough fuel to return he will find two people that he doesn't kill at first sight and he will even fall in love with one of them if you loved reading cormac mccarthy's the road then i have to say that this novel is 25% as good as that one that' isn't necessarily a bad thing but whenever heller's narrative touches on elements in mccarthy's masterpiece it fails there is coca cola the bad guys even the stripped houses they are key elements of the plot but not ones that come anywhere close to the quality or the depth of the road while the apocalypse in dog stars stems from a flu virus i enjoyed the way that heller wove other threats into the narrative climate change plays a role here as well as the population movements of poor arabian countries into modern western ones unfortunately a lot of issues that hig carries aren't fleshed out until he meets sima about 2 3rd of the way through the book the most perplexing issue to me was the 'shoot on sight' law by which hig u0026amp bagley lure wanderers to a house on the airstrip that they share and murder them the reason for this behavior isn't clear at first and it seemed more like target practice for the gun loving bagley

raw_text.1853: like the road the dog stars tells a story of the struggles of the few after a cataclysmic event that seems to have left most of the world dead and what remained of the world hard desperate bloodthirsty unlike mccarthy's book heller's has about it a certain but thankfully not overdone whimsy an occasional glimmer of humor it's a lovely book written in spare but often somehow also lyrical prose heller is apparently more well known for his nonfiction but i hope he writes a few more novels the book is not without its missteps the sudden ease with which pops and hig fall into a rhythm and a camaraderie as they storm the grand junction airport is a little out of step with the pace of their relationship so far but then again desperate circumstances are probably a catalyst aunt b and uncle jesse at that airport are enough of a surprise that they invite questions that only distract from the otherwise pretty smooth arc of the story give us characters out of deliverance here instead it's ok that we've seen similar characters already within the story and the settling of hard old bangley his ready acceptance of pops as a sort of surrogate father feels a little convenient heller who cites infinite jest as the protagonist's favorite book should feel comfortable enough leaving the odd end hanging loose the tail end doesn't really work for me heller has written a lovely enough thing himself that he need not deflate it by ending with somebody else's poem still it's a really good book that i'm grateful to have had recommended to me i imagine it's one i'll read again

raw_text.1859: in this day and age it seems that post apocalyptic novels must involve zombies or vampires or some similar species of the undead at the core of the plot the dog stars is a welcome change of pace in heller's impressive first novel the focus of the story is hig a survivor of a plague that has apparently decimated upward of 99% of the world's population in his former life hig was a contractor a private pilot an avid fisherman and a happily married man now he narrates a tale of a philosopher carrying on in the face of utter loss living at a small airstrip in rural colorado with one other man his eccentric survivalist neighbor bangley and his beloved dog jasper hig still fishes and hunts but his favored trout are gradually disappearing from the streams and lakes near his home he struggles with memories of his wife a victim of the plague he flies supplies to a group of mennonite survivors who are contending with other health problems and then one day while patrolling near his home in his cessna he picks up a fragmentary radio transmission apparently coming from the grand junction airport past his point of no return heller's tale is almost poetic conveying all of the love and respect that the author feels for the outdoors the writing is very reminiscent of cormac mccarthy's the road but far less pessimistic in its setting and its outcomes even in the spare journal like style of the writing the reader gets a real feeling for the characters and their personalities even the strange bangley it is simultaneously a poignant funny and at times harrowing book if you're tired of the typical end of the world gore fest this one is a refreshing alternative

raw_text.1863: 3 1 2 stars the writing style reminded me a bit of george sauders because of the clipped sentence fragments and a bit of the walled city portions of hard boiled wonderland and the end of the world it very much reads like the first novel of a graduate of the iowa writer's workshop which it is in that it's overengineered i read a lot of post apocalyptic fiction and the dog stars had one of the bleakest views of humanity since the road view spoiler most post apocalyptic novels at least show some hand wave towards people trying to re form society and relationships but like the road in this book's view kill and ask questions later is the only way to survive given the world of the book it doesn't make any sense there don't seem to be significant enough resource shortages to make people fight over them and if the marauders are skilled enough to kill other people they'd surely be skilled enough to kill game as i was reading the book i was thinking of a recent this american life episode where a soldier confesses the horror of discovering that a number of the people who enlisted with him did so because they wanted a societally sanctioned reason to kill another human at times it felt like this author was going out of his way to make the world he created one where he could have his characters kill with impunity and make it exciting while washing his hands of the moral uncertainty the enemies that are dispatched are often cartoonishly evil and seem inauthentic hide spoiler

raw_text.1872: a double disease pandemic decimates the population in the near future and the survivors have been brutalized by their actions to survive nearly a decade after things fell apart the main character hig his dog jasper and quiet veteran bangley have fortified a small airport and eek out a life dreading both strangers and their memories of before the catastrophe and during besides flying and helping some diseased mennonites the only solace is the occassional hunting and fishing trip outside their perimeter until hig starts thinking about a faint radio message from a distant airfield and starts wondering if he should explore this should appeal to fans of the road or even the time traveller's wife in the sense that it is post apocalyptic but more about the internal impact and takes its premise sincerely for those who like the literary side of science fiction
raw_text.1873: i love post apocalyptic fiction in general i'm always intrigued to see how writers handle the end of the world as we know it and those survivors dealing with the aftermath and the types of societies that start emerging from the rubble the dog stars is a post apocalyptic fiction set in the us after a decimating influenza outbreak there are not many survivors some of those who survived are ill with a subsequent illness and the rest seem to be random lawless scavengers trying to survive at all cost including killing and taking from others at the time we start our story our main character is actually in a fairly routine and somewhat stable world he and another survivor have carved out a territory that they defend at all cost against encroaching invaders the issue is that they are basically shooting first and no questions later assuming that all encroachers are up to no good indeed it seems like this may be the case but it has led to a tough morality dilemma for our main character he goes along with his friend but he doesn't seem to have his heart in it he wants to warn and to negotiate and he even has people living nearby that he does help this endangers him that is no way to build any kind of society or civilization it is only a way to claw the edge of survival until you die the main character does take an action to try to find something more and in doing so he finds what he's looking for what he finds seems to pave the way to a starting over where there is more promise to the world than simply defending boundaries it isn't a rosy ending which given the post apocalyptic genre i am thankful for but it is an ending that has some hope and some satisfaction
raw_text.1874: the apocalyptic theme is quite captivating i unlike many readers here haven't read much of those however the style is often mannered with hig stopping at mid sentences with a period often after the word but modernistic poets used to effect that gimmick and sounds like this writer is indeed a poet but i prefer to be spared of this in novels second the author is obviously a macho with great interest in the outdoors hunting aviation and all other things manly but to my mind he goes into way to much details about flying airplanes hunting fishing shooting and exhaustive and exhausting endless minute descriptions of nature i understand that he is a nature lover as well i think even wrote for some nature magazines but for the average reader it frankly becomes tiresome the unflinching descriptions of the escalating horrors are fine but then ah the mandatory love interest appears out of the black and that's as usual when it goes south with all the incredible devastation sickness scarcity of everything including human beings wouldn't you know hig meets that absolute perfect woman gorgeous smart a successful doctor no less and she as well meets her match in him and rather shamelessly it's implied they live happily ever after polease give me a break
raw_text.1875: heller's the dog stars is a thoughtful emotive look at a post apocalyptic world through the eyes of a pretty normal fella you won't find shambling zombies or leather clad road gangs in this book as much of it delves into the main character's isolation and his worldview the reasons to continue on after such a massive calamity and the struggle to not succumb to the darkest parts of our human nature the prose style in this book is concerned primarily with function but if you can get through the abbreviated style there are a great many gems to be found personally i don't mind this style of writing it's direct and feels more organic to me closer to the way people think often not in complete sentences parts of this dragged a little for me but once things picked up it kept my interest and by the last page i definitely felt that i got something out of this book there are tender and heartbreaking moments in here i think it is a mistake to compare this to cormac mccarthy's the road though i can see why some would make that leap post apocalyptic setting with a literary approach but it is nowhere near as bleak as the road that's not taking anything away from the dog stars mind you just my way of saying if you are looking for something as dark and unsettling as the road keep looking i recommend this for anyone looking for a more introspective take on life after a worldwide disaster

9 years after a flu like calamity rushed through society and left few survivors the main character hig lives in an airport hanger with his faithful dog jasper his neighbor bangley a borderline sadist and gun aficionado resides closeby and the two operate in a strange symbiotic relationship hig flies the airplane and farms bangley provides protection there is great contrast between these two characters hig a writer and a poet still hasn't adapted to this world bangley has taken to it swimmingly eventually hig parts way with bangley he wants to investigate a transmission he heard over 3 years ago hig takes to his plane a 1956 cessna and goes off in search hoping that there may be someone or something out there that is a safe haven i think this boiled down to a matter of preference for me in regards to my rating my overall impression is that the dog stars is an outdoor novel masquerading as a dystopian apocalyspe novel there is very little description of the disease only one meager hint as to what may be happening across the u s outside of hig's area the world building is bare the violence surprised me not the actual killing but the fact that everyone is violent and the raw_text.1905: if i could give half stars i would give this 4 1 2 a very good post apocalyptic novel that finally deals with the different sides of humanity and how each person may handle crisis and the aftermath what i loved is that it is set in colorado more particularly in the erie lafayette boulder area the particular avenue of mass death was an influenza virus that wipes out 90% of the population as well as many other species the main character hig is a pilot living at and old airport in the abandoned town of erie he has lost everything his wife his friends his way of life even the trout in the streams he so loved to fish for no longer exist he still makes forays into the wilderness to fish and hunt for what is left grasping for a life of normalcy his only companions are a dog his best friend and co pilot and a not so friendly misanthrope who teaches hig tactics on how to stay alive in this apocalyptic aftermath but he also can make flights in his beloved cessna regular unleaded fuel used for cars has broken down so it is unusable but jet fuel has a lot more staying power his plane is his joy but because of the vast depopulated world fuel is still very hard to find once on a flight he hears a mysterious voice on his radio coming from the grand junction area a brief moment of and its gone it sparks in him a hope for finding other human contact that he finds near impossible to resist despite warnings from his companion no assurance of having enough fuel and the constant threat of violence from other survivors he makes a decision that shows him more wonders and more horrors than he could have imagined

raw_text.1908: i'm still amazed at how many end of the world 'literary' novels have been coming out lately maybe it's the whole 2012 business the dog stars is one of the most recent entries in this category a first novel from a writer who has several non fiction books to his name hig lives at a small airfield with his dog jaspar plus bangey the survivalist gun nut neighbour oh and a flu bug wiped out 99% of the human race nine years earlier including hig's beloved wife melissa now he fills his days with growing food for himself helping out an area group of mennonites who are weakened by a blood disease that started going around the same time as the flu and which leaves them barely able to take care of themselves and flying his cessna on patrols of the area keeping an eye out for 'not nice' surivivors oh and going up into the mountains to fish and hunt even though global warming means that his favorite trout has vanished after an attempted assault on their home and a death hig decides that he wants to go looking for the source of a signal he'd heard faintly from another town three years earlier the only problem is he wouldn't be able to carry enough fuel for the round trip which has limited his flights in the past so will he go what will he find will he be able to get fuel to make it back home and what will he find when he finally gets home again the formatting of this book is one that normally drives me nuts namely no dialog punctuation or markings of any type and the language is very choppy but strangely it didn't bother me here the choppiness is easily put down to the fact that hig clearly has ptsd and the other formatting makes it easy to figure out the dialog i had no problem with it where i didn't even bother trying to read the novel blindness my only real complaint about the book was the hanging ending which seemed almost tagged on for the sake of saying 'oooh what will happen next ' i don't know if the author would do a sequel and i really recommend he not do so since the tag means that any sequel would have to be in a completely different style of story still other than that i thoroughly enjoyed the story

raw_text.1915: a post apocalyptic story with an open elegant heart heller's debut novel follows a pilot hig and an ex military man bangley in their fight for survival although stuck together in an uneasy partnership they each flawlessly compensate for the deficits in the other and guard their home an abandoned airport from maurading intuders even as danger lurks around every corner and death is present in every exchange the two work together as a well oiled machine yet nine years on hig is lost and yearning for something he can't quite name leaving bangley on his own hig takes off in his little cesna and flies beyond the point of no return holding on to the only thing he can hope the dog stars is an achingly beautiful book with characters that are wholly human it's a dazzling story full of loss pain and sorrow but also truth and absolutely every page is humming with brilliance

raw_text.1917: loved this book immensely readable while still literary in its execution just flew through the pages perfect voice great set up for a post apocalypse inhabiting a rural airport after a flu wipes out most of humanity excellent fully developed characters loved jasper the dog and hig's connection to him loved the pervasive sense of the outdoors the deep love of nature despite everything that ran through these pages enjoyed the flashes of humor from hig's at times odd way of looking at the world and from the secondary characters got a kick that bangley and pops were such bad asses compared to hig and were always reminding him of that at the end of the day hig was a deceptively simple man he just wanted to fish fly spend time with his wife and dog but he had a poetic nature about him as well i thought that combination of traits made him very likable very sympathetic i also appreciated that it ended on a hopeful note not a false sense of hope either but a well grounded sense of hope there are some terrible people on the margins in this book but there is a little bit of light at the end of the tunnel liked this book even better than the road not as bleak great book

raw_text.1923: 4 5 stars part post apocalypse survival tale part aviation narrative and part character study the dog stars is a book that will stick with me for some time to come i appreciate that the dog stars avoids a pessimistic view after all survival ability is greatly influenced by mental outlook and i would expect long term survivors to have at least some hope bangley pretty much steals every scene he's in through his dry singleminded focus on survival a lesser author would have rendered bangley superficially and used him for unwitting comic relief but heller gives him a depth and intensity the partnership between bangley and hig works because both are deeply flawed in very complementary ways bangley represents decisive action and survival for its own sake while hig represents contemplation and the quest to better one's situation instead of merely surviving heller's style of clipped prose and lack of quotation marks feels hokey and forced marring his otherwise excellent narrative also the book loses a little because i can't quite believe that survivors of the pandemic would so isolate themselves as to summarily kill any interlopers approaching them without even making efforts at communication
raw_text.1924: loved this post apocalyptic drama about a pilot who survives a flu epidemic that kills most of the people on the planet a beautiful and compelling treatise on humanity and hope until the last 5 pages which nearly destroyed me
raw_text.1925: ask me what books made the biggest impression on me in my childhood and one of my answers would be nevil shute's on the beach - an unforgettable vision of a post apocalyptic world in that book captain towers hears a faint morse code signal transmitting from far away and heads off on a tour of a ruined world seeking life i suspect that peter heller is also familiar with on the beach his debut book the dog stars is simply masterful unlike other writers of this genre who focus on the scientific or other worldly reasons for the apocalyptic event or move forward in a plot driven manner mr heller writes beautifully and powerfully about how the events affect one person a contractor poet and pilot named hig it is hig's fate to watch the extinction of everything and everybody he once loved his pregnant wife melissa the tigers elephants apes baboons and cheetahs and eventually the last trout - a heartache for this avid fisherman the prose is fragmented accurately mimicking how someone who has not needed to talk or communicate for many years and has "lost the touch " hig's only companion is a gun nut named bangley who is fleshed out and given an affecting back story and his loyal and aging dog jasper hig reflects "there is no one to tell this to and yet it seems very important to get this right the reality and what it is like to escape it that even now it is sometimes too beautiful to bear " and a little later "so i wonder what it is this need to tell to animate somehow the deathly stillness of the profoundest beauty breathe life in the telling "that is precisely what he does hig will eventually try to track down a static broken voice he heard on the radio years ago in much the same way that captain towers follows the enigmatic morse code signal and like captain towers he will find comfort in surprising places much of this book is surprisingly heartbreaking in its beauty as hig faces the toughest existential questions about life - and wonders why he is struggling so hard to survive in a world devoid of what and who he loves the most - he learns that hope and love and decency and humanity can come when you least expect it and he discovers that life and death live inside each other "waiting for warmer nights a compromised system a beetle as in the now dying black timber on the mountain " mr heller tackles nothing less than the reasons for living and the hopeless cycles that we all must go through this is a book that showcases an author who already possesses a voice to follow

raw_text.1966: this is one of those books that is like an unexpected gift you know from the moment you open it up that it is going to be something special it is beautifully meditative and deeply moving written in the first person as a stream of consciousness it is also a great choice for national poetry month the constant flow of poetic images juxtaposes the beauty of the prose with the profound sadness of the world coming to and end you are left with an overwhelming sensation of bittersweet the longing for what is lost combined with a microscopic and joyful appreciation of what still is hig the narrator 40 lives near one other person bruce bangley in an abandoned airstrip in colorado he still has his dog jasper but in the nine years since a flu pandemic and global warming destroyed most of the world he hasn't seen many other living beings ten miles away there are some thirty mennonites with the blood disease that hit after the flu but they are isolated and probably contagious so hig stays distant from them all other encounters few though they have been have been violent confrontations with armed and desperate people willing to kill any others to get their food and provisions hig and bangley have erected an eight mile "safety perimeter" and hig takes regular flights in his 1956 cessna to patrol it bangley is cynical and uninterested in anything not related to survival but hig is somehow still steeped in memories still leaking pain still battling tigers in the night and still harboring hope when he sees new vegetation peeping through the blighted timbers below his plane he yells out to the trees go go go grow grow grow that's our fight song the green patches are spreading year by year life is tenacious if you give it one little bit of encouragement i could swear they hear me they wave back wave their feathery arms back and forth down low by their sides..."he contemplates all the species death and muses still last summer i saw a nighthawk first one in years flitting for bugs in a warm dusk wingbars blinking in the twilight that soft electric peep "what keeps him going he wonders he thinks about how he no longer has many choices and yet still even with nothing much to lose he doesn't want to lose what he has nothing is something somehow and that is the crux of this story in a nutshell the will to live the tenacity of the life force and the resurgence of life and beauty and hope when all is gone discussion this book has been compared to the road by cormac mccarthy but it reminded me much more of zen and the art of motorcycle maintenance zamm by robert pirsig i thought the writing in this book to be far superior however zamm is a first person description of a cross country journey by motorcycle during which time the narrator explores many of the same issues as does hig philosophical questions ranging from the relationship of man to machine to the meaning of life and how to achieve peace of mind no matter what the circumstances even the discussions of the quality of fuel in both books are parallel but pirsig is more prosaic heller adds magic to the mundane such as this pithy but poetic reflection by hig on what he sees when flying his plane the round bales and scattered cattle and horses as perfect in their patterns as sprays of stars... " hig's relationship to fishing is also reminiscent of the zamm author's loving care he bestows on his bike and the joy he derives from it hig reflects all of this these motions the sequence the quiet the rill and gulp the riffle of the stream and the wind soughing the needles of the tall trees as i strung the rod i had known it all hundreds probably now thousands of times it was ritual that required no thought like putting on socks except this ritual put me in touch with something that felt very pure meaning that in fishing i had always all my life brought the best of myself my attention and carefulness my willingness to risk and my love patience whatever else was going on ... "and he describes the carp trout are long gone in the world they fought without the vigor of a trout but with a sullen reluctance like a mule digging in its heels they didn't charge upstream or wrap themselves in the branches of an old deadfall they simply refused to budge which wasn't fun but then there wasn't much fun anymore and i came to admire their stoicism a stolid refusal to be yet consumed by the universe like us "finally much as zamm does you will find yourself contemplating the many questions heller raises about life and how best to approach it having "the end of the world" as a factor adds more urgency and piquancy to the contemplations what is it after all that makes us want to go on living in spite of pain and loss and adversity is it the quest for connection with other human beings and the rewards it brings one is reminded of e m forster's famous entreaty only connect only connect the prose and the passion and both will be exalted and human love will be seen at its height live in fragments no longer only connect and the beast and the monk robbed of the isolation that is life to either will die e m forster howards endis it curiosity or is it sheer stubbornness and then there are the apocalyptic issues does terror lead to madness that is would a prolonged period of fear and depravation cancel out the civilized veneer of our animal natures is civilization even adaptive under such dire circumstances evaluation i've marked way too many passages to quote it's all so good heller's right on description of living with the pain of loss his adept stream of consciousness rendition of reaction to a physical attack his ability to convey a mood to conjure up a moment in time to touch us and haunt us and remind us both of what is worst and what is best about humanity highly recommended rating 4 5 5

raw_text.1968: a solid dystopian post apocalyptic adventure featuring the standard tricks of the trade the unlikely antihero necessity's strange bedfellows the absurdity of outmoded ethics in a kill or be killed environment love in the most unlikely of places and all of that done quite nicely it's also a book with a lot of heart and without issuing any spoilers i'll share that i was also impressed by the amount of optimism and romance heller was able to inject into the story without compromising the harsh realities of its universe that's all the good stuff and that was all good enough to keep me hooked and turning pages so by most measures the book is successful but heller chooses to have our hero narrate the story in a terse choppy staccato that try as i did to accept it felt unnatural to the character and made for a jumpy uneven read i just couldn't see any reason for it it didn't successfully convey stream of consciousness or internal dialogue and it was an ill fit for a hero with a deep appreciation for poetry my suspicion is that heller may have been looking for a little something to hide behind some of the more rapturous passages in which he positively gushes with love for his beloved western landscapes might have left him feeling a little vulnerable it is his first novel after all perhaps he was looking to create some distance with a little stylistic abstraction just a guess in any case it didn't work so the style knocks it down at least a star but still very much worth the read

raw_text.1997: slight spoiler warning going to try and not repeat what all the other reviews said overall i was entertained by the book and it caused me to think the "what if" scenario i found the timeline and or circumstances by which they arrived here a bit confusing it seems as if it was intended to be "today" that the pandemic takes place and the story picks up nine years later but there also is a "blood disease" that also has occurred at the same time or after as a result of not really clear to me also why are all the animals dead this doesn't seem to be related to flu global warming i'm no scientist but i would think if all the humans are dead that global warming could reverse itself and the earth would return to a more natural state which probably would mean more animals not less i'm also perplexed by the references to arabs so everyone else on the planet was wiped out except the few immune and the arabs is peter helms trying to make some sort of political statement maybe i'm reading too much into it... nevertheless the story does explore what it may be like after such an event and how loneliness and instincts kick in and can change a person into a killer cannibal etc there are real emotions and feelings demonstrated in the characters and although i wouldn't particularly ever like any of them in real life i was drawn into the story and had a hard time putting it down it does explore what risks one might be willing to take to have that human connection that most of us need and crave as part of our survival i enjoyed the manner in which the story was written and the prose despite the gaps in the history

raw_text.2004: peter heller's the dog stars is the first stream of consciousness style book i have read the style took a few minutes to adjust to after which it ceased to impede the flow of reading big hig and his aging dog jasper are survivors of a flu pandemic living in the confines of an abandoned airport they partner with a hardened ex warrior bangley to keep their territory safe from marauding groups of scavengers bangley's blunt hard core instincts and skills provide critical protection in a world where everything is a potentially lethal unknown hig has lost virtually everything and everyone important to him he eludes bouts of crushing loneliness and depression through simple acts of hunting fishing gardening and flying a vintage cessna aircraft all of those things are tentative though as he watches the wildlife disappear and his fuel reserves diminish when jasper dies hig is devastated anew in desperation he makes a momentous decision three years earlier he heard a faint signal from a distant airport the fuel to reach it is more than his cessna's capacity it could easily be a one way trip if there is no fuel at his destination or if anything bad happens along the way it's also a matter of abandoning bangley his only if borderline friend protection has been a team effort with hig scouting long range invaders from the air and bangley dispatching them via his sniper's tower both men will be especially vulnerable during this indefinite period of separation their hesitancy and resolve are reminiscent of a young man leaving the only home he has ever known to seek his destiny and of a strict parent knowing he cannot stand in the way hig's journey leads him to a place he never expected and to a part of his soul he thought would never see the light of day again the story mainly dealt with hig's emotional state his reactions and observations of the destruction and ruthlessness that became his world heller gives enough details of the pandemic and the breakdown of society to set that stage for us there is beauty in between the grisly tasks of survival and bits of hope that will not wither to make any comment about the ending would give away too much so readers will have to make that journey on their own with hig in the pilot's seat

raw_text.2018: the dog stars is set in a post apocalyptic future where 99% of the population has been wiped out by a superflu the protagonist is a lonely man with only his best friend a dog and the slightly unnerving survivalist bangley the authors prose reminds me of the road narrated in the third person the character uses sentence fragments that give the impression of unfiltered thoughts as they come to the main character at times the writing style can be abbrasive and difficult to follow he also relies heavily on metaphors and has a strong poetic style to his writing when it works the story haunting and intimant in its relationship with the reader some problems that eventually faded as the book wore on was the slow pacing i was almost halfway through the book before i started to fall into the story and stop paying attention to how close i was to finishing this is mainly because there is no conflict or strong emotional feeling i could relate to up to that point i did enjoy the moments with his dog but they do not play a huge part in this novel fortunately once the book got going i was happily engaged and enjoyed the story while it compares nicely to the road in style and genre i don't think it will have the road's lasting emotional impact 3 5 stars
raw_text.2019: the dog stars by peter heller tells the tale of hig who is living in a time following a flu pandemic that wiped out 99 5% of the human population those who were immune are left to eke out an existence in a lonely world hig and his companion bangley do eke out an existence and regularly defend their little piece of the world against the not so nice people who come in twos or fives or nines to threaten that existence from time to time when hig decides to use his plane to go beyond the relatively safe boundaries of their established perimeter what he finds is much more than he bargained for i really liked this book i liked it because of the way it was written stream of consciousness style short paragraphs incomplete sentences no quotation marks it made me work a little bit and that's a good thing to have to engage the brain when reading what i liked even more was the way heller dealt with the natural world in this most humans wiped off the face of the earth scenario all too often in stories like this earth is totally destroyed reduced to ash think the road by cormac mccarthy instead of going that route heller chose to get rid of all the humans but let the beauty of earth remain and allow hig to find solace in the mountains and streams and forests that surrounded his place in the world and when the mountains and streams and forests no longer provide the solace hig seeks heller creates an opportunity for hig to go beyond the safety of the perimeter this journey allows hig to confront fears both real and imagined and come into his own in a way that was satisfying and rang true for me
raw_text.2020: this post apocalyptic novel is often compared to the road and while there's definitely reason to make that comparison heller's protagonist and his book as a whole have quite a bit more humor and more tenderness at times the wasted world doesn't even seem that bad after all hig can still fish and hunt in the rockies scarred as they are by drought and beetles the language of the book with its abundance of sentence fragments and dearth of punctuation takes a bit of getting used to but it provides a fitting voice for hig expressing at various times his focus on survival his depth of grief and his love of the land in an appropriately stripped down way that still manages to be poetic at times the romance that crops up late in the book isn't horrible well developed but as a reader i still liked that it happened there's gore and hardship and loss here as the situation requires but also some hope just enough
raw_text.2021: if you liked the road but wanted more planes this is the book for you

we still felt obliged to love each other we found we had little in common four years can be a serious obstacle when you're a teenager we also belonged to an entirely different social groups my sister was more of a cheap wine flannel shirts suicidal rock singers kind of girl while i tended to find my solace in weed hoop earrings and rappers who'd been shot dead we didn't see eye to eye sometimes we wouldn't even acknowledge each other on the street now it's all different and literature is one of those things that keeps bringing us closer and closer we read this book together on our respective kindles and decided to review it in a recorded conversation here translated from polish for your benefit kinga i decided that 'the dog stars' is a post apocalyptic novel about fishing how did you like it basia i have mixed feelings i did like the message and concept but i believe that the author didn't use their full potential he focused too much on fishing and flying and old cessna and at times it feelings exactly it was as if the author created this post apocalyptic world a very believable it has to be said and during writing he remembered a novel should also lead somewhere that there should be a climax so while the main character is flying his cessna playing for time the author comes up with what happens next but let's start from the beginning we are in the united states the majority of population died of flu the narrator who guides us around this post apocalyptic world is hig who is somewhat forced to share his new life with bangley the creation of these two main characters was one the things i really liked about this book although i think some people might find these two too stereotypical kinga i really liked these characters too and i didn't find them particularly stereotypical in the beginning i thought hig was a really tough guy because he can swear and shoot a deer but then when see him through bangley's eyes we notice his weakness or if you like his humanity and we see that bangley is taking care of big hig at the same time revealing his own weakness in reality 'the dog stars' is a bit of a western two guys sit in some god forgotten hole they talk little shoot a lot sometimes they would feed a corpse to the dog but in all of it they grew to love each other and as it is in all westerns there comes a woman traditionally devoid of personality and her main feature are her violet eyes that woman is a nurturer care taker and all round chicken soup for the soul basia you thought of westerns and i thought of two philosophers who spoke of anarchy and the creating of nation and there is no better place and time to test such theories than right after an apocalypse where everything that the humankind had built falls apart and it can finally be established whether the natural state for humans is to be happy and peaceful like locke had it here hig or whether it's a state of constant struggle brought forward by the innate selfishness of people like hobbes maintained starring bangley so what i think peter heller is doing here is that he is proposing a thought experiment of a sort imagine that all the humandkind expired and there are only two dudes left with completely opposite outlooks on the world what will happen and will those outlooks even matter anymore kinga i also thought about this dichotomy and that even in those almost lab like environment such as that post apocalyptic world it was very difficult to test these theories because on one hand we have bangley who preventively shoots everyone and on the other hand we have hig who is free to test his theory of loving one's neighbour but he will only be able to be wrong once to be perfectly honest i thought that it would've looked different in europe due to purely technical reasons it would be next to impossible to gather such an arsenal like in the us and it would be somewhat harder for people to kill each other so they would be forced to talk to each other and once they start talking it might turn out it's better to be together than against each other i think this was the final optimistic conclusion of this novel basia i believe that paradoxically this novel was supposed to be uplifting after all and it wanted to remind us something important from the flashbacks we can gather that the characters' lives before the catastrophe were full of waiting for something until they make enough money can start a family waiting for the courage to change their careers waiting for that real life to begin and of course only with the hindsight and with the apocalypse in mind can they realise that that was the real life those were the best moments funny how you can live a whole life waiting and not know it waiting for your real life to begin maybe the most real thing the end maybe those quotes away from the novel might sound trite and gushing but amongst that jagged and austere narrative made quite of an impression on me kinga i agree i think in general this is the appeal of post apocalyptic novels all those things that we fret over even though we realise they're not that important get cancelled and life returns to the basics in real life only selected few have it in them to just reject all that nonsense the rest console themselves with reading as a matter of fact most books about fishing are not really about fishing but also about what's important in life and it turns out that what's important it's to find someone we can love and everything will somehow works itself out even if that someone is just a dog you mentioned the jagged austere style i liked it a lot it was as if that whole trauma of the apocalypse deprived people of the ability to talk loneliness and sadness drive hig to speak like a troglodyte there are many things left unsaid and sentences end with prepositions that should be followed by a noun but hig can't bring himself to say it there was a great scene of a conversation between hig and bangley which i'll quote here i asked him if he ever thought there was anything more than this than just surviving day to day recon fixing the plane growing the five vegetables trapping a rabbit like what are we waiting for his chair crick crick stopped he got very still like a hunter that smelled an animal on the wind close like he woke up say again more than this day to day he worked his jaw his mineral eyes graying in the fading light like maybe i'd tipped over the edge gotta go he said stood up basia this is exactly how i felt about the style i was enchanted by the language especially after my trials and tribulations with doris lessing and her 'memoirs of a survivor' where by contrast the narrative is formed by long fancy sentences always ending with an ellipsis actually the only thing i didn't quite like about this novel was that despite great world building and a fantastic style simply not enough happened on the other hand now i'm thinking what can happen when the world ended kinga raw_text.2044: men's health called this one of the manliest reads of the summer and indeed this is a manly book which would make it surprising that i liked it given that i seem to have a preference for somewhat feminist reads but let me elaborate hig our narrator is a manly man not john wayne manly more like humphrey bogart kind of manly he flies a 1956 cessna he loves fishing he hunts takes care of the weak is truly best friends with his dog not that there's a lot of competition for the dog but see what i did there heller's writing sneakily won me over anyway he also loves poetry mourns incessantly over his late wife is prone to philosophizing and falls in love like a teenager he also also frequently lacks confidence in himself but in manly way you see you can't not like this guy no really i expect this to become a big book as more people fall in love with hig and jasper and even bangley and spread the word an utterly originally exceedingly well written and gut wrenching novel
