raw_text.2417: this one pulls you in by the scruff of the neck with its sparse prose before you know it you're inhabiting a faded new world most people are dead due to some superflu most life seems to be on its way out and the climate seems to be changing supposedly bleak but it all seems a bit too beautiful the protagonist hig and his dog jasper live on an abandoned airfield everywhere's abandoned he's buddied up with a grumpy survivalist gun nut who watches over everything and occasionally seems to use hig as bait to lure in other survivors so he can pick them off this is all very standard stuff but the telling of it is well done and that urges you on where mccarthy's the road stuck to its guns and portrayed a consistent and wearying bleakness with its characters avoiding contact out of fear the dog stars switches up and hig goes out looking for others this is where the book sagged for me becoming predictable and hitting all the marks and beats you would expect a tv movie to go through there are a few set pieces along the way played out in a manner that seems designed to tick all the right boxes rather than make you feel emotionally engaged it does flow and it does carry you along but in the end it begins to lose substance and becomes quite light lots of promise and great style all that's needed is a better story to tell
raw_text.2418: powerful riveting the editorial review began i can't improve on that i want to find new words that haven't been invented yet to describe how much i loved this book but superlatives almost seem at odds with peter heller's spare pared down writing this is an odd quirky style that employed no dialogue tags and staccato wildly unconventional punctuation almost as if you can imagine hig the main character writing it with a body that survived this apocalyptic flu but his brain can't quite get over the shock i always tell my friends i will read almost anything except post apocalyptic dystopia too sad too hopeless but this was so highly recommended by the publisher that i had to take a chance if all books in this genre were of this calibre i would be tempted to read nothing else in a world gone mad and the human population almost decimated hig and bangley his gun crazed neighbor have lived for 9 years on the abandoned airport at erie co their only visitors are roaming bands of survivors who have degenerated into homicidal savages hig a skilled pilot and avid fisherman lost his wife to the outbreak and could think only of basic existence ever since when he finally makes plans to follow up on the most tenuous of connection to the outside world a radio transmission he heard years ago while flying he has no idea where this will lead he will be vulnerable without bangley's fire power and superior survival skills and there are no guarantees that fuel will be available at other airports but it has become a risk he has to take if he is ever to feel life is worth living again i feel privileged to have read this it was a very special book

raw_text.2420: i don't usually like dystopian fiction but this book was really good heller writes in stark hemingwayesque prose that pulls the reader in and keeps them there hig the narrator is a pilot who has survived a mass extinction from a fatal flu he is one of the few survivors and has managed to survive with a dicey partnership with his shoot first ask questions later neighbor bangley their difficult relationship the constant challenges of survival and how they adapt is fascinating especially as they come to understand each other and the reader learns more about their stories at times funny touching and even nail biting peril the book never stoops to using death as entertainment but seeks to show the difficult consequences of acting to survive the more i reflect on the book the more i like it
raw_text.2421: this book is frightening beautiful and moving a rare combination it possesses a kind of poetry what one critic very aptly describes as the soul of haiku peter heller writes with such skill and grace that i was completely drawn into the world he has created terrified by it moved to tears at times and laughter at others i especially loved the keen attention to tiny details the description of patterns on quilts the at times almost microscopic views of nature the passage that tells us about the cental character returning home to retrieve only volumes of collected poetry some of the very best writing in the book is the passages presenting the central character with his dog these are the finest examples of that wraith like poetry woven throughout the fabric of the narrative there is a remarkable dexterity to this novel so very evident in the artistry of the author poet naturalist scientist aviator philosopher human being a huge thank you to the person who recommended this book to me when it otherwise may have passed me by good call

raw_text.2424: "country boys will survive "this is hig's only friend's favorite line i'm not sure it's his favorite line because together their daily job is simply surviving or because they live in the valley of beautiful country or that they need aphorisms as pompoms to keep them selves going day to day they are survivors of a deadly flu and these two wildly different men are now dependent on each other for their lives there's a mad max element out there beyond the hanger and old house where they live respectively it's not really a big part of the dog stars but provides the edginess that keeps hig the pilot and gun toting bangley on their toes though the dog stars seems couched in the dystopian genre it's really more of a love story than anything else hig loves his dog jasper the days he spent fishing for trout when they still existed the small plane he uses to survey the valley and the beautiful outdoors peter heller manages to convey all of this in wonderful poetic like prose i think i've read the first page of this novel ten times as a survivor hig's beginning to place more value on human connections and whatever else is out there beyond the lonely valley he helps his mate bangley protect when hig takes off in his small cessna plane to follow a lone voice he heard transmitted he begins a new adventure one made at the great potential cost he'll never realistically return this is what hig thinks he wants he's charmingly naive but manages make some special discoveries so as to not spoil anything i'll say one thing he finds is something we all take for granted every day news "my god hig you haven't heard any news real news in almost a decade it's making you horny "this is a hard book to write about without giving anything away so i'll stop now just readit already you'll be happy you did

raw_text.2431: set a few decades in the future the dog stars tells the story of a small number of survivors in colorado after a virus has wiped out almost everyone else hig is a carpenter hunter fisherman pilot who has teamed with a heavily armed tactitian named bangley to protect their hideout at an airstrip anyone coming to call is considered "not nice including children and bangley efficiently deploys his firepower with hig's reluctant acquiescence after losing the only living remnant of his old life hig sets out in his cessna to seek the source of a radio signal from the other side of the state knowing he can't carry enough fuel to return peter heller tells hig's story using spare intermittently lyrical and always lucid prose hig tries to make sense of his life without thinking too hard about his losses--he knows his thoughts "are discomfited unlike bangley who is "at home with his solitude as a note reverberating inside a bell" hig seeks connection so he helps a group of mennonites who have a contagious "blood disease" and flies off to meet the unknown radio voice more of the story you should get from reading the book the dog stars is rife with dualities--silence speaking philosophy tactics protection by the strength of weapons protection by the weakness of disease serenity danger--to name a few hig says "i want to be two people at once one runs away "heller describes flying fishing and paramilitary strategy in ways reader aficionados will enjoy this is a story about people surviving because of what they know how to do because they have acquired "a hard won usefulness but living rather than just surviving occurs when the book's characters find ways to connect in a desolate and dangerous world i read this book twice--once quickly flying through the story and the second time slowly savoring the writing the dog stars held up both times

raw_text.2440: dog starshig likes to escape reality by flying his 1956 cessna now that a pandemic has taken out most of the earth's population he may be one of the few pilots left hig lives in an abandoned airport hangar with a fellow survivor bangley and his beloved dog jasper bangley and hig have teamed up to reinforce their shelter against any possible invaders who may be infected or on the prowl for food or weapons it's been years since the sickness hit and civilization is in decay everywhere supplies are running low and they rely on their survival mentality hig is a generous soul bringing supplies and aid to a group of families who have not fully recovered from the flu he and bangley don't always agree on things but honest human companionship is a rarity that both want to hold onto it but something's missing in hig's life without his regular life to keep him sane he wonders about his purpose and has to reevaluate his existence peter heller does a remarkable job bringing beauty to these destitute souls his descriptions of the environment are breathtaking and grotesquely simple once i was absorbed into the book i was immediately impressed with hig's faith and determination his good spirit and honest drive made me appreciate his struggle to be human in a world where humans have been extinguished highly recommend
raw_text.2441: the dog stars is a dystopian novel told in first person the narrator is hig a pilot who--nine years after the end of civilization--still has an old cessna up and running he lives at an airport in erie colorado with a man named bangley together they survive by fighting off occasional attackers and maurauders hig uses the cessna to patrol the perimeter and spot any approaching troublemakers ahead of time and bangley uses with his weaponry and sharp shooting skills to eliminate them hig and bangley have a symbiotic relationship they each depend on the other to stay safe unlike cormac mccarthy's the road here we know exactly what happened to the world and when it began as a virus and moved quickly the few survivors became protective of their home and supplies and fearful of anyone who still might be carrying the blood disease but hig wants more that just to survive he longs for humanity for human connection he wants more than just the seemingly cold business relationship he shares with bangley one day while flying hig hears a voice from a control tower a few years pass and he can no longer resist the call and goes out in search of its origin is hig just a dreamer who'll invite more trouble for himself and bangley by looking for the person who made the call or is there a reward at the end to justify his risk the novel has heart and unfolds at a pace that is both absorbing and satisfying and we get to see it all through hig's eyes i really cared about the character of hig all that he had lost and the hopes that he still harbored i got lost in the world heller created and wanted to see how it all turned out as much as i enjoyed this novel i'd be remiss if i didn't mention the writing style some readers may find it off putting like mccarthy heller relies on the gimmick of not using quotation marks to indicate dialogue i found this to be distracting since the story is told in first person sometimes i had to go back and see if it was really dialogue or just hig's internal monologue the other style choice heller uses is very short and incomplete sentences such as this one "he is the only one now the only sight which tomorrow i'll i don't know "heller did this to show hig's scattered mindset in the beginning his competing emotions and thoughts because of what happens in the second half of the book these incomplete sentences are not used as much or maybe by then i had gotten used to the style and or was absorbed in the plot but i felt like i had to give a warning to readers who might not like this style stick with it though the story is that good

raw_text.2443: i was supposed to read this for my book club last december but i was too busy everyone hated the book or didn't like it very much so i decided to skip it however it was announced that the author would be at booktopia in petoskey and i knew i had to read it i really liked this book i thought the writing was amazing for being in a weird first person stream of conscious diary type of format i was instantly sucked in and devoured this book i loved how the writing was unique but not flashy or gimmicky and really got you into the head of hig i read this book in two days in a couple of sittings i also liked that this was a small contained story this story was about loneliness as told in a time where most humans were killed by a plague it wasn't just about the mechanics of living in a post apocalyptic world this was a book about how to deal with incredible loneliness and how we as people cope with loneliness though the world was not a cheery place it wasn't bleak it wasn't totally cruel it had a real sense of humanity for me and i enjoyed this book that wasn't about total despair i had a few issues i thought may times the events were too convenient i felt there wasn't a real struggle at times and that didn't feel authentic in some ways the story was just this happened and this happened and this happened and this happened it didn't have a sense of urgency or anything driving the story also i don't understand the title at all i think it sounds like a cool title but it doesn't make sense to me overall i liked this book and i had fun reading it it was nice to have a small contained linear story that grabbed me and pulled me along for a ride

raw_text.2458: i do like a good post apocalyptic story i guess it comes from being an australian the landscape and weather lend themselves to thoughts of the absence of humanity of the collapse of life as we know it peter heller's the dog stars like cormac mccarthy's the road is set in a post collapse usa in the dog stars it is a series of diseases a flu and some mysterious blood borne disease that have wiped out nearly all people and the survivors have descended into barbarism in many ways the road and the dog stars could both be set in the same world the way the world ended might be different but the behaviour of the survibors is the same although the characters in the dog stars seem to have been much more successful in setting themselves up for life after the apocalypse at the start of the novel hig and and bangley are the only two remaining people in a small town in inland usa they defend themselves from other survivors who seem to turn up in the town every few months trying to attack and kill them the novel is somewhat unclear about the morality of all this hig seems ambivalent about whether they should be killing these attackers or trying to befriend them his few attempts at befriending have failed nearly getting them killed so now their reaction to newcomers is now to shoot on sight it's a slow story with only a little action but it's an exploration of hig's loss his sadness and his search for hope in a ruined world it comes to its conclusion well and you get to know the characters well enough that their reactions to things can sometimes come as a bit of a surprise the dog stars is well written the switching between hig's stilted day to day voice and his waxing poetical is very nicely done and well worth reading

raw_text.2484: after a pandemic kills 99% of the population a survivor tries to find some hope for the future hig along with his dog jasper and fellow survivor bangley is living on a fortified compound in colorado after a flu pandemic their safety is precarious and hinges on hig's piloting his 1956 cessna to scout their area from the air and bangley's uninhibited penchant for killing intruders though bangley seems content with their situation hig can't forget a radio transmission he heard 3 years ago coming from grand junction and the hope that came with it hig must decide between his commitment to bangley and the search for a better existence powerful and beautifully written heller's debut novel not only illustrates the horror and isolation that come with the near annihilation of mankind but the new bonds that are forged and the humanism that remains

raw_text.2487: i loved the writing in the dog stars the author did such a great job of evoking the main character's personality hig was a combination of an outdoorsman and "man's man " and then also a poet and philosopher he was sensitive and often compassionate i really loved his character the dog stars reminded me of "the little prince" in which the narrator flies around the world in his airplane is stranded in the desert and meets the little prince who expounds on the beauties and also the frailties of the world like the little prince the dog stars presents a lesson about life this famous line from the little prince is really the theme of that book one sees clearly only with the heart what is essential is invisible to the eye in the dog stars it seems like the apocalypse has made hig's past life "invisible " and somehow allowed him to live more in the present appreciating every small beauty like the little prince said hig is has a poetic nature anyway and so his observations throughout the book are poignant and touching at the end of the little prince the prince tells the narrator that when he leaves it will make the narrator sad but it will be consoling to look at the stars and think of the prince's lovable laughter and that it will seem as if all the stars are laughing it seems like hig uses the stars in this way as a sort of consolation and that the name of the book refers to the nostalgia and beauty in the memories of all the stars he has named that console him in his current post apocalyptic life the dog stars is the type of sci fi that i like i think you could call this science fiction in that it takes one aspect of the world today and fictionalizes it but still lets all the characters interact in totally realistic way and the lessons learned apply to us today in the real world all the ruminations that hig dished out over the course of the book seemed to be useful not only in a post apocalyptic world but also in our modern day world i loved hig's relationship with bingley they are forced together and they both learn from each other the evolution of bingley's character is interesting and heartwarming

raw_text.2489: i'm not a fan of the post apocalyptic genre usually but this was really good the plot is relatively simple a pilot tries to survive in a bleak and brutal rural america after flu has wiped out the majority of the population he and his dog and a fellow survivor with whom he shares his encampment exist in a state of permanent watchfulness punctuated by moments of extreme violence the action of the plot reveals a single question is there a point to surviving when everything you lived for is gone i'm not sure heller ever really answers that question but that's probably the point and the bare skeletal prose and the raw emotional power of his writing are really startling and very moving plus anyone who can write so perfectly about how great dogs are is onto a winner

raw_text.2502: when i first picked up the dog stars i didn't know anything more than the cover copy gave me "savagely funny and achingly sad a breathtaking story about what it means to be human " just my cup of tea a woman at checkout said "this is considered one of the best books of the year " i waited for her to say more to personalize her review but she didn't so i thought i'd be able to tell for myself shortly actually it was definitely one of the best books of my year but it wasn't because i learned "what it means to be human" but because heller told an old fashioned story in a new way i could have read on far past the last pages the writing was stellar tension and restraint braid the narrative and propel the story heller took us on a flight in a plane packed with only essentials he jettisoned anything that didn't add to the narrative...pronouns prepositions even nouns and verbs were flung aside if less is more we get just enough to set our imaginations free i loved it the setting is post apocalyptic times let me state that this is not my favorite venue but readers who find might someone else's vision less than fully imagined put your reservations aside in this case this vision is fascinating but it is the writing that makes the experience there is a clipped muscular quality to this narrative that kept me rapt heller managed to make even his hard bitten characters completely absorbing flawed but generous in unexpected ways these are characters we care about and i suppose it is about what humans want and need to thrive while it's frightening at times it is not dreary not really it's a love story

raw_text.2505: part of what makes this survival story so remarkable to me is how it made me feel thoughout the journey the storyteller hig made me travel whether i was ready or wanted to or not hig's language the way he thinks talks expresses himself describes events of the past present and future are heart meltingly beautiful it made me reread passages and sit and think about what he said why it mattered that i remembered it and what i hoped to learn from it i had no idea that such raw and powerful grief could be so beautiful so that although your head and heart ache you move through the pain slowly experiencing and feeling it fully this is not something i normally appreciate in a book i dread the loss and pain i know is somewhere up ahead and then i rage a little bit at the author because i don't want to go through this with the character but hig is someone i was willing to endure with even the most unbearable agonies maybe it's because his spirit embraces the love and pieces of himself he's lost and continues to cherish those losses and take it all with him as he moves forward with warmth humor determination and a courage i not only admired but wanted to find for myself too hig takes another huge loss nine years after the flu has struck down most of civilization leaving many survivors with a blood disease then he sets out to find he doesn't know what but he starts the journey anyway and what he finds answers of a sort the great treasure of human connection affection and cooperation doesn't make his loss ok but it does make those finds more comforting satisfying valuable
raw_text.2506: when listing the things that i like to do camping and living off the earth rank near the bottom while this book is written with great technique and certain scenes like the one at the river is wonderful there is a lot too much surviving in this book for my tastes the book does improve in the second half after he finds a different set of people felt like putting this book down more than a couple of times also the ending is very satisfying don't write a sequel i would definitely try this author again if he picks another topic to write about
raw_text.2507: okay so i'm not a huge fan of post apocalyptic fiction i appreciated the road as excellent writing but couldn't stand the imagery it left in my head so i picked up the dog stars with some reservation and expected i'd be putting it back down quickly i was wrong this is written from the perspective of hig a man who has survived the inevitable pandemic flu as well as a follow up blood disease that has left the world very few survivors hig is a good man or at least is trying to be one in a world that doesn't recognize good and evil on the same terms anymore it is truly a world of just survival he has his dog jasper for companionship and bangley a fellow survivalist for a tactical partnership together they live on near a small airport and protect their perimeter from potential threats all potential threats what struck me about this book was the way the story was told it was downright poetic at times which is fitting as hig is a poet at heart when hig starts to feel unrooted the writing becomes similarly so hig tries to be the good guy but is often the fool which he comes to realize and accept in his own way he tries to relish the few happy moments that come his way but always with a touch of grief because he knows these moments are fleeting and everything ends sounds depressing but oddly is not there's also a feeling of isolation and loneliness woven into everything hig does but think about it how does one connect with others in this new world where everyone is trying to take what you have hig has jasper but jasper's conversational skills are woefully lacking as you can imagine the story can feel outlandish at times but only because it also feels outlandish to hig i mean really he knows that his survival and this new crazy world are totally insane so i accepted the unrealness of it and enjoyed the book even more

raw_text.2523: this book clearly owes a lot to cormac mccarthy the prose is purposefully clipped and choppy with sparse punctuation and lots of intentionally fragmented sentences within internal monologues the setting is a post apocalyptic world not unlike that of mccarthy's the road with a similarly bleak outlook on humanity it really could be happening in elsewhere in the same world these similarities though are not enough to dismiss this book out of hand as a derivative work it has it's own point of view and it works really well as a character study of its protagonist the settings are all in colorado mainly denver grand junction and in between which i didn't realize before starting the book and was kind of a cool surprise the book is well researched and relatively short and the bleakness while undeniable isn't quite as overpowering as that of the road anyway if you haven't read the road you should probably read that first i definitely thought this one is worth a read too though

raw_text.2548: the dog stars makes me wonder if i should spend less time reading and writing and editing books and more time learning to fly airplanes and grow gardens and shoot the people who will want my airplane and garden after the apocalypse but hig a denver carpenter and grieving poet somehow manages to hold onto his literary self while he survives so maybe i'll be okay heller's world is vivid in its starkness this isn't about what happens as 99% of the world's population dies it's about what happens 10 years later to a handful of survivors who are still holding on still grieving still watchful hig is a man on the brink of devastating loneliness and sadness held together by his dog and his one and only neighbor on the remote airfield in northern colorado he flies scouting missions and fishes and tries not to visibly cringe when bangley shoots anyone who stumbles on or attacks their perimeter but eventually hig must leave the safety of the airfield to see what has happened to the rest of the world he flies west over mountains i know well and finds what he least expects this is a beautiful dark funny book about loneliness and if that sounds contradictory wait til you read it because you really really should read it and then learn to shoot because we never know if we'll be the 03% who live

raw_text.2555: this book is a post apocolypse story taking place in the 2030s global warming has progressed a deadly flu has wiped out most of the population of north america and probably the rest of the world although that isn't certain since communication has broken down hig is one of the few survivors his only neighbors for several miles a community of mennonites with a fatal slow acting blood disease and a survivalist named bangley with whom he has an uneasy alliance most remaining humans are savages and hig and bangley kill anyone who approaches their perimeter seven years after the catastrophe hig's dog dies and he realizes that the dog was his only friend desperate for connection hig risks everything to find a voice that he briefly heard in a radio transmission two years ago i devoured this book it felt very realistic to me as far as what the world would be like in such a situation and how people would feel and it makes a larger statement about how much we all risk to makes real connections with other people but mainly i just liked hig so much and was rooting for him and for the survival of some semblance of civilization
raw_text.2556: the post apocalyptic world has never been quite so eloquently lived gutsy and raw i couldn't put it down
raw_text.2557: what this novel does best is convey a feeling of loneliness loss and inertia or perhaps apathy there is a poetry inherent in the stream of conscious writing style that brings the story to life even as the plot trundles along rather slowly and it feels odd to call the book slow when quite a lot happens in only 330 pages but it did seem slow nine years after a flu that has killed 99 point something per cent of the population hig is living a lonely and stagnant life his only companions his dog and a gun enthusiast neighbor named bangley while bangley thrives in the intensely violent new world hig is uncomfortable with the shoot first never negotiate mindset that seems to be modus operandi in heller's vision of post apocalyptic america hig longs for the family he lost and the comfort of old routines that have been irrevocably lost hig's stream of conscious narrative really helped me see both the debilitating loneliness of his world and how frozen and stuck hig is in basic survival mode he is alive but barely living and many of hig's observations about life love and loss are beautiful and haunting i would say this story is about hig's awakening and return to life and for me the plot picked up as hig began taking steps to become again more of a protagonist than a passive observer in his own life i've always been drawn to post apocalyptic fiction because i find the story of rebuilding society very interesting after a devastating loss how would people put their lives back together how would communities get recreated the dog stars had very little of that as there were so few people i would say that this book is more about emotional rebuilding how does one individual rebuild after such a catastrophic loss i've read in a couple of places that this book is likely to become one of the classics of post apocalyptic fiction i suspect that's true

raw_text.2577: another post apocalyptic world represented in this story this time one in which a plague has wiped out most of humanity and left the rest with either debilitating side effects or a penchant for gruesome crime the author is a regular contributor to one of my favorite magazines outside and you can tell that he does indeed love the outdoors the novel reads like an ode to all things natural and beautiful which is a nice counter point to the ugly realities of this life the writing style takes a moment to get used to the first person narration is a little stilted and sometimes stops mid thought almost like how i imagine i would think after spending 9 years not really talking to anybody else the dearth of punctuation also kind of drove me nuts at times no really major plot twists or anything but a nice story of different kinds of love and perseverance

raw_text.2580: the dog stars has some of the most beautifully written prose in any book i've read this year flowing words almost poetry a lake like a gem set in a bezel of tufted tundra and rough scree the water green with the luminous unapologetic green of a semiprecous stone but textured with the wind and written in a style i rarely experience no dialog well of course there's dialog but not set apart not he said she said why then the 3 stars i debated over that quite awhile in the reading i kept running upon road kill those words that i spot and just have to look away i cannot write or speak them yes i'm a prudish old lady with deeply embedded christian ideas and proud of it so there went one star and then there were the horrors of the killings but understandable under the circumstances yes the killings were acceptable but not the cannabalisim or not exactly that what would be the term for feeding dead people to your pet dog i don't know but the idea didn't set well on my stomach so there went another star see i didn't even mention the expicit sex scenes i completely understand the sex and see that the author planned it to occur in a timely manner i was expecting that even before given the ages of the couple and especially since they didn't even know if any other males or females were alive completely natural althought i would have wished for less explicit desrption and more implying of the acts oh well in between the road kill human dog food and sex amazing writing sentence after sentence word after word of down to earth beauty heller has possibly written an award winner

raw_text.2589: mild spoiler i have a tendency to pick up the mood of a book i'm reading and this was no exception its sad it has a hopeless feel to it even with a relatively happy ending when i was reading it i felt sad and a little hopeless so i read it very quickly i read a review by someone else who said that she doesn't agree with the book and that after an apocalyptic event she doesn't believe only bad people would be left and they kill each other to defend what they have i agree with her belief that there would be good people left but i disagree with the idea that the book indicates otherwise the book to me was about a good person who loses everything and does his best to survive and maintain his sanity in a postapocalyptic world i think it is perfectly reasonable to assume you have to do bad things to survive probably not a book i need to read again but i enjoyed it there are some specific scenes that i will think about for a long time also i am not a pheasant the reading style took a bit to get used to it was disjointed i think to underscore the mental state of the narrator in places it was a heavy handed and made it difficult to follow the story in others it was brilliant and actually made the book

raw_text.2600: critics have compared "the dog stars" to cormac mccarthy's pulitzer prize winning dystopian novel "the road " that is justifiable but "dog stars" is a better book it is as bleak as "the road" in many ways but author heller offers rays of hope for his characters which makes "dog stars" more palatable i always felt mccarthy received the pulitzer for "the road" because he didn't get it for the much better "blood meridian" or any of the border trilogy books heller's style is as quirky as mccarthy's short paragraphs separated by wide chunks of white space choppy hemingwayesque prose alternating with poetic swoops constant unpunctuated veering between what is thought and what is said but the overall affect is just as effective "dog stars" is a fine novel

raw_text.2609: though i'm not sure what was expected when i began reading the dog stars i know now what was read was not what i had come to expect i didn't immediately enjoy it though as i progressed the pages definitely turned faster in the beginning it was inconvenient to follow hig's the narrator way of speaking this way of speaking comes from his brains being fried which was a result of a fever that resulted from a flu that wiped out most of the worlds population a minor annoyance came from getting used to the way of speaking and it not carrying throughout the book an event takes place roughly 30 percent into the book this event changes hig's perspective on things and he goes searching for a signal he heard three years back he leaves behind his estranged comrade who though crazy has basically kept hig alive we see that even nine years after the end of the world as they knew it people are still adjusting and searching for meaning in this new world the book as a whole starts off slow and until hig leaves erie i wasn't sure if this book would resonate with me in the end i found it quite enjoyable but not as much as i wanted to hellers way of delivering dialogue in this novel was refreshing it was perhaps my favorite part the novel was also refreshing because it was a nice change of pace from the end of the world zombie stories that currently plague our culture

raw_text.2614: while in a post apocalyptic setting this novel is set in time period immediately after when things haven't quite settled into a rhythm yet and authority or government is just a distant memory or dream there is no totalitarian government guarding against looting and every person you run across is more likely to kill you for what survival tools you have than try to make friends to survive with you we explore the emotions of hig who alone of his family and most of the population of colorado has survived the deadly flu outbreak he knows there are others around the world but with virtually no communication connecting with anyone else is pretty much impossible he remembers the loss of his wife the terror of the community as the knowledge of what was happening became apparent he is haunted by memories of what it has taken to survive after the disease has run its course he struggles between absolute survival which is the haven of his companion bengley and hanging on to threads of his humanity and compassion the desire to survive conflicts with the desire to connect it's one of the truest representations of what the end of the world as we know it would truly be like what we as human beings will sink to when faced with kill or be killed even while knowing that we are stronger together what is the price for holding on to survival what is dignity and humanity worth even the ending is a bit ambiguous as it truly would be surviving one danger does not rule out the next and the next and the next as we as humans have been dealing with since civilization began when rome fell there was a period of chaos but then slowly and surely civilization began again different from before but still with humans gathering into safer groups we see all the potential and all of the fear longing loss and hope how it happened ultimately does not matter what matters is how we carry on afterwards
raw_text.2615: i enjoyed almost everything about the dog stars great characters a smattering of big action scenes some quiet introspection a bit of sweeping philosophical pondering a nice little romance and just enough terror as far as post apocalyptic stories go heller's world isn't as horribly depressing as the one found in the road or as dangerous as the many zombie ridden futures where people are constantly fighting for survival still the main character hig finds himself living on a planet that is filled with a more realistic level of emotion boredom regret fear loneliness confusion anger love despair suffering survival awe revery and hope perhaps that reason i enjoyed the book so much is because it is so well rounded while most other books of the sort seem to approach the end of the world from only one or two of these lenses my main complaint about the book preventing me from giving it a five star rating in the beginning of the story hig has a distinct voice one that is muddled and confused by trauma and sickness his brain is a bit fried as the book progresses this voice sort of mellows out and becomes more normal now if his mind slowly began healing over the course of the book i saw no other evidence of it i liked the beginning of the book and even though the diction made it harder to read and i'm sure harder to write the story would have benefited from either staying in the original dialect or showing a more gradual progressive change as a side note i participate in world book night each year and the dog stars is the book i hope to give away this year i think all types of readers could enjoy it not just sci fi or post apocalypse lovers i strongly recommend giving this modern classic a read

here's an excerpt that might give you a flavor we were on the edge of a small basin above treeline and in the bottom were patches of old snow and a small lake recently cleared of ice a lake like a gem set in a bezel of tufted tundra and rough scree the water green with the luminous unapologetic green of a semiprecious stone but textured with the wind then it wasn't the surface stilled and glassed off polishing itself in an instant the water reflecting the dark clouds that massed and poured against the ridges like something molten and it was suddenly very cold and the snowflakes began to touch the surface ringless silent vanishing i let go the sled's bridle i was fifty yards from the water the snow heavier a white scrim that darkened the air that hastened the dusk the way a fire deepens the night i stood transfixed too cold for bare hands but my hands were bare the flakes struck in my eyelashes they fell on my sleeves huge flowers and stars they fell onto each other held their shapes became small piles of perfect asterisks and blooms tumbled together in their discrete geometries like children's blocks i don't know about you but with writing like that i don't even care if all hades is breaking loose around the characters at least they stop and smell the snowflakes now and again

raw_text.2625: there are books that i want to read but have no intention of ever actually reading these books have some appeal but in my short life i only get to read so many books so they shall forever remain on the bottom of the to read pile never to be read peter heller's the dog stars was one of these books it had too many strikes against it to be really good an established writer of non fiction trying his hand at fiction at the age of 53 a post apocalyptic story a protagonist who loves flying fishing and his dog a gun toting misanthrope if the publishing industry stopped printing books and i lived an extraordinarily long life i figured i'd get around to it eventually... maybe so with the publishing industry still going and my old age beginning to show why did i read the dog stars now bingo literally bingo i had to read a book with a blue cover for a reading bingo game i'd planned originally to fulfill this requirement with infinite jest but traipsing through those 1100 pages would certainly slow down my becoming reading bingo champion of the world and i want all the glory dammit the dog stars was nearby convenient and much shorter so i decided to give it a try don't worry joe--if i don't start infinite jest by mid year i give you permission to defriend me and take whatever action necessary to drag my name through the mud if hemingway had written a post apocalyptic novel i think it would've looked very similar to the dog stars our protagonist hig is built from the same mold as nick adams he likes the outdoors fishing and life that last one is important because keep in mind this is a very very dark world it bears great similarity to the world of cormac mccarthy's the road in fact aside from one world being warm and the other being very cold i can think of no other difference so yes this is a savage book but it also has heart hig may be the last man in the world capable of compassion but at least he exists i liked the dog stars much more than i had anticipated especially during the first half of the novel i was drawn in the world heller has crafted is probably the most realistic post apocalyptic world i've seen in literature obviously i cannot say what the world will be like after "the apocalypse"--maybe there really will be zombies white horses human sacrifice dogs and cats living together--but this story hummed with a realism i felt the first half of the novel is five stars all the way unfortunately the second half didn't quite work the same for me the world still felt real but there was something mildly artificial about the story hig spent much too much time in location b discovering himself and... well i wasn't able to get back on track from that point on nevertheless i largely enjoyed the novel i've never walked away from such a dark world and said "i wish i could spend more time there " moral of the review never say never
raw_text.2626: wow as a general rule i don't enjoy post apocalyptic novels where roving bands of survivors are picking one another off in an inevitable march to the end of all human life but somehow heller puts that in the background of a remarkable and beautiful story of love loss and hope he is a beautiful writer who conveys memorable images with spare and well chosen language i regret that i finished it too fast

raw_text.2628: i love apocalypse stories the the dog stars is theoretically right up my alley unfortunately while the premise is interesting and full of potential the book ultimately doesn't deliver the 'riveting powerful' read promised by the publisher's blurb hig is a fairly well drawn character and his relationship with jasper is sweet and compelling but the rest of the characters are really just sketches of people with no really depth they seem to exist primarily give hig someone s other than jasper to interact with in a lot of ways the dog stars is a post post apocalypse story when we pick up the story the majority of the population has succumbed to a virulent flu and the violence that one would expect to come hand in hand with such a fundamental breakdown in social structure has largely petered out descriptions of past incidents and current threats attempt to inject the story with a sense of dread or danger but i never really felt that the characters were at risk given the timeline of the story this wouldn't be a problem if i didn't get the impression that i was meant to feel that sense of danger this lack of dramatic tension imminent threat is especially problematic when hig leaves the airport to chase after the years old radio message he heard in grand junction he encounters some token danger but ultimately everything on the trip comes so easily to him it stretches the suspension of disbelief too far he never has any trouble landing the plane he's shot at but not hit the people he meets are not only friendly but one of them is a widowed woman as interested in him as he is in her she's a med student they want to return to the airport with him which ultimately ensures both that he gets back alive and that bangley is saved it's all just too convenient and it really detracted from my enjoyment of what could have been a really interesting look at what happens to people who've lived through an apocalypse and come out the other side ultimately the dog stars is 'apocalypse light' not a lot of blood mayhem or tension to upset the sensibilities of more delicate readers while this may ensure it appeals to a wider audience it also makes for a story that just isn't as good as it should have been

raw_text.2636: peter heller's hig is something of a cousin to cormac mccarthy's survivor from the road each wandering through his respective post apocalyptic landscape and longing for a world that once was a world inhabited by a wife and possibly more importantly trout seriously as soon as i heard hig longing for a creek and some line i thought of some of the final words in the road once there were brook trout in the streams in the mountains the men are definitely related hig's apocalypse is a bit more forgiving than the other guy's however as at least some animals are still alive dogs deer hawks carp even bears and ash doesn't constantly drift down like snow also like mccarthy heller uses a lot of sentence fragments and sometimes disregards capitalization and punctuation the unmaking of the world writ small in the dissolution of grammar but i liked both books and though the dog stars feels like a shadow of the road it's a lighter shadow like mccarthy's story took the full brunt of the nuclear glare and heller's is tempered a bit

raw_text.2672: this book utterly blew me away i heard it recommended by a few people and finally got a copy in short this book was amazing fast exciting read but with a careful well paced philosophical and psychological message that spans the entire book it's written in an odd 1st person with extremely short widely spaced paragraphs that make it easy to charge through it there is some confusion due to the fact that he never uses quotation marks around dialogue and often employs creative use of periods but this actually adds to the experience rather than subtracts it can be hard to tell when he's thinking and what he's saying out loud and i think it's an excellent reflection of the impact of long term semi isolation this does get frustrating during long conversations when you're unsure who's talking but it's not worth lowering the score also if p g wodehouse can do it so can peter heller this is a book about friendship dealing with loss isolation survival and savoring life also an airplane and a dog and also guns the main character hig is a pilot who lives at a small abandoned rural airport in colorado with his dog jasper and an odd survivalist bangley 99 99% of the world's population has been killed off by a virus and the remnants are trying to get by bangley and hig and jasper help each other defend the airport while hig flies patrols to catch attackers looking for plunder before they can get close then one day he gets a radio signal the first he's heard since the virus coming from an airport just outside his point of no return i'll leave it at that seriously just go read it it took me maybe 3 sittings though to be fair they were long sittings since i was so engrossed if you like apocalyptic fiction but are sick of zombies or you like reading books about friendship yet think this needs a cessna and a sniper rifle i absolutely recommend this book

raw_text.2694: a post apocalyptic book club selection the author is a writer for magazines like national geographic adventure so i know i've probably read some of his writing before he concentrates on outdoor u0026amp adventure writing so the whole post apocalyptic survival thing seems to come naturally i felt that may of the details of flying a small plane traveling through the wilds etc felt like personal experience and lent a sense of reality to the book the writing style is a very stream of consciousness flow which varies depending on the emotional state of the narrator i felt it was done very well there seems to be a big trend in the post apocalyptic genre toward non standard language usage and it often annoys me see the road the book of dave but i just fell into this and went with it as far as the plot well there are a lot of familiar elements the holed up in a safe place trope the fighting off mad gangs the survivalist trek the dealing with plagues all that good stuff two men have teamed up to try to survive in a violent world one has a small plane one has weapons expertise and is almost psychotically defensively violent they've been doing well or at least as well as can be expected they're alive but when the pilot's aging dog dies he sets out on an almost surely doomed expedition to try to find the source of a mysterious radio broadcast he'd heard years before in addition to the expected though there are also some really original and interesting elements here i really liked some of the characterizations i saw the book as a musing on what people need to survive and an exploration of the theory that compassion must balance aggression but that both are needed and essential parts of humanity
raw_text.2695: it seems as if another day brings another post apocalyptic book the dog stars is in a class of its own flu pandemic has killed off most of the world's inhabitants people and animals alike it is nine years after the outbreak and there are pockets of survivors struggling to live in a world where all the rules have changed hig and bangley are two such men who have formed an uneasy alliance with each other they live on an abandoned airfield in denver they scrape by and care of what they have even if it means shoot first and shoot to kill hig is our narrator we see everything through his eyes he is the moral compass of the book remembering his past life and questioning his current existence bangley is far more pragmatic we don't learn much about him but he has no problem defending his home against all intruders the world may be coming to an end but he will go down swinging most of the book is written in a stream of consciousness style there is very little dialogue because there is no one for hig to talk to except for bangley and hig's beloved dog jasper sometimes thoughts aren't completed or go off in tangents much like most of our inner conversations this is a style that can be hit or miss in this case it works and i think that is due to the writing poetic and beautiful in equal measure this is a book you should not know too much about before reading so i don't want to go into details about the storyline it is a book that is dark it's hard to write about the end of the world and not be dark but it has humor and humanity there is compassion and there is hope many reviews i have read compare the book to cormac mccarthy's "the road" i have not read that book so i cannot comment although i believe that this book is not quite as bleak i also believe that one of the best aspects of the story is to make us wonder what we would do in the same circumstances most of us would like to think we are good and possibly noble but when it comes down to it just how far would you go to survive i was sorry this book came to an end i cried a couple of times and i have thought of the story and the people in it often always the sign of a good book read it you won't regret it

raw_text.2756: again i find myself wishing that i could give this book 3 5 stars the dog stars is a meaningful and thought provoking story about who you can rely on besides your dog when the shit hits the fan the answer of course is very few people maybe even just one such is the case for this story's odd couple big hig and bangley big hig and his dog jasper scout the perimeter on foot and by plane make supply runs visit a group of afflicted survivors living peacefully nearby sleep outdoors under the stars keeping watch hunt and tend the garden bangley is the eye in the sky the sniper at the ready the protector and the voice always reminding hig he must never let his guard down while their relationship is far from warm they share a trust that is rare in a world turned upside down by flu blood disease and climate change it works but can it be enough hig must decide between addressing his loneliness and unanswered questions and his current routine and repetitive existence that is his means of safety and physical bodily self preservation between running his plane around the perimeter and returning to his stores of fuel or filling her up and flying to the end of the line the nuts and bolts hig's broken narration is effective at conveying his fogginess a result of both his own bout with the flu and his subsequent isolation the details of colorado by foot and by plane are nostalgic for me and well appointed for the uninitiated there is enough sadness fear and brutality for the book to take you on a ride but wraps up neatly with a dose of beauty and hope but in the end i may have found the dog stars a touch boring

raw_text.2764: i love a good post apocalyptic tale and the dog stars is a fine one a flu has wiped out much of the country leaving survivors to fend for themselves and to fend off one another hig lost his wife in the epidemic and for nine years has survived with his dog and neighbor a survivalist with a mean streak and accurate aim hig goes on recon flights in his 1950s era cessna and one day hears a radio call from an airport far away in his attempt to chase down the originator of the call leads him to a discovery that will change him for as long as he's able to survive heller contrasts the bleakness and violence of the setting with a soulful humanity in the person of hig and puts them both in the service of a story that is at once taut and warm quickly paced and beautifully rendered

raw_text.2768: wow this is a beautiful lyrical perfect novel it's definitely one of the best post apocalyptic novels i've read to date peter heller's writing soars like the plane his character hig drives i'll bet he's written and read a lot of poetry a book like the dog stars is the reason i read so much to find a beautiful gem of a story that distills the essence of what it means to be human in the 21st century and what really really matters in life thank you peter heller here's an excerpt so you can see this for yourself "funny how you can live a whole life waiting and not know it " she spoke as she lifted a pile of greens from a bowl of peapods we sat at the table in the shade of the big trees "waiting for your real life to begin maybe the most real thing 'the end' to realize that when it's too late i know now that that i loved him more than anything on earth or off of it more than god the one in my episcopal liturgy " she snapped the early peas her hair hanging in her face the backs of her hands blotched purple with blood her finger tips worked gingerly as if sore they rolled a particularly tough pod back to the knuckles of thumb and forefinger "he died calling for me looking desperately around the ward calling my name confused very early on before all the networks went down and my friend joel the doctor who ran the wing called me before we knew what this was ""my mother was dying and it was too late to fly back home to new york too late and i made the decision to stay with her and dad joel said he would cremate tomas and hold the ashes i was beyond grateful it was apparent that my mother would not survive i would fly home in a week or two and drive upstate and spread his ashes in john's brook up the in the mountains outside keene valley were we spent every weekend we could... "we stayed in a white clapboard cottage in the village with a view of noonmark from the sleeping porch that's a little adirondack mountain that looks like a parody of a mountain very peaky like the matterhorn but tiny the little mountain that could we climbed it often on saturdays after sleeping in trotted happily up the ledgy trail to a rocky top just out of the stunted firs and in the long evening we'd take the two single gear bikes up the paved road to a stone pothole with a little sluicing waterfall the water always freezing and we'd strip and jump in this was our ritual while we waited for our lives to truly begin and i think now that only true sweetness can happen in limbo i don't know why is it because we are so unsure so tentative waiting like it needs that much room that much space to expand the not knowing anything really the hoping the aching transience this is not real not really and so we let it alone let it unfold lightly those times that can fly that's the way it seems now looking back like those pleasantly exhausted bike rides up the side of a country highway on a warm evening to a bridge to a little root snaked trail through heavy maples where we padded barefoot upstream to a swimming hole even getting poison ivy so badly one weekend i missed two days of work seems from here that that was the sweetest time ever vouch safe to two people ever on earth while we waited for him to finish his degree or for me to have a child to do the real work of living " she looked up "we are fools" you know... once in passing she told me that she didn't expect to live passed 50 or 55 from what she knew of the damage caused to organs by the fever she also confessed that in an odd way she was happier here than she'd ever been even with all the loss happier 'being' whatever that was than waiting "

raw_text.2775: the dog stars is a post pandemic novel told in the first person by the protagonist hig as he goes about the task of surviving and attempting to remain a semblance of humanity in a violent world the book is clearly semi autobiographical hig being a thinly disguised version of heller himself also a pilot and fisherman the writing style like the character's thoughts is somewhat fragmented which some may find annoying but i quickly became used to it despite the fact that i don't think it served any real purpose or even the purpose heller probably intended ... to convey a sense of shattered personality the story itself is pretty good with some nice action sequences though there were a few things that stuck out as odd in the canyon with cima and her dad with their only water source a stream drying out hig baths up canyon in a pool after 9 years of survival he doesn't know enough to keep fecal coli form out of his drinking water there's a dramatic take off from a short runway yet for some reason he brings a woman cima and 2 goats along with him only to land and pick up cima's dad why didn't he leave them all on the ground to save weight makes no sense as the plane takes off from a short runway hig exclaims "praise god " gratuitously and unnecessarily the scene was oddly out of place and clashed with the rest of the story hig brings cima and her dad and 2 goats with him to get gas for his plane so he can fly back home a route which takes him right past their dwelling there was no reason to bring them it would have made more sense to have gone for gas himself and picked them up on the way back heller casts the dog jasper in a heroic role and in the title of the book and associates cats with the evil doer's who set up a trap for his plane all i can say is ... cats have taken over the internet they've won dogs have lost ... suck it up heller also the cat stars would have been a better title
raw_text.2776: while this book merits the numerous comparisons with cormac mccarthy's the road heller's post apocalyptic near future is even more plausible at least for someone living in the west with its beetle distressed trees seemingly endless drought and constant wildfire smoke hovering on the summer horizon while the plot focuses on a post pandemic flu way of life it is the characters expertly rendered and well rounded that drive the novel forward especially the yin and yang of hig and bangley an odd couple that has set up a home of sorts at an abandoned airport heller's sparse fluid prose is channeled through the quirky voice of narrator hig and the story is his emotional and physical journey through the altered landscapes of both his dream world and the new reality of a sparsely populated always dangerous west
raw_text.2777: america has been ravaged by pandemic plague a super flu society has collapsed and the few survivors have fallen into lawless savagery amidst the turmoil hig and his dog jasper search for a life worth living haunted by memories of his lost wife and forced into an uneasy alliance with a survivalist gunsmith hig seeks solace in short flights aboard his small cessna plane until a mysterious radio transmission leads him on a journey across state lines into the unknown the dog stars is far from your average postapocalyptic survival novel while the flu and its effects permeate every corner of the book the real treat here is in hig's emotional life he's a sympathetic well drawn character just an average guy who nine years after the plague still struggles with his feelings of loss and despair hig's trips into the foothills to hunt and fish are among the highlights of this novel peter heller's descriptions of the natural world are beautiful spare and poetic while many postapocalyptic books focus on adventure the prevailing mood here is loneliness the same ache for human connection that we can feel before or after the fall of society great read reviewed by walker e the dog stars on linkcat

raw_text.2788: i took this book with me on a flight to the midwest appropriate as the protagonist is a small airplane pilot and much of the action takes place in and around vintage airplanes this novel has particular appeal for flyers for men who like action stories with lots of weapons lovingly detailed and for those of us who have experienced the special sort of salvation that only having a close animal companion can provide the novel describes a dark stark and stripped down future world but unlike most post apocalyptic fiction it won't make you want to put your head in the oven or jump off tall deserted buildings the story centers on human beings doing what we somehow always do continuing to struggle and survive in the remains of a civilization brought down by a decimating virus the recently invented bug hasn't stopped at wiping out the requisite one tenth of the population it has weakened and killed so many more that everyone left is reduced to sheer survival mode those who have been spared by the virus generally fit the cynical notions we have regarding the species most of them are either desperately lacking in survival skills or brutally ruthless and unscrupulous the rest so far as we know are our heroes in the narrative characters other than the protagonist are perhaps not as fully modeled as the average reader might like but the novel is heavy on narrative at which the author excels and each persona becomes better known and better liked as one reads between the lines of dialogue it isn't a spoiler to reveal that the most likable character is killed off halfway through the story everything that transpires thereafter is entertaining perhaps enough so that you won't want to put down the book but the narrative takes on a special poignancy because as the main character puts it it all happened because my dog died
raw_text.2789: after a slow and thoughtful buildup this novel really does take off and leaves you hanging on for more i was initially bothered by the abrupt and stunted narrative and the slow pace of the story told from hig's pov one of few survivors of the pandemic that wiped out the planet the opening chapters are full of clipped sentences and hig's stream of consciousness melting back and forth from present and past however i quickly realized that hig was one of two survivors in the immediate vicinity the other being bangley a gun toting trigger happy fellow and had been for nine years after all that time what's the point of full sentences i think peter heller did a brilliant job of making the reader feel the bleakness and desolation of hig's circumstances in the post pandemic world by using the absence of language the first half of the book is slow but you do get to learn a lot about hig and bangley and their stories before and after the pandemic the second half of the book brought hope and desire and a feeling that these survivors were becoming alive again after years of loneliness and terror hig's relationship with cima was raw and at once painful and joyful i think the true beauty of this book lay in the second half but i thoroughly enjoyed it all

raw_text.2798: excelent book actually done on audio the book is set after most of humanity is killed by a flu virus then something called 'the blood' both highly contagious and fatal the main character hig is a survivor he and his dog jasper live in a hangar at an abandoned airport in western colorado sometimes they fish in the mountains where the air is cooler and the trees are alive their only neighbor bangley lives in a house abandoned 10 years earlier hig fuels his 1956 cessna from the airport's pumps he flies produce from his garden to "the families " a group of people with the contagious blood disease bangley has an arsenal in his fortified house and spends his time guarding against strangers who show up hig often feels guilty when he helps bangley fight off invaders when hig's life suddenly changes due to the death of his dog he goes to explore another part of the state he flies over dead cities forests and farmland then he finds a hidden canyon inhabited by an old man who shoots the windows out of the cessna forcing hig to land hig talks his way into the area and meets the man and his daughter six weeks later all three decide they must leave because the only source of water is drying up this story sounds dreary and it is it's also suspenseful full of action and hope and a love story heller's writing style is almost poetic but is a bit difficult initially much of it is in phrases not sentences then you realize it's hig talking to himself recording his solitary thoughts

raw_text.2802: it says in the author info on the back of the audio edition that i listened to that this is heller's first novel although it also indicates that he is a contributing editor at several magazines and has written several nonfiction books a first novel of this quality is still an achievement heller picks up what may seem a well worn thread in devising a post apocalyptic novel perhaps it is because as a teacher i am so aware of young adult literature perhaps it's because of the exposure mccarthy's the road got before and after winning the pulitzer a few years ago but the dystopia post apocalyptic setting led me to wait on the dog stars for awhile however heller handles the setting well never letting it dominate the story he's telling which is one far more universal and far less a dire warning about some current political or other situation human activity than it is a comment on the underlying savagery all too close to the surface in even the seemingly most gentle human beings the pains of loss and the strangeness of love relationships and family heller doesn't waste a whole lot of time indicating what exactly caused the destruction of our own civilization painting broad strokes of a super flue followed by an autoimmune plague but neither is ever fully explored in fact i was quite grateful that the one mention of potential causes view spoiler alluding to at least the possibility of government culpability in the release of the virus hide spoiler was relatively unexplored i've seen too many novels that made use of the cause hinted at and not just lately heller does a good job here of making the story a very personal and specific one stumbling on one of the paradoxical truths of art that the more specific the story recounted the more universal it can be made to appear heller eschews the big national worldwide thriller angle for a very focused story about a particular survivor the man in question whose name is hig is an idealist just practical and violent enough to survive with the help of a former soldier more suited to the violent post apocalyptic world in which the story takes place who can't quite make himself fit in to the cold harsh practicalities of the world he now lives in one of the manners in which heller individualizes the text and plays with the writing in a manner critics have solidly praised is to write the novel in first person present tense and whenever the novel is not in scene to slip into a kind of stream of consciousness this has been hinted at by several reviewers here and elsewhere with predictably mixed results i found it a bit jarring at first as stream of consciousness often is if done well the interior of one's mind doesn't naturally lend itself to communication to others terribly well that's a good part of why we often screw up our ever our conscious efforts so badly but having settled in i found myself comfortably ensconced in hig's head and thoroughly enjoyed the ride it must be said though that this style does not lend itself to an audiobook even one like the production i listened to with a fine reader i believe mark deakins gave as good a performance as the text would allow without serious modification but the choppy nature of the stream of consciousness elements made for a very strange effect when read aloud it often felt as if deakins was reading at a pace slower than the slowest of all southern drawls and at times with less coherence it was nearly enough to make me decide to wait and read the novel rather than listen to it but after an adjustment i was able to settle in and enjoy the novel heller's skill overcoming this minor deficiency this is a relatively slow book despite its slimness for one accustomed to reading the gigantic novels commonly published in fantasy and science fiction such as myself it comfortably ambles along at a literary novel's slow pace although it also has its moments of tension and very direct combat heller maintains a sense of urgency and danger by fulfilling his own predictions that combat might arise to engulf the characters at any point and for no particular reason the novel does not settle for an easy resolved ending in which civilization seems on the mend and it is better for it however it also avoids the pit of despair that so many literary dystopias fall into suggesting that under even the worst conditions it is possible to carve out a happy life so why four stars rather than five well the audio issues that i mentioned above and unfortunately what felt to me like a gratuitous excessive use of f k yes i'm an adult i know how people speak i know that in moments of high stress it can be both realistic and justified for a person to use strong language still while most other swearing was relatively minimal it felt this particular word was thrown around far more freely at least then i encounter it day to day and a notch beyond that when it comes to my comfort level it was deadened by overuse here and grated on this reader's ears i still finished the book gladly and still gave it four out of five stars still a warning to those sensitive to such language there's enough to make you a bit twitchy uncomfortable here

raw_text.2816: wow the dog stars by peter heller is an amazing book i loved it but i don't know if i could read it again because it is emotionally wrenching and has left me feeling out of sorts the way the tiger's wife did this is a lovely beautifully written poignant story of a man trying to keep his humanity despite living through the end of the world as he knows it the narrator's name is hig he lives in an abandoned small airport near denver with jasper his dog and bangley his fellow survivor hig has a small plane that he uses to survey the area for intruders gather supplies and help a family of mennonites who are afflicted with the blood disease that struck after the flu pandemic this is a post apocalyptic world in which other humans are automatically assumed to be attackers and the proper response is to kill or be killed human kindness is in short supply even bangley hig's companion is no comfort bangley is a taciturn angry man who takes delight in surviving in killing the humans who stumble into their area bangley is right of course--these other humans will kill them if they can but hig is uncomfortable with killing this is a story of their day to day survival and hig's quest to make human contact it's also suspenseful and full of adventure and as soon as i opened the book i forgot about the outside world heller's prose often comes in short abrupt spurts which i at first i found jarring but as i got drawn into the book i realized why heller wrote like that and the abruptness had a certain rhythm to it then he would write long paragraphs that are almost poetic in their use of imagery while i don't want to give away the whole story of the book i'm going to quote some long passages that may hint at things that have happened so this is your spoiler alert here is hig contemplating the possibility that someone may be alive at an airport tower he passed by while flying the beast his plane and wondering if it even matters "the old excitement of a trip a real trip meaning new country surge of optimism don't know why bangley is right the odds of any useful news are low the odds of the man in the tower being a skeleton high and what news is useful i've asked myself that every day in the week since what is news we eat we sleep we secure the perimeter we defend ourselves i go up into the mountains sometimes to get the news of the creeks and the trees from the beast the news of the wind what else is there " 148 heller describes the pain of loss eloquently and this passage gets me every time "there is a pain you can't think your way out of you can't talk it away if there were someone to talk to you can walk one foot the other foot breathe in breathe out...and you can't metabolize the loss it is in the cells of your face your chest behind the eyes in the twists of your gut muscle sinew bone it is all of you when you walk you propel it forward when you let go the sled and sit on a fallen log and not feeling well then it sits with you the pain puts its arm over your shoulders it is your closest friend steadfast and at night you can't bear to hear your own breath unaccompanied by another and underneath the big stillness like a score is the roaring of the cataract of everything being and being torn away then the pain is lying beside your side close does not bother you with the sound even of breathing" 114 heller manages to convey the extraordinary sense of loss and grief that hig is feeling now--he is at this moment utterly alone--more alone than he's ever been since the world went to hell and his wife died from the pandemic this book is so well written that i don't just identify with hig in his despair i am hig and i feel what he feels despite the sense of desolation loneliness and grief that fills the book it does have moments of humor and optimism and a sense of happiness and hope no matter how fleeting i don't want to say this is a book about the ultimate survival of the human spirit or something so trite as humanity and kindness do ultimately win but as hig wonders for how long "still some nights i grieved i grieved as much at what i knew must be the fleeting nature of my present happiness as any loss any past we lived on some edge if we ever lived on a rolling plain who knew what attack what illness that doubleness again like flying the stillness and the speed serenity and danger the way we could gobble up space in the beast and seem to barely move that sense of being in a painting" 311

raw_text.2818: i'm a super fan of post apocalyptic schlock fiction zombies viruses emps whatever i'll take it i wasn't sure how i would find an actual literary work about life on earth after a super flu event i guess trepidation sums it up i so wanted to like this book but i was worried that it may end up on what has lately become an ever increasing pile of books i simply do not finish reading things got off to a rocky start heller begins the book using some sort of bizarre sentence structure thing that i'm sure was meant to convene some meaning better understood by readers whose sense of what makes appropriate dialog in a novel was not developed by reading stephen king what an i say erudite book snobs need not apply to join my reading club anyway i put the book down for a few days to polish off some previously started vampire fiction and when i returned to the dogs stars low and behold i couldn't put it down i don't know what changed but the story grabbed me but good i was one burned out battery in my reading light from staying up all night and finishing this sucker i loved the story i loved the characters i nearly loved it all at times heller's life as a nature writer tends to sneak in and dominate the story i myself love trout fishing and yet some of heller's passages about the joy of fishing and the therapeutic results of fishing an isolated stream left me feeling bored and nearly put me into scan reading mode please don't let that stop you from reading this book go get it today and enjoy after all who knows when a super flu will wipe out 99 9% of the population
