raw_text.2833: in the near future a virus rapidly sweeps through the human population followed by a horrific blood disease killing almost everyone hig was one of the few survivors his wife died his friends died everyone he knew is gone nine years later hig lives in a hanger at an abandoned airport with his dog jasper the airport is one of the few places remaining with sustainable power wind and solar energy and water from a nearby creek also there is plenty of fuel for hig's small plane a 1956 cessna together with his only friend and neighbor bangley a survivalist with an arsenal of weapons they patrol the perimeter and guard against other survivors who would attack and kill them for their supplies one day while hig is flying his plane he catches a short radio transmission and then it's gone is someone else out there hig wants to find out but to get closer to where the signal originated hig must fly beyond the half way point the point where he will have enough fuel to return to the hanger he decides the trip is not feasible a short time later something happens to change his mind and hig believes it will be worth it to try the story is narrated by hig we experience his world as he relates it in the present tense this is a reality filled with loss and pain and sorrow he dreams of the past and of his wife his dog is his best friend and co pilot he has a garden that he tends with love and care the world he lives in is both bleak and at times beautiful sometimes funny too often sad but he still has some glimmer of hope for the future the book is written in a very free form stream of consciousness style jumping from one thought to another often leaving sentences incomplete and with little punctuation i thought this would be disorienting but it wasn't it fit the style of the story perfectly and in no time i was right there with hig experiencing his world and feeling his loneliness but for all the sadness and loss this is not a depressing book there is also action adventure a little romance and possibilities i would have liked to know a little more about hig's world i always want more world building but we were provided enough detail to make most readers happy the story starts a little slow in the beginning but by the second half i was flying through the pages i wasn't ready for this book to end and while i was satisfied with the ending i still wanted more i loved this book and recommend it to everyone even those who don't usually read dystopian fiction it's not your typical post apocalyptic story there are no vampires robots or zombies just a wonderful heart warming story about what it's like to be human in the face of adversity definitely one of my top ten for the year

raw_text.2849: usually when i write a review for a book i try to avoid revealing major plot points there is nothing really worse than if you happen to be scanning reviews to see if a book is right for you when your eyes stumble upon something like dumbledore dies unfortunately for the dog stars i cannot write a spoiler free review but for those of you out there that have read it or don't really give a shit if something is spoiled for you then please continue reading i promise a fun time will be had to all on to the review little known fact about myself i never cry while watching movies or while reading books i mean i am that person who is laughing during the scene in finding neverland where john depp's character is holding kate winslet's hand and watching her and she passes on to the other side i'm basically a soulless monster when it comes to things of that sort but there is one thing that will make me tear up like a drunken girl on prom night stories with a dog as a major character let's be honest people i have read enough of these stories to know that the dog always dies in the end always who doesn't ball till their tear ducts run dry when that adorable and clever dog sacrifices its life to save a child's nobody so you can understand my reluctance to reading the dog stars at first i knew at some point that hig's dog jasper was going to die i just wasn't sure how but that damn peter heller is full of surprises in fact the whole book is really nothing like the summary don't even bother reading it because it won't give you the insight to the inspiring prose that was composed like a 300 page poem so the premise to the dog stars is a depressing one the summary is correct in this instance hig is a survivor of a worldwide pandemic and now society is basically one big lawless town in any western film a shoot first talk later kind of deal he lives in an airplane hangar with is old dog jasper and a psychopath named bangley who will do anything to survive like gun down anyone who gets near their home to me this premise sounded a lot like the road by cormac mccarthy apocalypse check a strange and fruitless journey in which the main character searches for better life check lots of murder climb aboard the murder train no quotation marks so the reader is easily confused during lengthy dialog check plus but somehow this is so much better than the road the road never made me cry in a public place within the first 100 pages that's right the dog dies in the first act the road never once made me laugh out loud in an inappropriate setting and garner angry looks both sorrow and laughter are qualities i admire in a good story because who doesn't just need a little cry over a fictional dog every once and a while "the difference maybe between the living and the dead the living often want to be numb but the dead never do if they never want anything " -hig in the dog stars

raw_text.2856: this was a stunningly beautiful and sad yet hopeful read i absolutely enjoyed every page heller's descriptions are wrought with such emotion and allow the moment to live and breathe one of my favorite passages is hig's description of flying and how the landscape looks from above the way the earth below resolves the way the landscape falls into place around the drainages the capillaries and arteries of falling water mountain slopes bunched and wrinkled wringing themselves into the furrows of couloir and creek draw and chasm the low places defining the spurs and ridges and foothills the way creases define the planes of a face lower down the canyon cuts and then the swales and valleys of the lowest slopes the sinuous rivers and the dry beds where water used to run seeming to hold the hills and the waves of the high plains all together and not the other way around the wat settlements sprawl and then congregatenat these rivers and mass at every confluence i thought it's a view that should surprise us but it doesn't we have seen it before and interpret the terrain below with the same ease we walk the banks of a creek and know where to place our feet 49 there are many more beautiful passages that describe hig's loneliness that are so poignant but i don't want to give away any part of this book to future readers

raw_text.2887: peter heller's 'the dog stars' is one of the best books that i've read in a long long time similar in theme and language to cormac mccarthey's 'the road' but for the most part without the harrowing darkness 'the dog stars' is a post apocalyptic thriller that also works as a ruminating character study the protagonist hig his dog jasper and deadly friend bangley struggle to survive on an earth devastated by a pandemic flu that has wiped out most of the population in his small engine cessna hig patrols the skies above the compound home that he and bangley have built to keep away the bands of marauding and murderous denizens that populate the landscape when hig decides to follow a random broadcast that comes across his planes radio he flies past the point of no return into a new life changing adventure contemplative and poetic yet with scattered and thrilling scenes of action 'the dog stars' was a hard book to put down and one that i was sad to finish highly recommended

raw_text.2894: dog stars by peter heller was another book that i had seen on spring lists but been hesitant about it's a post apocalyptic story and after reading the road i felt that i had already explored that vision pretty thoroughly after hearing heller speak at ala though i jumped right in line to get a free signed copy of his book librarians do get some nice benefits on occasion dog stars is the story of a man who loses everything - wife home society - after a plague kills most of the world population he survives along with a half crazy companion at an abandoned airfield where he pilots a cessna and keeps track of the possible invaders of his perimeter he has his dog his memories and maintains his humanity despite many attacks but at a turning point in the book he goes off in search of more dog stars was thoughtful poetic intriguing and not without hope heller began his career as an adventure sport writer and his love of the natural world comes though clearly during his talk he shared with us that he felt the need to research the possibility of a pandemic that could kill 90% of the world's population he says he first asked a friend at the cdc about it who answered "no it's not possible even the worst have only killed a fraction of the population " unsatisfied he called a contact who worked for the government who replied "you mean like a genetically altered virus yes i'd say that's a possibility " heller said he then froze clearly understanding that it had already been made and was simply sitting in a incubator ... waiting

raw_text.2896: in the dog stars the "old rules" are done we're in colorado and it's post apocalypse and w'ere with hig and bangley at an abandoned airstrip near denver hig is our narrator a survivor of a major pandemic that has left resources scarce and left behind a world where it's every man for himself "old rules are done hig " this is bangley talking but heller uses no quote marks in the book "went the way of the woodpecker gone with the glaciers and the government new world now new world new rules never ever negotiate " bangley is the grizzled older tough guy and weapons nut who is merciless when it comes to watching out for numero uno hig is more sensitive reflective type--more apt to head into the countryside for a fishing trip with his dog jasper--but finds it with himself to kill when it's needed thinks hig "life and death lived inside each other that's what occurred to me death was inside all of us waiting for warmer nights a compromised system a beetle as in the now dying black timber on the mountains and life was inside death virulent and insistent as a strain of flu how it should be "the first third of the book is about hig and bangley gathering resources to keep their "world" going including fending off attackers and defending their corner of the bleak landscape in the middle third hig flies to western colorado in hopes of finding a voice on the other end of a radio transmission in the last section hig first must find a way to avoid getting shot by a rancher and his daughter who treat hig at first the way he has treated others slowly hig ingratiates himself into the small farm finds himself drawn to beautiful and alluring daughter cima hig helps them escape and then okay don't want to type "spoiler alert " but the love story at the end here--significantly between a healthy man and a healthy woman--distinguishes the dog stars from the road heller's prose is light breezy and wonderfully poetic he uses a choppy brisk and nearly pixilated approach to descriptions "younger than or not leaner white haired hard like shoe leather creases creased lines deep from cheeks down grimace lines spray of creases from corners of the eyes outside corners gray eyes sparking "but the style varies in the airplane flying west "drop down and follow the fraser past tabernash most of the valley burned except the firehouse and the discount liquor store which now stands alone at the edge of a field full of bighorn sheep they rouse swing and trot in a panic toward the blackened forest as i pass and i see four wolves standing out of the grass and they turn them back like sheepdogs fly on "heller is a pilot and his knowledge here plays a nifty role in helping make the return trip to the front range the flying sequences are powerful i can imagine hundreds of fascinating book club discussions debating whether the dog stars envisions a world we should all fear--and perhaps do something now to avoid ok i'd vote for a plan of action now the central question is what is a good man going to do how will he act how will he behave when all the rules have changed

raw_text.2899: there are very many things to like about peter heller's the dog stars it's a rich tale even if it is not that original i mean there are plenty of post apocalyptic sagas out there that chronicle the hard lives of the planet's last remaining survivors except for cormac mccarthy's the road however most of them take on mad max dimensions heller though has done something different he's written a touching story about the need for human companionship about the tragedy of loss and about the very real need for all of us to love and to be loved it's intersperesed with touching descriptive prose and supplemented by the very deep emotional development of hig and his suporting cast and it's even better because of the fast paced plot with any number of twists and turns a really nice read a couple of things i didn't much like that kept this from getting five stars one was the kind of odd somewhat post modern decision to put spacing between each paragraph i really have no clue what purpose that served and it just kept annoying me also bothersome was the reference at the very end of the book to the fact that the arab tribe may have survived that felt like a gratuitous slap but maybe it was meant for something else finally peter end you novel with your own words not someone else's poem

raw_text.2910: i always feel like a bit bad when i abandon a book i quite often keep reading even if i'm hating it and i'll very rarely stop before page 100 and i've made it to the end of some truly awful books i kept going with the dog stars until the end of part i 137 pages in i couldn't face part ii i can recognise that this novel is a thing of beauty i appreciated its heart and it's possible that it could have dragged me in completely the problem was that i couldn't get past the language it was so difficult to read punctuation came and went without any regard for the rules i've heard one reviewer lament the absence of quotation marks when someone speaks which is one of my pet hates but there were so many other liberties taken with the language that i hardly noticed that particular one i found it so distracting that it became too much of a chore i continually lost the rhythm as i reread passages to work out what the author was trying to say it's not as if the language didn't make sense the narrator was a poet who now lives in a world which has been decimated physically by climate change and who is one of the few healthy survivors of a deadly pandemic poetry can legitimately live by its own punctuation rules so he was probably like that beforehand and now he's probably worse because he's out of practice communicating even still i didn't like it it seems strange to give this 2 stars if i didn't finish it it's because i recognise that behind the written word is a haunting story that i simply couldn't reach others will and it's for them that i recommend it i personally wish i hadn't picked it up though it's made me feel like a terrible failure

raw_text.2915: yes this book takes place in a post apocalyptic post pandemic world while the superflu and murderous marauding survivors may be familiar tropes to fans of dystopian fiction don't get hung up on those things or let them deter you because that's not what this book is truly about this book is about love and loss and finding joy even in what seems to be the most desolate life and heller does an absolutely sensational job of capturing those emotions rarely have i felt so pulled into a book emotionally i cried and i felt the feelings of falling in love it was more than empathy i felt for hig as he was suddenly overcome with the emotional reality of his life after 9 years living in what seems like a hell on earth i was transported and was feeling what he felt as i read i was entranced by this book and already know i'll want to read it again a rare thing for me

raw_text.2930: an action story a nature story a grand adventure story this book has it all but more than anything it is a love story hig his beloved dog jasper and bangley a craggy irascible older guy with the skills of an expert crackerjack soldier are holed up in an airplane hangar somewhere in colorado one of the few survivors of a flu pandemic that has totally devastated the world it is nine years since civilization has basically fallen apart nine long years of existing surviving against all odds nine years of being on guard nine years of hig flying his plane around the countryside looking for marauders constantly searching for the bad guys a series of events leads hig to fly off in search of friendly forces what he finds is way more than what he bargained for this book may sound like a man's story and certainly the adventure of it all will appeal to any guy but the language of the book is pure poetry how a human being can survive unspeakable loss and somehow manage to find happiness again in a desolate destroyed dangerous world is at the heart of this novel absolutely wonderful

raw_text.2961: the dog stars by peter heller is a post apocalyptic novel that takes place nine years after a pandemic flu virus has decimated mankind hig has survived along with his dog jasper and his neighbor bangley a gruff well armed survivalist they live at the small airport in colorado where hig kept his plane before civilization ended now he flies surveillance missions along their perimeter looking for any indication that he and bangley should be expecting unwanted visitors hig and bangley cope with their situation quite differently bangley is a loner who almost delights in always being prepared and ready to kill any intruders hig would rather spend time with jasper while flying fishing walking among the remaining trees in the forest and hunting one day hig picks up a part of a transmission full of static that haunts his thoughts more and more are there other survivors out there and is some connection to other humans beyond terse laconic bangley possible it takes a life shattering event to send hig out on a trip to perhaps discover the person behind the radio transmission and maybe some reason to hope in the dog stars heller manages to write in captivating prose an inspired and poetic end of the world novel hig may not quite be the wary cut throat survivalist that he should be to survive but he is still able to at least try to connect with his emotions while making his way through this changed world and the world has changed it wasn't complete annihilation of a nuclear strike nature is intact but global warming is still marching onward so what the flu and blood disease didn't do the changing environment might finish along with the exceptional writing heller manages to make hig a very sympathetic and appealing character he also takes the natural world around hig and does a great job describing it and how hig relates to it for the bleak subject matter this novel doesn't leave you with a hopeless feeling the actual writing style is nontraditional no quotation marks and fragmented thoughts for example so if you think that would bother you please read the excerpt linked below very highly recommended one of the bestexcerpt www peterheller net the raw_text.2980: peter heller's the dog stars is very reminiscent of post apocalyptic books like cormac mccarthy's the road and justin cronin's the passage not only in the fact that these are books about the near end of mankind but also in their characters' desire to find comfort and goodness in what little is left of the human race and the world hig and his dog jasper have survived the epidemic that wiped out everyone he loved including his wife melissa in this new decimated world where species are going extinct and some of the few survivors that remain are dying of a contagious blood disease hig relies on his gun totting neighbor bangley for survival against the ill intending strangers that wander through their property a small abandoned airport they have made their home one day while flying in his 1956 cessna to secure the perimeter hig receives a mysterious transmission through his radio this voice gives him hope that a better life exists beyond his home and sets out to search for the source but what he finds when he arrives is greater than what he ever expected this story in essence is about the basic human need for contact hig hears the unexpected transmission from another pilot and decides to seek him regardless of how dangerous the expedition might be how many attackers he might face or how low his gas tank might get one might think that leaving safety behind for the unknown is downright idiotic and to a certain extent it might be but i believe the force that drives us towards human interaction is also a form of survival hig is idealistic more so that his logical thinking neighbor bangley he is relatable and his flashbacks to his life before and during the epidemic not only give answers to what happened to the world but also give insight into the strong human instinct for survival the choppy writing style might make it hard to read at times but this book is so good that it motivated to write my first review on goodreads in fear of spoiling anything for the reader this review is short but i promise it is not lacking for the post apocalyptic story buff and for the reader in search of deep and moving characters this is a must read

raw_text.2984: the dog starsby peter heller4 starspp 320a loyal dog adventure nature survival and action are all ingredients which make for a fast reading book which you can't put down and peter heller's the dog starshas them all only a small few have survived a rampant virus the earth is heating up and small bands of the survivors roam about pillaging whatever they can find hig lives at an airport in colorado with the beast a 1956 cesna his dog jasper and his neighbor bangley bangley seems to thrive in the survival mode from hig's perspective he enjoys the fighting killing and defending his little world hig however feels constricted he misses a social life and he misses a greater world whenever he can he is either flying or hunting and fishing he longs for another life heller is an adventure writer and it shows reading the book heller's appreciation for nature shows through it is clear that he is comfortable both hunting and fishing and uses these skills to describe hig's adventures in the mountains there are elements to the book which are a bit gruesome and it is a bit violent so the squeamish may want to avoid it i thoroughly enjoyed it

raw_text.2989: originally posted on my blog a lovely bookshelf on the wall the dog stars has the standard elements of the usual post apocalyptic novel most of humanity has been wiped out in this case due to a flu and then a blood disease the protagonists defend their territory from the mostly antagonistic groups of people who remain there is grief for what has been lost and the ever enduring hope for a better future and finding others like them there are even a couple of action scenes but the novel's delivery gives a unique spin this is hig's story told from his point of view and wow is it ever fragmented poor grammar incomplete sentences that just kind of drift off no quotation marks sometimes you have to really concentrate to figure out if he's talking to himself or to another hig refers to himself a brain cooked human i believe it because wow sometimes he is downright incoherent but he mentions he was a writer before the flu hit this approach is a daring choice on the author's part one i felt added to the post apocalyptic confusion and fight to survive while reading my mood went back and forth between the knot in your stomach you get watching the walking dead and the overwhelming loneliness of a jack london novel it was an odd mix for me the middle slowed down a bit but that didn't last too long overall i did enjoy the dog stars i just didn't have many strong feelings about it either way

raw_text.2992: hig is a survivor of an epidemic living with his dog and a nearby neighbor on constant alert for danger by traveling scavengers a pilot who still takes periodic scouting flights he is plagued by the memory of a voice on his radio calling to him from the denver airport i loved this story part post apocalyptic part adventure story this book goes beyond the average post apocalyptic where usually a story of this genre would simply branch off into a good ol' horror yarn this story explores human nature and is a more real look at life after the apocalypse rather than a fantastical look albeit with a somewhat desperate and negative bent assuming the worst of human nature not only a book about survival but a story about the love between a man and his dog hig comes off as a pretty honorable man a man with a conscience and uncomfortable with some of the things he must do his ornery neighbor is not so conflicted he has absolutely no problem with living in the world they now struggle to survive in in fact you get the impression that he may be more comfortable in this post apocalyptic world than the cushy world of the past my final word if you like the post apocalyptic genre and appreciate good writing give this one a try it is a fast read well written with emotional moments there is some brutality but nothing explicit or excessive bound to be one of my favorites of the year very nice

raw_text.2995: when it comes to end of the world stuff i like my reading material to be as bleak as possible which is why the road is one of my all time favourite books when i saw the dog stars being billed as 'the road but with hope' i was marginally intrigued and then decided to pick it up from the library after a friend recommended it the dog stars is one of those books that can be described as both heartwarming and thought provoking our protagonist hig is one of only a handful of people who managed to survive a massive flu outbreak which killed off most of the world's population he lives with his dog jasper and a sociopath neighbour at a tiny airport that they guard against the'others' hig is also a pilot but his plane has limited fuel and is only used for short trips to check for intruders around their encampment the prose is simple but beautiful as hig recounts what he has lost in his life and whether a future can ever be planned again dog lovers will especially love this book as the story certainly reaffirms that old saying of a dog being man's best friend
raw_text.2996: i certainly did not expect to like "the dog stars" desperate to find an audiobook to absorb me as i cleared up post vacation clutter i decided to give this story a chance based on relatively high goodreads and amazon ratings i am glad that i did the summary of the plot sounded grim and depressing the story takes place sometime in the future about nine years after a flu epidemic has killed off a vast percentage of the american and european populations much of the book is about the friendship between hig who struggles to survive and maintain his humanity and bangley who survives by shooting first and occasionally asks questions afterwards although i am not enamoured of the canine population hig's relationship with his dog jasper added much tenderness to the story i listened to this book every chance i got its themes of friendship and coping with loss under unimaginable circumstances were written with sensitivity it was easy to figuratively be on the edge of my seat as i rooted for hig and bangley to survive attacks on their property although i occasionally had to enter a suspension of disbelief mode it did not interfere with my appreciation of this book which i highly recommend

raw_text.3010: dog stars tells the story of hig his dog jasper and his plane the beast hig lives in post apocalyptic america which has been ravaged and essentially wiped out by a strain of the flu nine years ago his days consist of tending the garden killing off intruders flying the perimeter and maintaining an awkward relationship with his survivalist extreme roommate bangley bangley leaves a bit to be desired on the comforting front so when hig hears a radio transmission from an airport just outside his point of no return he feels a temptation he cannot ignore and so he sets out to discover this is a story of loss and it's a story of survival it is told through a more complex version of narrative verse some entire sentences are but or and but i cannot stress enough that this does not detract from the story let me be clear my husband and i listened to this on audiobook and the narrator was out of this world he made the story flow if you do not like to read stream of consciousness on a page i would suggest listening to the audiobook either way i suggest listening to the audiobook it was amazing the style of writing is what i would consider art look i've been reading a lot of dystopian novels there isn't a lot of new material out there this novel is new and fresh because it's told in a different way it's a hero who is not all that skilled and not all that charming but loves things fiercely hig does not understand the world around him but he understands his airplane he does not beat us to death with repetitions of his thoughts but explains his thoughts through his actions we see his grief in not just the actions of hig but in the sentence structure i cannot stress enough that the stream of consciousness of this story lends itself to this story of loss and sadness not to mention which hig was an aspiring poet he feels and sees things through a poet's eyes thus we see everything through a poet's eyes but it's not kitschy or forced at least it wasn't for me hig feels things that i think a genuine human would feel in the world that he lives in he acts in the way that i feel a tired but headstrong but very sad man would act there seemed to be only a few personality types in the book cima hig the poetic moral compasses of the story bangley pops the survivalist bad ass men who do not waste time over thinking things and the side characters the families or the bad guys neither of whom get much time in the book perhaps these are the only people who will survive the bad asses and the people they choose to take care of i love how it all comes back to jasper in the end everything is about jasper and that's saying something considering view spoiler jasper dies halfway through the book hide spoiler peter heller is brilliant and staggeringly so he has written a book about hunting and guns and the cruel people at the end of the world but made it a story about love and loss in a way that can be accessible to almost everyone if that is you can get past the writing style which i suggest you try to do i actually think i will read this book several times there are so many books right now that i put down and say hey that was fun like a movie like a summer blockbuster but this is a book that made me want to pick it right back up as soon as i was finished i already miss hig and jasper and bangley even if i could add the whole book as a quote and like the quote here on goodreads i would the style the characters the story it was just plain amazing note this book is not for everyone this is not a fluffy book there are many parts of this book that are very disturbing but then this is a book about the depravity of the human race at the end of the world

raw_text.3013: when i first pulled peter heller's the dog stars from the shelves of a bookstore i remember muttering a sarcastic "yeah right " after i read a comment on its cover claiming it was "a novel about the end of the world which makes you glad to be alive " that's not the role of apocalyptic fiction i thought but after reading the novel's blurb i decided to give it a go the story is set in a post apocalyptic america a decade after a virus has killed 99% of the population hig a poet handyman gardener fisherman hunter and pilot along with his dog jasper share a small airfield with a bangley a gun toting survivalist they have nothing in common but need each other to survive hig uses his cessna to make daily surveillance flights searching for marauding survivors while bangley uses his guns to kill them all other survivors are deemed threats because hig and bangley both know what they had to do to survive so at the beginning of the book they are hard characters to like but as the book progresses and other survivors attack them it becomes clear that their ruthless defence of the airfield is the only reason they have survived hig bangley and jasper seemed destined to live out their lives together after successfully killing anyone who comes near but then things change i found the story engrossing but the authors writing continually interrupted the flow of the story in particular his decision not to use quote marks to specify dialogue and not to use attributions annoyed me i often had to re read a passage to discover who if anyone had been speaking peter carey did the same thing in the true history of the kelly gang but he is a much better writer than peter heller as i never found myself asking if someone had just spoken carey also had a reason for his lack of dialogue signifiers as he was trying to emulate the absence of punctuation in a the jerilderie letter a letter dictated by ned kelly to joe bryne i wonder why peter heller chose to forgo dialogue signifiers it certainly did not add to the writing another quirk with heller's writing is that he often had the same word twice in a row for example "they had seen enough enough to flee but not the full demise " "before before" was quite common by the end of the dog stars the book had lived up to its front cover comment and instilled some hope for humanity into me it is just a shame that heller's writing style damaged the flow of the story it turned what could have been a really excellent novel into one that is just good

raw_text.3024: knowing that this book is receiving a large amount of well deserved praise is just icing on the cake to this thoroughly engaging read listen in my case the dog stars combined some of the most memorable elements from the following books and movie *i am legend the emotionally stirring relationship between a man and his dog okay this relationshp is actually portrayed in the movie which deviates from the book so much that aside from the same title they could be considered almost completely independent of each other but the movie was awesome and if you didn't get a little misty over the final scene between will smith and his dog you just might want to chop a few onions to make sure that you tear ducts still work seriously *the road by cormac mccarthy the gritty desperation of a world where the majority of humans have become the enemy and yet the emphasis is on the tenderly insightful words and gestures that manage to somehow still exist between characters*walden by henry david thoreau a poetic appreciation of nature not from someone who views it from behind glass or reads about it in books but by a person who plunges themselves physically and spiritually into the whole of itthe overall feel was similar to george r stewart's earth abides which was released in 1949 but with profanity fully automatic weapons and a cessna named the beast and while i think the dog stars can be enjoyed by a fairly large majority of readers i feel that many of the concepts and descriptions will resonate deeply with male readers i hesitate to say this as i don't want to scare any female readers away hopefully my five star rating will testify as to how much i personally enjoyed the book one of my favorite things about post apocalyptic novels is their ability to turn the everyday into the extraordinary because each interaction activity and item is limited they now take on new significance not in the way that a book about extreme poverty or hardship will do in those stories a character may be living without something but that something hasn't ceased to exist for all eternity that glimmer of hope that knowing an object or type of interaction is still available somewhere completely changes the way that we feel about it when you compare it to the knowledge that it's actually gone for good forever the dog stars puts all the mundane details of our lives under a microscope and upon further inspection shows how spectacular each kiss friendly greeting clean shirt and piece of cheese really is through hig the main character we feel the ache of knowing that physical intimacy with another human being might never be experienced again that foods we relish on a daily basis can no longer be enjoyed because the plants that helped produce them or the animals that they are made from cease to be on this planet what a truly aching sense of loss this would create i'd imagine it's like reading the list of extinct animals and then adding just about everything living and inanimate to it i know it's par for the course for readers who dwell in big cities and areas of the country that are consistently used as the settings for novels but it was a wildly new experience for me to read a book where the areas that the characters visit are literally down the street from me or within driving distance yep coloradoans take note the dog stars is written by a colorado author and actually takes place in colorado i know i know if this is something that makes me giddy it's probably a sign that i need to read more colorado authors the erie airport grand junction and a large selection of other colorado cities make an appearance in the book if nothing else read it just so that you can say hey i totally know where he's talking about and can acurately picture it in my mind kind of a lame reason to read a book in my opinion but i'll promote it if it gets more readers to crack open the dog stars for those of you open to an audiobook experience i highly recommend listening to the dog stars mark deakins the narrator has a melodic quality to his voice reminiscent of a younger cooler garrison keillor without being so god awfully quaint the relaxed cadence and pitch of deakins' voice as well as his elegant enunciation there's something just well sexy about impeccable enunciation is perfectly suited for the often poetic quality of the writing
raw_text.3025: hunger games for grown ups recommended by my friend evan in a post apocalyptic universe where most people have died of the flu hig who pilots a cessna and his dog co pilot coexist uneasily with an angry gun obsessed neighbor but one day when hig is out flying he hears a voice on the radio from beyond their little realm and he takes off to look for what's out there it's told first person and hig's voice is a bit difficult to adjust to at first he drops pronouns scatters references abbreviates phrases which i think is heller's way of reminding us that language is community property when the community vanishes language begins to go as well but the language is also at times lovely heller is a poet like here i set down the pack and breathed the smell of running water of cold stone of fir and spruce like the sachets my mother used to keep in a sock drawer i breathed and thanked something that was not exactly god something that was still here i think i have to be done with post apocalyptic books for a while not exactly hammock summer fare as another friend would say but this was a good one

raw_text.3045: fantastic this book has something for everyone it is postapocalyptic adventurous suspenseful there's enough for the animal lover the gun enthusiast the romantic and just about everyone else the story follows protagonist hig who lives on an air base with his dog and neighbor almost 10 years prior most of the world's population had been decimated by a dangerous strain of the flu what follows is hig's struggle with reality interspersed with flashbacks humor philosphy and desire this is the first book by heller who is actually a long time writer for adventure magazines his passion for the outdoors really comes through but not to the point where it detracts from the story character interaction was a strong point here and dialogue felt real if you're worried about this being just another postapocalyptic work i think you will be pleasantly surprised the author differentiates himself in more ways than one and emphasizes character development over plot this would make an awesome movie or mini series if done right go read this now

raw_text.3054: peter heller's vision of a post apocalyptic world is vivid and stunning in the dog stars heller captures a post time state with his flowing prose that encompasses the struggle of hig a fever plague survivor with an old cessna airplane to find peace of mind and a purpose in an american landscape depopulated and fluctuating due to the on going progress of climate change the dog stars simultaneously examines mankind's stubborn persistence to endure and the depths of debased depravity and primordial violence that individuals can sink to when hopes for the future are lost heller's novel is easily compared to mccarthy's the road with the contrast of still allowing for some possibility beyond a gray descent into oblivion other than the stark relief provided by the bulk of humanity's departure there is little in the way of two dimensional good and evil in the dog stars the relatively limited cast of characters is as contextualized and vivacious as the novel's sprawling landscape heller's first novel is a tour de force and well worth the read i hope it is one of more novels to come

raw_text.3059: this is a great little book i highly recommend the audio book edition read by mark deakins a few good qoutes " the dog stars gripped me--it's the real deal heller's voice is extraordinary and his narrator's toughness seems to hide a beautiful and aching restlessness one of those books that makes you happy for literature " --junot diaz wall street journal"lyrical this is a beautiful haunting and hopeful book written with a poetic sparseness that makes your breath catch and your heart ache " --carole o'brien aspen daily news online"beautifully narrated a book that will surprise you hig is a charmer a man of his word with a wicked sense of humor and an acute sense of survival his eyes are open to the world as only a poet's can be observing and absorbing any beauty left in the aftermath of the world's tragedy the author shocks readers with unexpected bursts of action packed scenes that keep the book moving at a suspenseful pace without compromising the literary style heller has written a rare novel that combines readability with high style prose while making each compliment the other the result is a book that rests easily on shelves with dean koontz jack london or hemingway the prose in this novel is anything but conventional it often is painfully beautiful as the story lapses into arching poetic verse when high is pushed to the very depths of despair yet still he retains hope the dog stars illustrates the strength of bonds that can be formed between men the fierce companionship between man and dog and the inner struggle of a survivor's guilt with gut wrenching clarity heller's sensitivity to nature and descriptive detail brings about an appreciation that will make readers pause if only for a moment to reflect on the majesty of their own natural surroundings it's a tale of humanity after doomsday from an author who's not afraid to step out of his comfort zone " --mindy sansoucie the missourian

raw_text.3079: a surprisingly elegiac post apocalyptic story the story is set nine years after a pandemic that wiped out almost all of the human race and narrated by a well rounded outdoorsman with a taste for poetry presumably a lot like the author who made his name with adventure travel narratives before this his first novel the narrator is holed up in a small airport on a rural part of colorado's front range with one neighbor a psychopathic survivalist who seems disturbingly at home in this environment which is effectively that of a zombie story without zombies as the only other surviving humans appear to be mad max esque marauders the role of narrator hig is to fly fly an old cessna reconnoitering the territory and picking up supplies the story reaches a turning point where hig cannot maintain the status quo and moves on from there it's a great read but where the book really caught me was in its occasional ruminations and meditations on grief that's what elevates the dog stars beyond a pure genre book
raw_text.3080: wow simply put this is the best book i have read in years i have never felt a connection to a book like i did for peter heller's 'the dog stars' heller creates a frightening and realistic world through disjointed but incredibly evocative language his main character hig is so beautifully raw a man overwhelmed by his heart wrenching past horrific present and unknown future this book is 'the road' coupled with more humanity compassion and hope you know a good book when you cry at the end not because its sad but because you don't want it to finish i would recommend this to anyone it's true what the cover says a novel about the end of the world that makes you glad to be alive

raw_text.3086: i liked this book it was entertaining although at times it did remind me a little too much of a hollywood movie the actions sequences the ammo the excessive good luck of the protagonists when facing peril that said it makes for a good summer reading ok now i need to get out of my chest a couple of thoughts on the plot so what follows immediately after this sentence are spoilers what i really found interesting in this book is the relationship between hig and bangley during the first half the book hig has a sort of ambiguity towards bangley on the one hand bangley is crazy scary and aggressive the quintessential macho man on the other hand several times does he remind hig of a wife granted the context in which these references appear is not sexual but still i found it an interesting choice of words there is even an odd moment in which hig is talking with bangley and there is a piece of tobacco in bangley's face hig describes it as looking exactly as marilyn monroe's mole it did seem at that point like hig was experiencing a sort of attraction so much so that the perfect girl had to be produced out of nowhere to remedy the situation well i guess it's all a manner of how you look at it

raw_text.3111: this is a beautiful book by an author that obviously has a great love for animals and nature the narrator hig has survived the end of the world where 99 9% of the population has died from the flu and the predictions of global warming are coming true he has been living at a small commuter airport with his dog jasper and another survivalist for the past 9 years and has begun to question his will to live a bleak existence where living consists of primarily guarding the perimeter against other violent survivors eating u0026amp sleeping the theme of finding meaning in a meaningless life is a classic theme and the author handles it superbly heller manages to portray beauty and hope as hig flies his small cessna plane across the mountains and plains of colorado the moments of grace has he sees signs of re growth of plants in spite of the droughts beauty in the sight of a grizzly mom and her cubs or a glimpse of bull elk thought extinct there is ultimately hope of a better future in spite of the tragedies of the past and purpose in life may just be enjoying those moments of beauty oh and i can't resist a book with a really great dog companion who is hig's co pilot as much as this story has resonated with me there were some flaws that keep from giving it 5 stars the cadence of the writing with short stilted and fragmented sentences was distracting at first though either the author either stopped or lessened the use of this technique or i got used to it because it seemed to diminish further into the book i didn't understand the point of jasper's unpleasant dining habits or the entire scene at the grand junction airport or the reference to the mysterious planes piloted by arabs that fly overhead near the end lastly while it may be an accurate prediction of humor behavior but it was depressing to think that after most of the human race has died rather than valuing life the remaining human's main activity appears to be trying to kill each other

raw_text.3142: this quiet meditative post apocalyptic tale is punctured by battles with maurauders who breach the perimeter that hig the protagonist of the story and his survivalist neighbor bangley have devised around the abandoned airport where they reside it is nine years after a pandemic the blood a highly virulent and contagious flu has drastically reduced the population and turned most of the remaining survivors into grim opportunists hig is a former general contractor who built single family homes and wrote articles for outdoor magazines his wife melissa a school teacher died from the sickness when she was seven months pregnant with their first child hig spends his days flying in an old cessna with his dog jasper to survey the harsh landscape or to enjoy some hunting and fishing events cause hig to take off one day without sufficient fuel to return to the airport although heller creates a world that is bleak he holds out some hope that human relationships can be redemptive

raw_text.3144: i like how peter heller wrote this story in an understated style and slowly unfolds details of the past written from the main character's point of view a man hig who is surviving his ninth year into a post apocalyptic world with his dog jasper and another survivor who is a bit more ruthless than he is bangley hig remembers how the world was before the event and mourns it daily as tries to find new routines to pass the time bangley and hig are an unlikely pair a partnership born out of necessity as hig is a bit of a renaissance man able to hunt and fish yet loves poetry who also cooks and can fly planes on the other hand bangley is more ruthless and without sentiment and as hig says at one point bangley was waiting for the end his whole life we all know someone like this someone who is a little bit off in normal society but is exactly who you'd want to have around in a post apocalyptic world he'd have the guns and the food caches and the ability to thrive alone in a lawless world without needing or missing human interaction hig always questions his value to bangley and sometimes wonders why bangley hasn't killed him yet they turned an old airport into their home and hig is able to fly an old plane to constantly check the perimeter and anticipate attacks from wandering survivors and also catch glimpses of hope i liked this story it was a bit predictable in formula but i enjoyed unearthing the details of the past and the simple gruff style in which it was written worth reading and i am definitely going to need more guns and a dog like jasper

raw_text.3151: i would rate this around a 3 and 1 2 i really liked the story i would recommend it to another reader heller's writing was somewhat hemingway esque there were moments in the text that reminded me of reading the nick adam stories the meticulous description of landscape the current of the river breathing life back into a war weary soul and taciturn characters are right out of hemingway's novella the allusions to hemingway gave me the sense the heller has been influenced by him as a writer the plot motivated me as a reader there were moments i shuddered at the idea of a world laid desolate by a pandemic flu it seems far less fiction than an all too possible reality it also set the story up for some nice philosophical play as well as questions about human nature the idea of morality as seen in today's world was set aside creating a frailty in clinging too strongly to notions of judea christian ethics the characterization was complex with complementing foils that felt natural the disdain hig holds for his bunk mate bangley is coupled nicely with a pragmatic respect created by his dependency on him hig's sentiment is somewhat pathetic when it puts himself and those around him at risk yet it tends to give bangley a conscious and a connection to humanity hig's relationship with his dog was heart wrenching for a reader that has a dog that is like a family member the emotional connection expressed is even stronger the mennonites sick with the blood disease demonstrate the notion that there can be organized and humane life in a post apocalyptic world yet their threads of survival seem questionable in such a harsh an unforgiving environment the narrative ends with the potential for a pretty decent sequel one that i would pick up and read with all that why not give the book a higher rating for me the plot lagged as a story telling device heller's pace is reasonable it truly does bring the reader into a world filled with predictable drudgery despite the occasional fire fight and death scene unfortunately the pace was killing me i am one who can read only so many descriptions of extent fish and blackened forests before i am too weary of the setting this happened rather early for me as the pace slowed i made a lot of predictions to keep me connected to the text to my disappointment i was able to guess events well before they unfolded this left potential plot twists bland and unsavory further the notion of the survival instinct turning back the evolutionary clock leaving so many people functioning primarily on their reptilian brain a bit extreme call me a pollyanna but i feel as if i have to believe that our species has he capacity for more than brutal savage attack when faced with questions of survival i hold to the hope the artistry of humanity is weaved together with something stronger than the grim outcomes this story suggests had more of the book read like the part iii i think i would have to given it more stars but i waded through a lot of dying pine to get to the inevitable and predictable last few chapters i am interested in reading other review it also appears that i need to take some time and read the road by mccormick i have read a few reviews that praise the book on all levels yet the responses are general and vague i think this is a book that might serve a book club pretty well

raw_text.3157: this book was really good and really unique i am challenged by how i feel about the book not in how it impacted me but the writing itself i do respect the book and i feel accomplished that i read it but it was a challenging read and not so much challenging that it makes it better i found myself getting lost in my own thoughts more times than i care for during any reading it isn't that it didn't hold my attention i often do this but the writing style allowed my mind to flow elsewhere when the writing itself didn't i fully understand and respect the style of writing it just wouldn't be the same without it nor as strong of a novel and when my mind was involved it was there 110 percent this novel is separated into three books the prose in each consecutive book was a little less jarring and the narration a little more riveting and interesting therefore i do have to say as the novel progressed i enjoyed it more and more i am glad i read this book through and through i do say i will have to read it again because i feel i missed a lot of what heller was trying to accomplish it reads to me like poetry i get a lot of it but it needs further investment to get all that is there this is my first foray into post apocalyptic writing and i do say i thoroughly enjoy it really it begs the question what if many passages refer to not knowing what you have until you lose it the fear of the future instead of the happiness of the present etc it is a great novel for self and world societal reflection it doesn't do it in your face so it is really up to the reader to do so i did so and i enjoyed if that can ever be the right word for a post apocalyptic novel that it did make me think i would recommend it and have done so several times already

raw_text.3183: while the post apocalyptic survivor story is a familiar one heller's unique style and poeticism help the dog stars stand out it's a novel that focuses on weapons tactics and gore and on introspection loss and loneliness in equal measure but while it's an amusing read it failed to make a significant impression on me i appreciated the unconventionality of heller's stream of consciousness poetic style more than i actually enjoyed the writing itself it's certainly refreshing and it reminded me somewhat of miriam toews' writing style in a complicated kindness which i love but at the same time i rarely felt moved by the story or its observations the characters seemed somewhat flat and cliche and the narrator protagonist hig had too much hemingway machismo for my taste i was disappointed that the story had such potential to discuss human relationships and society in a relevant way but instead offered little aside from its colourful visceral presentation of the protagonist's experiences the few sex scenes were particularly awful for their stereotypically male misrepresentation of women's sexuality heller describes vulvas as mounds countless times and uncritically describes hig trying to force his dick into someone's dry pussy even though it's obviously hurting her and how she instantly comes when he's inside her with no foreplay or stimulation and of course he's sure to tell us all about her boyishly thin frame with impossibly spherical breasts but overall aside from the sex the writing itself was skilful and often beautiful--just ultimately not that interesting on any deeper levels despite the story's flatness and lack of original voice it boasts an exciting plot and the book doesn't pretend to be anything it's not so my deeper criticisms about its cultural relevance and laughable description of women should be taken with a grain of salt it's not a bad book and if you're looking for a gritty adventure story with literary sophistication look no further but if you're looking for a novel that challenges convention and your own perspectives you'll probably find that the dog stars only echoes albeit skillfully the white male perspective that already dominates the literary canon

raw_text.3214: it's colorado nine years after a series of plagues mostly flu variations and other diseases have wiped out most of the population our protagonist hig is a little brain addled partly because of damage from his own bout with fever partly because of all the awful stuff he has seen and partly because i'm a bit but only a bit facetious here he's a poet hig lives on an airfield with his dog jasper and the mysterious and homicidal bangley a survivalist of the first order basically hig has survived because bangley kills everyone who comes near the airfield at a distance no questions asked although hig has done a bit of killing himself he flies out to collect a few supplies and to do recon occasionally with jasper he tends to his cessna keeps a garden and occasionally fishes although all that has survived are carp and some other bottom feeders the rest of the time he thinks depressive but poetic thoughts he's pre occupied by a message sent from a tower of an airport a place that's too far away to visit without refueling think of this as the road with a dog instead of a kid it's about as bleak although not quite and the bleakness is somewhat mitigated by a protagonist whose thoughts are on an artier level than the average person's would be and who is trying to retain some optimism i found him a bit tiresome a bit hard to believe at times on the plus side it's not a predictable book and i think the finish is the best pat i would ultimately recommend it more to the literary fiction reader who wants to dabble in an apocalyptic setting than the hardcore science fiction reader who may find it a bit pretentious

raw_text.3231: this book was a natural follow up to earth abides also post influenza pandemic the novel fast forwards nine years and follows the lives a few discordant stragglers eking out a living in dire circumstances while the scope is more limited to the personal the protagonist and author by extension are poets and as such bring a certain lyrical perspective to the surroundings and events and depth you would expect from an academic which is something a bit novel in a collapse novel save for earth abides also great about the novel is the practical knowledge research the author put into the text as so much of it takes place in colorado state much of the novel is a naturalistic review of the land and the changes wrought by man's absence and the lingering effects of it's last remnants on what's left of the landscape this book is definitely referencing earth abides thematically but more up to date including modern research regarding the practical tactical survival aspects that seem to be the sole focus in other collapse stories generally devoid of a meaningful narrative and characters with depth definitely one of the better modern books in this genre i have read so far

raw_text.3244: this was an amazing book it's written in the first person by hig one of the few survivors of a plague that wiped out most of the world's population it's now a post apocalyptic world the way heller has hig telling the story is kind of a stream of consciousness the punctuation is really odd periods in places you would not expect and the rythm was hard to get used to at first but once you do the writing flows and is lyrical and lovely hig is a very deep thinker and says incredibly profound things he also has a dog jasper and a partner named bangley hig is the thinker and bangley is more the action guy they get along in a weird kind of symbiotic way i don't want to say too much about hig's adventures he's also a pilot and flies a lot which echoes the way he looks at things it's one of the best books i've read in a long time and i def recommend the read

raw_text.3248: i read a blurb that sums things up nicely attributed to pam houston author of contents may have shifted "leave it to peter heller to imagine a postapocalyptic world that contains as much loveliness as it does devastation his hero hig flies a 1956 cessna his dog as copilot around what was once colorado chasing all the same things we chase in these pre annihilation days love friendship the solace of the natural world and the chance to perform some small kindness the dog stars is a wholly compelling and deeply engaging debut " that neatly summarizes the gist of the book without giving away much at all one thing to note is the protagonist narrator's often clipped style speaking in fragments with no quotation marks it worked fine for me and reminded me of mccarthy and gave the writing a sense of urgency but i have seen complaints other than that the book was touching depressing and yet somehow uplifting it's populated by extremes perhaps even caricatures but that can be explained as the most likely people to survive a global pandemic ultimately very little suspension of disbelief is required a rather scary thought and you're left to contemplate the character's actions and perhaps consider what your own might be in a similar situation
raw_text.3249: i don't give five stars lightly i loved everything about this book and would recommend it to anyone this post apocalyptic story is told by hig who miraculously survives the plague which kills about 99% of the population he lives in a small airport in colorado along with one other survivor the total devastation of civilization as we know it and the fight to survive are told vividly in great and believable detail the storytelling is from hig's point of view in an almost stream of conciousness journal style some passages are clearly disjointed incomplete sentences and confusion but others are beautiful filled with hig's writing skills from his pre apocalypse life i'm trying to write a review with no spoilers here so i will just say that the plot and the realities of life in this world are quite bleak and terrible at times but at others beauty and hope still survive this isn't really a quick read but i loved every minute of it and wanted more

raw_text.3254: as one who isn't a major fan or connoisseur of post apocalyptic novels i'm at a disadvantage at least in comparing it with others in the genre it's not quite mad max but there's certainly graphic violence while most characters stick to what seems to be the golden rule of the dystopian future do unto others before they do unto you our narrator wants you to see that he still has remnants of humanity as he helps a family afflicted by the "blood" disease that has come after the killer flu and can actually asks questions first shoot later as opposed to his pa'dner whom he describes in the usual cliche there's also much lyrical description of the remnants of the wilderness as well as a rather disjointed narrative at times matter of fact at times stream of confused and bewildered consciousness of course one must suspend one's disbelief just to get started so one might as well accept all of the relatively good fortune that has allowed our narrator to survive to this point and to successfully take off into and successfully return from parts unknown to find more humanity love etc i would have liked to see what allowed him to survive his initial encounter with the associate who is already a presence before the narrative clearly a very capable capital s survivor or how others were able to band together to do whatever they had to do otherwise most of the human encounters are determined by who has the better weapons and strategies still an engaging imaginative foray into a possible future

raw_text.3266: when i hear the term dystopian literature i shudder from the memory of being haunted as a teenager traumatized from the potential despair i read about in books like fahrenheit 451 brave new world and 1984 of those three texts only one hinted at a hopeful possibility of rebuilding from the ashes enter peter heller's the dog stars a beautifully written intelligent highly contemplative and psychological answer to the hopelessness of an orwellian or huxleyesque world big hig is one of a few survivors of a viral epidemic that left the world to decay under the reign of terror of roving bands of destructive savages nine years on a compound that he shares with an outlandish crude but brilliant artillery tactician and gun fanatic have left hig feeling trapped and hopeless but like apollo who spent nine years repenting for slaying the pythian dragon hig has the power of flight the only thing that liberates him and ties his spirits to his soaring cesna the classic hero paradigm blooms under heller's masterful storytelling replete with new interpretations of the old themes of seeking spiritual fulfillment death and resurrection heller also balances philosophical pondering with moments of sheer terror and despair capturing the full spectrum of the human experience while it was difficult for me to shake the haunting memories of the dystopian literature of my youth it will be even more difficult for me to shake the haunting sense of hope for rebuilding from the ashes that the dog stars left me with and i am glad for that

raw_text.3290: i really enjoyed this book it started a little slow for me but i find that some of the best books i've read go this route to really set up the stage so that you're as familiar with what's going on as the author the main character hig is 9 years into surviving after a sickness has taken out most of the now post apocalyptic world he has a dog and one person in his entire world bangley who he's not sure of at times if he is friend or foe hig takes you into his life of survival and on his journey if not kicking and screaming at times you feel all he felt the desolation the heart break the joy the fear all of it there were times i realized i'd stopped breathing because i was right in the thick of it with hig even though the world is desolate and empty there are still lovely and beautiful moments that hig experiences one of the main plots of the book is view spoiler him struggling to survive other people who are struggling to survive hide spoiler the author's detailed description of the world around him and the splaying of his thoughts and emotions draw you into the story i must say that i was disappointed in having to skip most of a chapter because of the obligatory sex scene not sure why authors feel they need to include graphic sex scenes in order to produce a good book just not all of us want to know what goes on in other people's bedrooms even fictitious ones totally not necessary this is a really good story and i think you will really enjoy it i'm not sure how i feel about the ending yet seems like there were some loose ends maybe some things not said but maybe that is to be filled in however we want it's a book that stays with you even after you have put it down which by the way i had a hard time doing i hope to see hig again to catch up with him in a couple of years or so

raw_text.3311: this was my first apocalyptic novel i developed an interest in this book and giving the apocalypse genre a try after hearing an interview of peter heller about this book on npr the fact that the story takes place near denver and surrounding areas in colorado peaked my interest it's definitely not something i would typically read but i enjoyed it obviously a book taking place post apocalypse is not going to be a cheery read it was very sad i found myself reading with tears streaming down my face at one point and i appreciate a book that can create an emotional reaction from me i also was impressed by how much i cared about the characters the events were mostly predictable but there were a few surprises along the way i wasn't a huge fan of portraying essentially all of humanity as evil violent blood thirsty or cold excluding the protagonist but i have a feeling that comes with the territory of this genre overall i liked it but i still think the post apocalypse genre isn't my cup of tea here's the npr interview if you're interested http www npr org 2012 08 13 1586894

raw_text.3316: reminiscent of the road but a bit less dark and dreary from reading a brief summary about this book beforehand i was afraid it was going to be a story about a man and his dog i'm happy to report it is not that there are man and his dog moments but that is definitely not the prevalent theme no instead it is a beautiful almost poetic tale of one man's journey through profound loneliness and inability to move on from the past at it's core it's a story of undergoing a momentous loss and change in extreme circumstances it's written in a style of broken fragmented sentences which takes a bit of getting use to but once done becomes almost poetic if you liked the road or enjoy delving into stories that seek to discover what it means to be human then i highly recommend this book

raw_text.3318: actual rating 4 5 stars i have friends who swore off post apocalyptic science fiction after reading cormac mccarthy's the road peter heller's the dog stars is the antidote you all can come back now you hear which is not to say peter heller's hellscape is populated with unicorns and ponies it's a hellscape all right the continental us reverting to nature after a blood disease has killed off more than 99% of the population unfortunately before we did anything to combat global warming which is now compounding the problem of survival with a devastating drought two men live near an abandoned airport somewhere in the high plains of eastern colorado defending their homestead against occasional marauders bent on killing them and taking whatever they have one is a poet who likes to fish and hunt and fly the other a monosyllabic survivalist with a taste for weaponry and killing the poet narrates and he has plenty of time to tell his story as he hikes or flies an old cessna to conduct surveillance the poet has a beloved dog and a soft spot for an extended family of mennonites who have managed to survive on a farmstead several miles away one day while flying he makes a radio transmission for old time's sake and gets a garbled response enough to let him know that someone like him a pilot is living at the airport in grand junction west of the rockies and just at the limit of his flying range after the death of his dog he decides that voice from grand junction is the only thing he has left to live for and flies off in that direction along the way he sees a man and a woman tending sheep and cattle near a stream in the rocky mountain foothills and then the story gets better i'll stop now lest i spoil it for you the narrator hig he of the dog and hunting and fishing validate all the flying information heller's character passed on i gave heller the benefit of the doubt and believed everything he told me about trout elk bear deer and the rapidity with which roads and buildings will crumble after we're no longer around to maintain them heller clearly knows his stuff and the writing is crystal clear did i mention the narrator hig is a poet some of the writing here reminded me of antoine de saint exupery i've told you enough by now to show you that there is an element of hope in this post apocaplytic world of peter heller's and that is what makes it a more read it

raw_text.3341: a hopeful man lost in a world where survival of the fittest has turned ordinary people into killers he is a grieving man who has lost everything and everyone he loves to a super flu except his dog and his plane his only company a man who must have starred in our doomsday preppers cable show this lonely sensitive man is our narrator who writes in a stream of consciousness style that can feel a bit too short hand especially when there are no quote marks at times you are not sure who says what not that there is a lot of conversation going on and that is the moral really what is important is our connection to one another his world is very believable in a possible not too distant future perhaps that makes this book so depressing and hopeful at the same time because where there is life left there is hope though the sentences were fragmented which made it hard to read at times i am glad that i did his ability to describe nature the love for his dog and for fishing and his skill and desire to keep flying drew me and held me in his story telling spell
raw_text.3342: there's a certain grim realism to the way even the most basic everyday tasks including defending oneself are laden with difficulty and peril in the post apocalyptic world of the dog stars and it's this grim realism that make the little victories that much more significant and makes hig's adventure that much more monumental hig is to me a believable and likable character he's a good man who knows how to handle himself and i like that somewhere deep down he refuses to fall to the savagery the the rest of the country has throughout the book he demonstrates that at heart he's peaceful a romantic but this is balanced by his willingness to do what needs to be done to survive he will and does kill people in this wasteland and doesn't let his tenderness get in the way but clearly has no taste for it it's this balance that i found to be compelling and realistic conversely the way the rest of humanity is depicted is at the same time frustrating and to be expected with few exceptions everyone is out for their own survival ready to kill hig and take what they can from him without a second thought it's frustrating to know how hig misses human contact besides his gun nut partner and then have his few interactions involve bullets and slaughter but then what are we to expect given the world that's been established it's a post apocalyptic story with a heart written in the vein of cormac mccarthy probably one of my favorite books i've read lately and i'd strongly recommend it to anyone who likes this genre

raw_text.3354: let me preface my review by stating that is not a book i normally would chose to read but i decided i needed to stretch my literary boundaries and so i took a chance with the dog stars after i read several good reviews from various sources the story takes place after a pandemic flu wipes out 99 x% of the people on earth to add a morbidly ironic twist one of the only groups to survive are those suffering from a blood aids like disease so instead of dying rapidly and painfully from the flu they get to die slowly and painfully most everyone left on earth are savage killing machines who roam the country and destroy what is left of the previous civilization aka before the protagonist hig appears to be the only human left with even a slight moral compass but he must use deadly force in the kill or be killed state of the world hig has forged a prickly partnership with bangley a brilliant military strategist who lives for battle bangley does have his own moral code in that he only kills those who venture into his perimeter however he shoots first and asks questions later and since bangley is a sharp shooter extraordinaire no one really has a chance to speak hig is struggling with his conscience he has lost his wife baby and everything that matters to him in life and often questions about why bother going on and then hig's dog jasper dies the only living thing left on the plant that he truly loved seriously could this get any more depressing many of the other reviewers said this is a story of hope but i don't see that at all even in a few moments when hig finds happiness he realizes his joy is fleeting and soon the world will be terrible again when he flies his airplane the beast to find himself and some form of humanity it just leads him to one of the most devious killing traps imaginable he does find some form of love and comfort with a female companion but they are both so wracked with guilt about betraying their deceased spouses you wonder about the relationship definitely not a happily ever after one last note i listened to this book on audio the narrator highlighted the beautiful elegant and sometimes magical writing which is high praise considering that i trudged through the plot line one reviewer mentioned that the author used faulkner like punctuation throughout the printed book and if i had to struggle through that mess on top of the story this book would probably have ended up as a dnf

raw_text.3358: spoilers spoilers spoilersi know this is a best seller i know it's been on people's short list for a long time i don't think it's actually worth all the trouble first the good i loved peter heller's syntax the way he moves from memory to action while fitting everything into the narrator's head good job now the bad the dog stars is a libertarian's wet dream man gets stranded in colorado after the apocalypse with all of his guns plus his private single engine plane he lives with another psychotic gun nut who's sole job is to make the narrator look like a saint narrator must use guns to keep apocalyptic stragglers off his lawn his nag of a wife literally pleads him to suffocate her with a pillow which is okay because he flies off and finds a newer younger girlfriend after getting explicit consent from her equally libertarian father my biggest problem with the book is how it's an apocalypse survival story and yet none of the main characters die i got to the end of the book put it down and felt hugely disappointed bottom line read this if you love libertarian nonsense otherwise steer clear

raw_text.3376: when someone gives me a book as a new year's gift all i want to say is "i loved it i loved it so much that the rest of 2013 will only extend my love for this book amplifying it month by month all the way up until next christmas season when i will reread this book and my renewed love for it will reanimate me throughout the next new year and beyond into holiday season 2014 " perhaps that expectation is a bit much to place upon the dog stars peter heller's adroit mash up of the road hemingway's fishing stories marley and me and any book with a male narrator who talks about a new relationship as though he were a chick the dog stars has one thing that the road lacked sap it is no mean feat to inject sap into a post apocalypse dystopia but heller has made that injection for some readers the author's lapse into sweet sludgy goo will be like the very life's blood of narrative itself after all books are made of paper paper comes from trees and sap is the blood of trees however i fast forwarded through the last third of the dog stars i felt if i read every word the goop would adhere to me and the year is far too young for that
